 7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation

16. Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office à l’égard du
       projet
Je suis agriculteur, dont le terrain est touché par le tracé éventuel du pipeline Oléoduc Énergie Est. Je suis
technicien forestier et agricole (2 diplômes). L'éventualité du passage de cet Oléoduc m'inquiète, de même
pour ma conjointe (agronome), au plus haut point. Nous craignons beaucoup les déversements qui auraient
une incidence majeure sur notre vie et notre entreprise: qualité de l'eau potable (perte potentielle
d'approvisionnement en eau potable):domestique, alimentation du bétail, irrigation des cultures. Nous
craignons aussi une perte de fertilité des sols, des répercussion négatives sur nos ventes (produits de crénaux
à image écologique) et la fréquentation de nos activités agrotouristiques.
Nous croyons aussi que la perte de terrain productif n'est pas assez prise en compte. C'est un capital forestier
et foncier (sols agricoles) qui risque de disparaître. Ce sont des ressources renouvelables (récoltes annuelles
et récurrentes), tant pour nous que pour toute la communauté locale qui en bénéficie par nombre d'activités
connexes. De plus, nous sommes déjà touché par le passage de quatre (4) lignes à haute-tension d'Hydro-
Québec. Qu'adviendra-t-il de notre entreprise et celle de nombre de nos voisins si on continue d'en diminuer
les superficies productives? Est-ce une tendance lourde que d'utiliser ce corridor pour y faire circuler de
l'énergie?
La question de la circulation sur l'emprises de l'oléoduc nous préoccupe énormément, puisque c'est un
endroit où nous circulons plusieurs dizaines de jours par année avec de la machinerie.
Nous craignons évidemment aussi une diminution de la valeur foncière de notre propriété et au moment
d'une éventuelle vente de notre propriété.
Et nous croyons que tous les effets négatifs peuvent avoir un impact sur la perception de la région et la
rétention des jeunes notamment. L'opinion publique plutôt mauvaise et l'acceptabilité sociale plus que
discutable actuellement au Québec semble en être un indice. Je pourrais aussi parler des tensions entre
voisins causées par le sujet.
Et plus de mon opinion personnelle réfléchie sur les questions ciblées, je serai en mesure de formuler un
scénario approfondissant et chiffrant la perte potentielle socio-économique liée à la perte de superficies:
diminution des rendements agricoles, perte de superficies forestières productives (valeur économique d'une
forêt gérée écologiquement, tant au niveau du bois que des produits forestiers non-ligneux), montants qui
seraient autrement injectés dans l'économie locale.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
8.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of increased marine shipping
I wish to be recognized as having relevant information that will assist the Board in understanding the
project's potential impacts on the state of water quality of the Saint John River and the Bay of Fundy in New
Brunswick, and in identifying and assessing the potential cumulative environmental effects of the Energy East
project in New Brunswick.
I am an environmental consultant and university teacher and have a B.Sc. (Ecology) and a law degree.
Because of the nature of my work, I have a good understanding of many of New Brunswick's environmental
issues. In addition, through my 10-plus years of work in New Brunswick, I have worked on or participated in
the environmental assessment of several large projects, including the proposed second Irving Oil refinery in
Saint John (Eider Rock Project) and the proposed Sisson Brook tungsten and molybdenum mine.
I obtained my knowledge regarding the state of the Saint John River's water quality through my work as an
environmental consultant in general and more specifically by being a co-editor of a report, "The Saint John
River: A state of the environment report" (2011)
(http://www.unb.ca/research/institutes/cri/_resources/pdfs/criday2011/cri_sjr_soe_final.pdf). The report
provided a synthesis of primarily recent and some historical data, information and studies regarding common
indicators of freshwater environmental quality and described trends in the condition of these indicators
along the Saint John River.
I obtained my knowledge regarding the state of the Bay of Fundy's water quality through my continuing work
on a project the purpose of which is to develop on Ocean Health Index (OHI)
(http://www.oceanhealthindex.org) score for the Bay of Fundy. Calculation of an OHI score requires data for
a number of indicators and metrics in a particular region. As part of this project, I have been responsible for
identifying and reviewing these data for the Bay of Fundy. Examples of these data include commercial
fisheries statistics, pollutant levels in mussels, marine trash and debris, and the conditions of various habitat
types such as rockweed.
Regarding the issue of assessing the cumulative environmental effects of the project, as mentioned above, I
have participated in the assessments of several large projects in the province. In addition, because of my
work I am aware of many other projects and activities that have impacts on the New Brunswick environment.
I have reviewed the proponent's Application and am of the belief that its cumulative effects assessment has
not identified all relevant past, present or future projects that may interact with the Energy East pipeline in
New Brunswick.
The information discussed above is unique because little of the data sources I have used in my work have
been referenced in the Application. The information I will provide will assist the Board because it is a
synthesis--a one stop shop--of water quality data for New Brunswick.

I wish to comment on the climate impacts of the project.
I have worked as a climate policy analysts with various environmental nongovernmental organizations over

universities. For the last five years, I have taught a course on energy policy and the environment at the

   Je souhaite participer de la façon suivante :
            ~ Auteur d’une lettre de commentaires
            { Intervenant
                                             Intérêt ou expertise
            ; Je suis directement touché par le projet proposé.
               Je possède des renseignements pertinents ou une expertise appropriée.
               Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
1.      Les éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques du projet proposé, notamment ceux qui
        sont décrits dans la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation environnementale.
6.      La planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement, d’accident ou de défaillance durant les
        étapes de construction et d’exploitation du projet proposé.
L'oléoduc traversera la rivière Trois-Saumons, à moins de 10 Km de la résidence que j'habite à l'embouchure
de cette rivière. En cas de bris ou de déversement, le pétrole suivra une série de petites cascades, une section
agricole inondable et ensuite de nouvelles cascades jusqu'à la chute située sur la propriété que j'habite. Le
contact avec le fleuve se fait dans une baie qui borne le terrain de ma résidence. C'est un milieu très riche
pour les oiseaux migrateurs et particulièrement l'oie blanche. Une arrivée de pétrole, même en faible
quantité aurait un impact majeur. En cas de bris pendant la saison hivernale, la résurgence du pétrole se fera
fort probablement au pied de la chute où l'eau vive reste visible, malgré la glace.
J'ai l'intention de faire la preuve que les premiers répondants de Saint-Jean-Port-Joli n'ont aucune formation,
ni équipements pour intervenir. Avec l'aide d'experts, je voudrais évaluer le temps de réponse disponible en
cas de fuite à l'endroit où l'oléoduc traversera la rivière Trois-Saumons pour atteindre le fleuve et ensuite son
comportement en fonction des marées.
Par faible débit, le bassin peu profond derrière le barrage pourrait être un endroit stratégique pour contenir
le pétrole de surface.
Du point de vue économique, je voudrais déposer un mémoire démontrant que l'oléoduc a un impact négatif
quantifiable quant aux emplois manufacturiers en Chaudière-Appalaches.

            ; I am directly affected by the proposed Project
               I have relevant information or expertise
                                         Connection to Project Issues
1.     The need for the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
This pipeline would cross numerous tributaries of the Ottawa river, which supplies Ottawa with its drinking
water. I reside in Ottawa for parts of the year and concerned about the quality of my drinking water.
Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year, the
same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads and larger than the climate footprint of an Atlantic
province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE). This is also 10 million tonnes per year larger than the Keystone XL pipeline
which the United States Environmental Protection Agency just determined to have a significant impact on
climate change. The National Energy Board needs to take the climate upstream climate impact of Energy East
into effect as there is no other federal review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East impact nearly every issue already on the list of issues:
If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit warming to 2 degree celcius there is no proven
need for Energy East as tar sands expansion must be capped (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
The economic feasibility is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble & the low price of
oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and ways of life and much more.
For these reasons and so many more related to climate change the NEB needs to include climate change in
it’s review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across
Canada.

517 Tenth Avenue SW                                                                          Telephone/Téléphone : (403) 292-4800
Calgary, Alberta T2R 0A8                                                                      Facsimile/Télécopieur : (403) 292-5503

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
7.     Safety and security during construction of the proposed project and operation of the project, including
       emergency response planning and third-party damage prevention.
9.     The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue.
A portion of the proposed Eastern Mainline pipeline is planned to transit an area located within the
boundaries of the Town of Greater Napanee which has been identified as having groundwater contaminated
by leachate from the Richmond landfill. This area does not have access to municipal water system and
residents and farmers depend on groundwater for domestic and agricultural uses. The Concerned Citizens
Committee of Tyendinaga and Environs has been studying the potential impacts of leachate contamination
from this landfill for over 15 years. The committee has employed a professional hydrogeologist and a
toxicologist as well as a team of local volunteers for much of this period to ensure a comprehensive
understanding of the known limits of contamination as well as the proposals intended to mitigate and
monitor future contamination. Our understanding is that construction methods being contemplated for this
section of the pipeline (which include mechanical excavation and blasting) could dramatically impact the
direction and rates of groundwater flow which has the potential to complicate the monitoring and mitigation
plans. There is a further concern that construction crews could be at risk of exposure to significant chemical
contamination during the process of installation of the proposed pipeline within the area of groundwater
contamination.

    Je souhaite participer de la façon suivante :
            ~ Auteur d’une lettre de commentaires

            ; Je suis directement touché par le projet proposé.
            ; Je possède des renseignements pertinents ou une expertise appropriée.
               Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
3.      Les effets du projet sur les échanges commerciaux, l’économie, l’approvisionnement et le marché
13. La sécurité et la sûreté associées à la construction et à l’exploitation du projet, y compris la planification
        de l’intervention d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés par des tiers
L'oléoduc traversera la rivière Trois-Saumons, à moins de 10 Km de la résidence que j'habite à
l'embouchurede cette rivière. En cas de bris ou de déversement, le pétrole suivra une série de petites
cascades, une sectionagricole inondable et ensuite de nouvelles cascades jusqu'à la chute située sur la
propriété que j'habite. Lecontact avec le fleuve se fait dans une baie qui borne le terrain de ma résidence.
C'est un milieu très richepour les oiseaux migrateurs et particulièrement l'oie blanche. Une arrivée de
pétrole, même en faible quantité aurait un impact majeur. En cas de bris pendant la saison hivernale, la
résurgence du pétrole se fera fort probablement au pied de la chute où l'eau vive reste visible, malgré la
glace.
J'ai l'intention de faire la preuve que les premiers répondants de Saint-Jean-Port-Joli n'ont aucune
formation,ni équipements pour intervenir. Avec l'aide d'experts, je voudrais évaluer le temps de réponse
disponible en cas de fuite à l'endroit où l'oléoduc traversera la rivière Trois-Saumons pour atteindre le fleuve
et ensuite son comportement en fonction des marées.
Par faible débit, le bassin peu profond derrière le barrage pourrait être un endroit stratégique pour contenir
le pétrole de surface.
Du point de vue économique, je voudrais déposer un mémoire démontrant que l'oléoduc a un impact négatif
quantifiable quant aux emplois manufacturiers en Chaudière-Appalaches.
formation: scolarité de doctorat en Développement régional

hydrocarbures. Je travaille aussi sur l'introduction du marché du carbone et son effet sur le marché du gaz
naturel. Les répercutions du projet Énergie Est et Réseau Principal Est peuvent changer drastiquement la
composition et les forces en présence du marché et c'est pourquoi je désire participer a l'audience ceci est
d'autant plus relié à mon sujet d'expertise pour mon mémoire de maitrise.

 1.     The need for the Project
2.     The economic feasibility of the Project
3.     The commercial, economic, supply and market impacts of the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
8.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of increased marine shipping
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
As an MBA, business professional, and now researcher, lecturer and PhD student at the Queen's School of
Business and visiting scholar at the University of Michigan's Ross School of Business, I would like to offer my
input to this project. In short, I believe this project is unwarranted for two key reasons.
First, the potential social and environmental costs pertaining to both spills and greenhouse gas emissions
involved in the production and use of the fuel, far exceed any small and short-term potential benefit to
Canadian jobs or tax revenue.
Second, I am writing my PhD dissertation on water scarcity and the emerging water crisis and its impacts on
business and society. This crisis has been recognized around the world by leading business groups and
consultancies (WBCSD, CDP, 2030 Water Resources Group and McKinsey, KPMG, Deloitte, to name just a
few). Most recently, the World Economic Forum named the "water crisis" the worlds number one economic
threat in January 2015. Canada is blessed with this natural resource that will be far more valuable than oil in
the not very distant future. Threatening our precious water resources to ship tar sands crude near, through,
and over them makes no social or environmental sense, but also makes no business or economic sense. Clean
and plentiful water is also essential to ensure Canada's long-term energy and food security, and should be
protected from those who seek to compromise it for short-term profits.
I urge you to consider these vital issues and to reject this damaging, unsound, and unjustified project. There
is no way you can assure "safety and security, environmental protection and efficient energy infrastructure
and markets in the Canadian public interest" if you do not.
Sincerely, Wren Montgomery

I am a land owner, which will be affected by the proposed route. Part of the proposed route will go over farm
property I own. Existing forest will be affected. The value of my land will be negatively impacted. There are a
variety of wildlife which inhabits the land over which the route is proposed, including owls. Local indigenous
wildlife will have their habitat destroyed by the proposed route. There is a creek located not far from the
proposed route, which may be impacted by any accidents or spillage. That creek flows into the Wilmont
Creek, which in turn flows into Lake Ontario. I am a tree farmer. I will potentially lose stock as a result of the
proposed route and suffer an economic loss. The proposed route is located close my residence. I will suffer a
loss of use and enjoyment of my residence as a result of the proposed route.

5.     The commercial, economic, supply and market impacts of the Asset Transfer, including the need,
       economic feasibility and commercial impacts of the Eastern Mainline Project. This includes the
       appropriateness of the proposed capacity of the Eastern Mainline of 575 TJ/d.
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative

517 Tenth Avenue SW                                                                  Telephone/Téléphone : (403) 292-4800
Calgary, Alberta T2R 0A8                                                             Facsimile/Télécopieur : (403) 292-5503
                                                                                                http://www..neb-one.gc.ca
517, Dixième Avenue S.-O.                                                                                   1-800-899-1265
Calgary, (Alberta) T2R 0A8                                                                                                2
 15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
16. The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue for
       the Project
My family owns a cottage on Falcon Lake - Whiteshell Manitoba which has been passed down on my partners
side for multiple generations. Our family Nordic skies and canoes in the watershed downstream of the
pipeline in the Whiteshell. I fish in Falcon lake and the near by waterbodies.
My family owns residential property in St. Anne, Manitoba located on the Seine River. Our family owns land
further east which is dependent on the Sandilands aquifer.
I learn to Farm in St Norbert Manitoba at Aurora farm, my future livelihood is dependent on the state of the
water and soil in St Norbert. I frequent the Farmer's market there. An explosion or leak in St Norbert would
harm my food.
I live near the Red and Assiniboine Rivers, I spend considerable time using them recreationally with my
family. A spill into Winnipeg's nearby watershed would affect this ability.
I have experience reviewing and intervening in environmental assessments through my career as a researcher
for the eNGO the Wilderness Committee.
I am trained in political economics and currently am continuing scholarly research in Indigenous Economic
development. I am an expert in the inclusion of externalization of environmental costs and the resource
sector. I worked for Western Economic diversification as operations staff and review projects.
Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year, the
same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads, and greater than the climate footprint of an Atlantic
province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE). This is also 10 million tonnes per year greater than the Keystone XL pipeline,
which the United States Environmental Protection Agency has determined to have a significant impact on
climate change. The National Energy Board needs to take the climate impacts of Energy East into
consideration as there is no other federal review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East will affect nearly every issue on the list of issues:
If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit global warming to 2 degree Celsius there will be
no proven need for Energy East as tar sands expansion will need to be capped (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
The economic feasibility of the project is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble
and the low price of oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and on ways of life.
For these reasons the NEB needs to include climate change in its review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an
abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across Canada.

8.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of increased marine shipping
I am trained environmental scientist and the Forest Conversation Program Director at the Conservation
Council of New Brunswick. I have worked directly with communities that will be directly affected by the
TransCanada Energy East pipeline, including Upper Miramichi.
I have specialized knowledge of the forest watersheds that would be affected by Energy East pipeline route.
Many of New Brunswick's forested watersheds are already compromised because of clearcutting. New
Brunswick's major watersheds having less than 25 per cent intact forest cover. The new forest plan proposed
by the government plans to increase cutting in buffer areas and on steep slopes. The plan has been criticized
by a number of forest ecologists and biologists who have forced the new government to reconsider the plan.
I believe this project poses unacceptable increased risk to rural communities that rely on healthy forest and
watersheds for employment, income and recreation.

 8.     Les effets environnementaux et socio-économiques pouvant découler d’un accroissement des activités
       de transport maritime
En 2014, la Commission régionale du port de Gros-Cacouna (Commission) a été créée volontairement à partir
d’intérêts régionaux et a pour principal objectif le maintien et le développement du port de Gros-Cacouna.
Elle regroupe les utilisateurs, les municipalités, les expéditeurs, les transporteurs, le syndicat des débardeurs,
les organismes de développement économique; et comme observateurs Transports Canada et Québec ainsi
que les deux députés fédéral et provincial. Elle est un organisme à but non lucratif qui dispose de ressources
financières et humaines limitées. L’avancement de ses dossiers repose principalement sur l’implication
bénévole de ses membres.
Ses objets :
  ͲS’assurer que le propriétaire, Transports Canada, effectue la planification et l’exécution du plan
d’entretien et de développement des infrastructures et équipements portuaires de Gros-Cacouna, en
fonction de la vie résiduelle des ouvrages et en fonction des besoins spécifiques des utilisateurs actuels et
futurs.
      - Effectuer une vigie dans des dossiers reliés à des opportunités, des éléments spécifiques ou des
politiques pouvant influencer le développement du port de Gros-Cacouna et, au besoin, mettre en place les
stratégies d’interventions appropriées.
      - Positionner Gros-Cacouna dans le réseau portuaire du St-Laurent auprès des gouvernements,
organismes et comités à vocation maritime.
      - Agir en tant que comité aviseur auprès de Transports Canada.
Le conseil d’administration de la Commission est formé de huit administrateurs dont l’expertise est
diversifiée : développement économique, gestion de projets, logistique du transport, gestion des affaires,
transport maritime et gestion de territoire. Cette complémentarité des compétences est voulue de la part de
la Commission afin d’assurer le mandat qu’elle s’est donnée.
Les intérêts de la Commission à participer à l’audience reposent sur les éléments suivants :
- Elle veut s’exprimer sur la nécessité de cohabitation du projet Énergie Est avec les usages actuels et futurs.
Dans ce sens, la Commission travaille un projet d’implantation d’une rampe Ro-Ro depuis 10 ans. On doit
tenir compte de ce projet ainsi que des usages actuels avant d’autoriser le projet d’énergie Est, afin d’assurer
une viabilité à court, moyen et long terme du port de Gros-Cacouna.
- Elle veut informer l’Office nationale de l’énergie (ONE) de l’état d’avancement de la mise en place d’un
modèle de gestion novateur du port de mer de Gros-Cacouna, exploré en partenariat avec le Port de Québec.
- Elle veut s’assurer de l’accessibilité au port durant la période de construction, au niveau terrestre et
maritime, par les entreprises utilisatrices actuelles.
- Elle veut faire part à l’ONÉ de sa position dans le cas où Énergie Est voudrait acquérir l’infrastructure
portuaire de Gros-Cacouna.
Sous propriété fédérale, Gros-Cacouna constitue un outil de développement important pour les entreprises
locales et régionales, il fait partie intégrante de l’économie de la région. La Commission doit obligatoirement
s’assurer du respect de la vocation du port de mer de Gros-Cacouna dans le cadre de la réalisation du projet
Énergie Est.
Même si la Commission demande d’être l’auteur d’une lettre de commentaires, elle se rend disponible à
répondre aux questions de l’ONE dans le cas où celle-ci le jugerait nécessaire.

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
As a resident of Winnipeg, I am concerned about the proximity of the pipeline to the city. Not if, but when
spills or leaks occur and crosses the Assiniboine River, I have concerns about the safety of the water. If oil
were to enter the water, it will be almost impossible to clean up and tax payers will be liable to pay for the
clean-up. The forty-year old pipeline that is being renovated for this project has a history of explosions and I
am especially concerned about the city of Winnipeg needed to be evacuated when an explosion occurs. The
proposed pipeline project will also have many negative effects on the environment such as facilitating 32
million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year. This is not going to help with Canada's
pledge to lessen the amount of carbon dioxide we produce.

1.     The need for the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
10. The engineering design and integrity of the Project
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
As a resident of Winnipeg I believe I live in the city most at risk from the Energy East pipeline. The pipeline
crosses the Assiniboine River just South of the city Perimeter and passes very close to the Brady Road Landfill.
A spill near the Assiniboine River could cause oil to get into the river which would make its way through the
entire city of Winnipeg. The pipeline system that is being converted for Energy East is 40 years old and was
not designed to carry diluted bitumen but natural gas. Studies in the U.S. have shown that DilBit is much
more corrosive to pipes than conventional oil and pipelines in the U.S. carrying DilBit have had 16 times as
many spills as other pipelines. Yet TransCanada has not mentioned any specific measures in the area of
pipeline technology or spill prevention that address the risks to pipelines posed specifically by DilBit. Also the
liability for any spills or explosions could lie with taxpayers like myself in Winnipeg as TransCanada has
created a subsidiary company for the Energy East projects and has not disclosed its spill liability insurance.

 The Trout Lake Conservation Association (TLCA) is filing this application on behalf of its membership which
includes mainly Trout Lake shoreline property owners and property owners within the Trout Lake watershed.
Trout Lake is located within the municipalities of North Bay and East Ferris, Ontario. The Energy East Route
travels a total of 18.2 km through the Trout Lake watershed including a crossing of the lakes' outlet. Our
objectives can be viewed at the following site:
http://www.cityofnorthbay.ca/cityhall/department/environmental/tcla
The segment of the Energy East route that travels through the Trout Lake watershed has been identified by
the Energy East planning team as an ”Area of Interest” due to its sensitivities. The proponent has prepared
Trout Lake Site-Specific Risk Assessment, Stantec, 2013 to support its application.
The TLCA believes it has pertinent information to offer and we seek standing at the NEB’s Energy East Hearing
as a commenting body for the following reasons:
1) The TLCA has valuable knowledge and expertise:
• TLCA has considerable local knowledge of the segment of the route that passes through the Trout Lake
watershed; designated an “Area of Interest” by Energy East;
• The TLCA Board of Directors includes Engineers and Environmental Professionals (we are prepared to
submit a list of Board Member qualifications if required);
• Board members have diverse knowledge and experience in many environmental disciplines that have direct
application to this proposal;
• TLCA has specifically been investigating potential spill pathways and has pertinent information to offer
concerning the assessment of local risks;
• TLCA has access to and knowledge of a significant body of scientific and environmental data and literature
for Trout Lake and its contributing basins that has been collected over the past 40+ years;
• Our comments will be focused on local issues including the Trout Lake Site-Specific Risk Assessment.
2) The TLCA has already been engaged in the process to-date:
• TLCA Board of Directors and individual Board Members have had ongoing dialogue with TransCanada
Pipeline - Energy East personnel concerning the project since it was announced;
• TLCA Board Members have attended TCPL Energy East Information Sessions held in the local area;
• TLCA has presented information and sought input from its members at Annual Meetings concerning Energy
East;
• TLCA contributes to and supports the work being carried out by the City of North Bay and the North Bay-
Mattawa Conservation Authority regarding the Energy East application;
• TLCA has received representations from TCPL personnel regarding what they are prepared to do locally and
the TLCA wants assurances that these representations will be included as conditions of approval.
Humbly submitted on behalf of the Board of the Trout Lake Conservation Association

 J'ai travaillé comme analyste de politiques publiques pour de nombreuses organisations non-
gouvernementales en environnement depuis plus de 12 ans. Je suis le responsable de la campagne Climat-
Énergie de Greenpeace Canada depuis près de 3 ans et suis basé à Montréal. J'ai une maitrise en sciences de
l'environnement et un baccalauréat en Administration des affaires concentration sécurité et gestion de crises.
Énergie Est pourrait générer 32 millions de tonnes de GES par année, soit l’équivalent
d’ajouter 7 millions de voitures sur les routes du Canada, une empreinte carbone plus
grande que celle des Maritimes (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE).
L’impact d’Énergie Est serait même plus important que celui du pipeline Keystone XL,
un autre projet de TransCanada que l’Agence de la Protection environnementale des
États-Unis a déterminé comme ayant un impact significatif sur la situation climatique.
L’Office national de l’énergie doit prendre en compte les impacts climatiques en amont,
car il n’existe aucun autre processus fédéral d’évaluation des impacts climatiques des
projets liés à l’énergie au Canada.
Les impacts d’Énergie Est sur le climat touchent à peu près toutes les problématiques
présentes dans la liste :Si le Canada se joint à la communauté internationale pour lutter contre les
changements climatiques et limiter le réchauffement global à 2 degrés Celsius, le
besoin pour une infrastructure comme Énergie Est disparait en raison de la nécessité
de plafonner l’expansion des sables bitumineux (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4 &
http://bit.ly/SccvIZ). La faisabilité économique est aussi liée aux changements
climatiques, de par la relation à la bulle du carbone et d’un bas prix du pétrole
(http://bit.ly/14wgVB4).
Considérer les effets environnementaux et socio-économiques potentiels du projet sans
prendre en compte les effets des changements climatiques comme impacts cumulatifs
est insensé dans la situation que nous vivons à l’heure actuelle à travers le monde.
Étant donné les conséquences des changements climatiques sur l’agriculture,
l’utilisation des terres et les modes de vie qui y sont liés, le projet aura des effets sur «
les intérêts des Autochtones » et sur « les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement
touchés ».
Pour toutes ces raisons, et parce que cette liste est loin d’être exhaustive, l’ONÉ doit
inclure les impacts d’Énergie Est sur le climat dans son évaluation. Échouer à le faire
équivaudrait pour les régulateurs à nier la responsabilité qu’ils ont envers les
Canadiens.

I believe that trying to stem the devastating outcome of Climate Change is the single most important item on
the Global Agenda. Allowing Energy East to proceed is completely incompatible with stepping up to the
challenge of our Climate Crisis. It would be like tackling the issue of Obesity by giving discounts on prepared
foods that contain only empty calories; or by giving a tax incentive to those who drop out of their exercise
programs! To not consider Climate Change when determining the feasibility of moving fossil fuels, (the
ultimate burning of which has brought us to this crisis in the first place) from one end of the country to the
other, is beyond belief.
Although the pipeline does not go through my Regina backyard, it is located close enough to cause me to
wonder what will happen in the case of a rupture and/or explosion. I have not been able to get answers to
my questions on the state of the pipeline itself---are all sections the original ones? what is the expected
lifespan or "best before" date? More importantly, my direct question on the composition of the diluents
(used to allow the bitumen to flow) has been repeatedly ignored. Is Regina likely to be another Bhopal,
where emergency care providers don't know what treatment or antidote to provide because they don't know
what they are dealing with? What kind of information is being provided to our hospitals and fire
departments? What if one or both of our hospitals has to evacuate all their patients? Where will they send
them? From personal experience I know what a daunting task this can be. My experience was in a large
metropolitan area where there were a number of 'receiving' hospitals within a few kilometers. That would
not be the case in Regina.

The Richmond Village Association Inc.’s membership is comprised of the population of Richmond as well as
every property owner or business owner in the Village. The population as a whole relies on groundwater and
two aquifers to supply the largely private wells of the approximately 4700 members of the Association. A
small portion of the residents rely on municipal wells drawing from the same water source. In addition,
subdivision development plans are in the final stages of approval for approximately 2000 additional homes to
be serviced by wells.
The Pipeline passes within 382 meters of the village boundary through sensitive wetlands, the Jock River and
the aquifers feeding all the residents wells. In this respect our member’s (and future members) source of
clean potable water is directly threatened in the context of Issues 7,9,10,12,13,14 and 15. This in turn will
have a deleterious impact on property values and village growth.
We have studied the proponent’s application and find it incomplete and inadequate in a number of areas. In
addition there appears to be a rush to go forward when all the information is not yet available. We have
exercised due-diligence and are well informed on the pros and cons of this proposal. We have attended the
proponents’ information sessions as well as a number of other forums and consulted our membership. We
have been unable to get satisfactory answers to how a major spill would be handled or worse, an insidious
slow leak poisoning our wells forever. From a Global perspective we as citizens and property owners also
wish to comment on the need for the project (item 1) and propose conditions for the NEB’s consideration
(item 16) in the event of any recommendation for approval by the NEB.
As a group we can provide relevant local comments on the potential impact of the proposed pipeline on
Richmond, our water resources, wells at risk, the high risk topography of the area and a collective point of
view on the appropriateness of this project. Having said that, we do not hold ourselves out to be experts on
pipelines in any way … we are an association of citizens with a deep concern for our homes and our country.
In view of the above, we look forward to being approved as a participant in the upcoming proceeding with
respect to the Energy East Pipeline Ltd. application.
Respectfully submitted for your consideration, the Richmond Village Association Inc.

 1.     La nécessité du projet
7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
8.     Les effets environnementaux et socio-économiques pouvant découler d’un accroissement des activités
       de transport maritime
9.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet
11. Les effets éventuels du projet sur les intérêts des Autochtones
14. La planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement, d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les
       travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
Le but de la coalition est de revendiquer et promouvoir une gestion responsable de l’eau dans une
perspective de santé publique, d’équité, d’accessibilité, de défense collective des droits de la population,
d’amélioration des compétences citoyennes des citoyens, de développement durable et de souveraineté
collective sur cette ressource vitale et stratégique
Ses objectifs sont de :
A) contribuer à une politique globale et intégrée de l’eau dans une perspective de santé des populations et
des écosystèmes, par un travail de recherche, d’éducation, d’information, de sensibilisation et de défense
des droits de la population ainsi que par une réflexion critique, argumentée et attentive aux différentes
problématiques de l’eau, notamment celles vécues par les citoyens, dans un contexte social national et
international ;
B) s’assurer que cette politique soit soumise à l’ensemble des citoyens, pour être suivi d’un projet de loi avec
réglementation et des outils de contrôle et d’évaluation conséquents ;
C) s’assurer que les enjeux, tant locaux, nationaux qu’internationaux soient exposés de façon transparente et
limpide dans le cadre d’un véritable débat public ;
D) assurer le suivi des dossiers, des politiques, des projets de réglementation qui touchent l’eau.

 I retired as a Professional Engineer and as General Manager of an Irving owned Construction Company which
installed in the Bay of Fundy the Mono-Buoy, used to transfer Crude Oil from tankers to the Irving Refinery. I
was also an Intervenor at the Emera Brunswick Pipeline (EBPC) Hearing, where I proposed a route for the
pipeline under the Outer Harbour instead of going through the city. Both these tasks required studies of the
Bay's incoming- and outgoing tides and the mixing of the Saint John River's fresh water with the salt water of
the Bay. The behaviour of spilled Dilbit in brackish water has not been considered in EnergyEast's Application
(the Application).
Because the 'Alert' Section of the Application does not consider a worst-condition spill in brackish water in
the Bay with in- and outgoing tides of 2m/sec and >100 km/h wind, I intend, if accepted as Intervenor, to
request that this scenario will be considered, and also the danger of the close proximities of the Mono-Buoy,
the proposed Marine Terminal and the LNG Terminal (which might be converted into an LNG Export
Terminal) and the increase of ships traffic within this triangle.
I was a member of the now defunct Saint John EBPC Liaison Committee, the Saint John Common Council
appointed me to the Saint John Emergency Management Organization Advisory Committee (disbanded after
2 years), I reported local public safety concerns in many letters to the NEB and became the spokesperson of a
concerned citizens group in two ADR attempts with the EBPC to improve the prevention of, the preparation
for and the response to pipeline emergencies. I had a meeting on these subjects with Temporary Board
Member Jamie Ballem, and recently presented my concerns to Chairman Peter Watso, Vice-chair Lyne
Mercier and staff when they visited my home. As an Intervenor the above experiences would contribute to
safety conditions for the New Brunswick Section of the EnergyEast Pipeline and its Marine Terminal.
The Application raises additional questions, but I am limited by the 500 word count:
Why are the Pump Stations not manned? A Condition of the Northern Gateway Project required Enbridge to
have them manned 24/7.
What is the back-up for the control of the pumps and valves, if the communication between SCADA in
Houston, Texas, the TransCanada Operations Control Centre in Calgary and Pump stations and/or Valves have
been 'hacked' or have been interrupted by atmospheric interference?
The Application states that for emergencies along the NB section of the pipeline no local FRs will be used. A
protocol how incidents will be handled is required but missing.
The Risk Assessment does not consider the worldwide increase in Terrorism, and how EnergyEast intends to
counter this increased thread to the pipeline, which by its length and its purpose might attract the attention
of saboteurs.
An increase in the patrolling of the pipeline from overflights to 'boots on the ground' or more sophisticated
means seems to be called for.
p.s. This is not a complete list.

12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
My wife and I own property In Ontario through which the contents of 3 pipelines flow.
Our lands were considered for another pipeline by Trans Canada but as far as our lands are concerned the
project has been put on hold. We have some 45 years of experience in dealing with pipeline companies
This past summer we had remediation work done on their pipeline by Enbridge. We also had work done on
the land above the two TransCanada gas pipelines. We understand that TransCanada will be returning this
spring to begin cathodic work which was not completed in 2014.
I have a number of issues which relate to the construction and operation of the pipeline as well as ones
relating to the products which are proposed to be carried therein. However, this application does not relate
to those issues. It relates to the interests of the landowner.
Since WW II there has been an increase in the number and capacity of pipelines which have been built.
Today's projects dwarf the earlier ones. And the mega projects themselves dwarf the landowner.
The landowner often encounters a blank wall or incomplete answers when trying to ascertain information
from a pipeline company, even in regard to the pipeline running below the landowner's property. In reading
about this process I note that governments themselves and their agencies encounter a similar problem. Just
think of the scale of such difficulty for the individual landowner.
Our lands form a forest managed under the Ontario MFTIP program. I am unable to ascertain whether this
would be reason enough to prevent any unwanted pipeline from being build on our property. The tax
implications for such a landowner are also unclear. There are also issues of assessment and taxation of lands
containing pipelines.
From my readings I conclude that we would be responsible for a pipeline spill coming from our property.
Help has been given to Nuclear energy companies to limit their liability in the event of an accident. There
should be no less consideration for the landowner in the case of a pipeline spill.
There are other similar problems I would like to raise. I would also like to offer solutions such as an
Ombudsman to assist the landowner in dealings with the pipeline companies
I am happy either to present written material or to be present at a hearing as well.
With all parties present this is an excellent time to direct avenues for solutions for the unintended
consequences which befall the landowner as a result of pipeline construction
Thanks
Bob

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
As a citizen of North Bay, I would have to live with the possibility of a spill affecting Trout Lake, my drinking
water source and canoe route, swimming place and recreational area. The value of my house and my
lifestyle, which I treasure, would be negatively affected in this instance. Further, the possibility of a spill into
Lake Temagami, my childhood home and frequent canoe route today would adversely affect both me and
members of my family, who also participate in such activities. The prospect of these events would add
anxiety to my life for as long as I live in Northern Ontario.
As a writer, I have expertise in describing the spirituality of the land and the peoples who inhabit it. This
sense of the land's integrity and inherent value is violated when a pipeline company converts an aging gas
line to dilbit and/or crude. The potential for ruptures is high. The potential for adequate emergency response
in a part of our country that is often covered by ice and snow (and often with little foot traffic to detect leaks
in the first place) is low. Discussion of the inherent value of the land for other than commercial purposes is
seldom present in NEB hearings, certainly not in a way that is balanced or proportionate. However, the word
"socio-economic" would indicate that social considerations (of which this discussion is one) do properly fall
under the purview of the Board.
I am the author of 14 books. I have written about spirituality as it relates to the land, and the current
evolution in Christian theology that brings it closer to the spiritual beliefs of the people indigenous to this
continent. I have an honourary doctorate from Queen's University (Kingston, ON) and I am a fellow of
Huntington University (Sudbury,ON), and receive frequent invitations to speak or write about these issues.

I have considerable experience in environmental planning, environmental assessment of public utilities, and
private land conservation acquired over 34 years as a professional in government and the nonprofit sectors.
This project is not about the public interest; rather it is about private profit and public risk and expense.
The World Wildlife Fund recently reported that in the forty years between 1970 and 2010, over half of the
global population of birds, mammals, amphibians, reptiles, and fish has disappeared. This is the best available
science and it indicates the loss as being due to the cumulative effects of habitat loss, hunting, exploitation
and, to a small extent, climate change.
It is against this global backdrop that the NEB wants to permit a 4,500 km long oil pipeline that will destroy
even more wildlife habitat including old forest and increasingly scarce interior forest habitat.
Then there is climate change, which will afflict future generations and is arising as an issue in relation to the
pipeline as a result of a policy vacuum at the federal level. This pipeline has become a lightning rod for
climate concerns because the government has abrogated its responsibility to the people of Canada in this
regard.
I note the pipeline route passes through many areas of private conservation land. Added to this, many
wetlands, now unprotected under any legislation, will be adversely affected by pipeline construction. Why
are wetlands important? Fully 75 percent of all wildlife spend some or all of their lifecycle in wetlands.
Destroy wetlands and wildlife is destroyed.
I spent four years while in government developing a wetlands protection policy. For this reason, I feel
qualified to write to the board on this topic. As well, I was Executive Director of the Nature Trust of New
Brunswick for 14 years, during which I assessed natural areas on an ongoing basis for potential conservation.

3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
I am a land owner that owns a 1 acre lot directly next to the original pipeline. We have lived here for over 20
years. They are asking to either purchase our property or buy an easement off of us. They are asking to have
an easement on about 1/3 of our 1 acre lot. This will limit any futures plans we have had for this area of our
property. The proposed easement starts from the center of our road frontage, passes within 2 meters of our
existing dwelling and then continues to the back corner of our rectangular lot. We have asked Trans Canada
multiple times how it will affect our aquifer or septic system and have not received any answer. They just
submitted an appraisal of our property to us on February 2. We have been misinformed right from last June
when they told us there would be no impact on us or our property and then last summer them "stating"
Trans Canada "will" be buying our property and then now they have a few options for us. We are in no
position to make any type of informed decision since we do not have answers to some important questions.

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be

6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the

The Cataraqui Region Conservation Authority (CRCA) is a non-profit organization that works with local
communities to conserve renewable natural resources in southeastern Ontario. The CRCA jurisdiction is
crossed by existing and proposed sections of the TransCanada Eastern Mainline natural gas pipeline.
The CRCA is directly affected by the proposed project as a landowner. New pipeline sections are proposed
for our properties at Eden Grove and Marble Rock near Gananoque, and at the Millhaven Reservoir near
Odessa, and the existing pipeline crosses our Mac Johnson Wildlife Area near Brockville. We have an interest
in the specific location of the pipeline route across CRCA lands, as well as the proposed construction and
environmental rehabilitation methods.
The Conservation Authority has expertise as a watershed manager and regulator, and wishes to share
relevant information with the National Energy Board (NEB) and TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. CRCA staff have
professional expertise in biology, ecology, engineering, planning and related disciplines. We have relevant
information about the erosion and flooding potential along the watercourses crossed by the existing /
proposed pipeline sections in the Cataraqui Region. The CRCA also has regional information about natural
heritage systems (i.e. wetlands, woodlands, other) and water resources (e.g. drinking water sources,
hydrogeology) in the vicinity of the proposed project. We have engaged in dialogue with TransCanada about
these topics since May 2014.
The CRCA administers Ontario Regulation 148/06 (Development, Interference with Wetlands, and Alteration
to Shorelines and Watercourses) under the Conservation Authorities Act and thereby regulates field
investigation work and pipeline construction activities near waterbodies and wetlands.
With respect to the List of Issues for the proposed project: we have an interest in the potential
environmental effects, pipeline routing, potential impacts on landowners, spill and emergency response
planning and NEB terms and conditions.

(Regarding Items #7, 12, 13)
My home is approximately five kilometers from the existing Energy East pipeline where it crosses the
Mattawa River between Trout Lake and Turtle Lake, commonly known as "the Narrows". My young family
and I make frequent use of the natural environment, including the hiking trails at the Narrows and the
waterways that the pipeline crosses. My two young boys are learning about Blandings turtles, snakes, and
salamanders while hiking, canoeing, and swimming in and around the Mattawa River. As such, I am deeply
concerned about the safety of the pipeline and the contents it might soon carry. The National Energy Board
has not received sufficient information about the nature or composition of "dilbit", and I suggest that the
NEB request and publish this critical information, and ensure that all communities along the pipeline receive
such information so that they might determine if their First Responders could contain and deal with a "dilbit"
spill or accident.
(Regarding Item #15)
Local, provincial and federal governments often seem to be "on the hook" for remediation of the natural
environment after a company abandons a property or asset, often to the tune of millions of dollars over
many years. Will TransCanada's liability in this newest venture be enacted and enforced to cover any and all
environmental degradation that is imparted on Canadian forests and waterways over the course of
construction, operation, and decommissioning?
(Regarding Item #3)
Canada must not be complacent in its approach to climate change. We must not continue to develop fossil
fuels that will have a negative impact on our climate and water resources for generations to come. The
economic and social impacts of this project will directly affect me as a Canadian living in a changing world,
and will most definitely negatively impact my children if this current carbon-based economy is allowed to
accelerate.
I will most assuredly be directly affected by this project as detailed above, and hereby request Commenter
Status.

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.

9.     The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue.
May 28 openhouse, my wife and I raised 2 specific concerns with respect to the project that we feel are not
adequately reflected in Appendix 7-7 Stakeholder Log of the NEB application, those being the proximity of
the proposed pipeline route to property at 4111 Mearns Ave., Bowmanville and the proposed construction
access routing to the project. More specifically on the route, we raised concerns with the route shown in the
NEB application as being extremely close to our home at 4111 Mearns Ave. and to the total degradation of
the environmentally sensitive creek valley and forest directly abutting the north side of our property. The
creek valley contains a branch of the Soper Creek which supports both trout, salmon spawning, together with
the valley that provides habitat/passage for many wildlife species along with an abundance of forest
vegetation which further provides cooling of creek waters, stability to creek banks and aesthetically visual
backdrop and economic value to our property. While a public notice of a route update was brought forward
in Dec/14 showing the pipeline well north of the area described above, we're unclear as to how this route is
being brought to the NEB's attention or approval in the absence of it not being included in NEB application.
Firstly, we are extremely pleased that TCP has relocated the proposed route away from our property and
wish to see that conditions are made in any approval to formalize that route. However, that being said,
secondly we are now extremely concerned with updated proposed route east of Bethesda Rd. which now
cuts through the heart of Stephen's Gulch Conservation Area. We are unclear as to why the pipeline does not
rejoin the existing pipeline east of Bethesda, thus avoiding the destruction of an equally environmentally
sensitive area and recreational trail system. As avid users and taxpayers which partially fund CLOCA facilities,
we have a vested interest in seeing that this jewel is not unnecessarily destroyed with a mammoth swath cut.
On the matter of construction processes and access, this project is massive in terms of the footprint that it
occupies, more so during construction. The project through Clarington traverses 26 Local Clarington
municipal roads (Mearns Ave is 1 of them) and 5 Regional roads. As the impact to any or all of these roads
from construction activity could be very minor, it could also have significant impacts such as lifecycle
shortening, which are not immediately recognizable. As taxpayers, we again have a vested interest in our
municipally funded roads. Mearns Ave is a high float surface treated road which will not tolerate heavy
construction traffic without either destroying the surface as present or significantly shortening the lifecycle
span of the road. We want construction access banned from Mearns Ave and a concise traffic, noise and dust
abatement plan approved by the Board. I am a Certified Engineering Technician (CET) in Ontario and former
Director of Public Works for Trent Lakes with over 30 years of civil, environmental and construction
experience.

 Ce pipeline représente un risque réel et important pour l'intégrité de la qualité de l'environnement dans
lequel je vis et où mes descendants évoluent et évolueront. De plus, je crains un déversement majeur, et le
désengagement de la compagnie responsable, malgré les très certainement contraignantes règles auxquelles
elle se soumet. L'Histoire est remplie de ces lourds héritages aux populations locales laissés par des
compagnies cautionnées par des États bien-pensants. Ici, le risque est trop grand.
Entre autres considérations, Énergie Est pourrait générer 32 millions de tonnes de GES par année, soit
l’équivalent
d’ajouter 7 millions de voitures sur les routes du Canada, une empreinte carbone plus
grande que celle des Maritimes (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE).
L’impact d’Énergie Est serait même plus important que celui du pipeline Keystone XL,
un autre projet de TransCanada que l’Agence de la Protection environnementale des
ÉtatsUnis a déterminé comme ayant un impact significatif sur la situation climatique.
L’Office national de l’énergie doit prendre en compte les impacts climatiques en amont,
car il n’existe aucun autre processus fédéral d’évaluation des impacts climatiques des
projets liés à l’énergie au Canada.
Les impacts d’Énergie Est sur le climat touchent à peu près toutes les problématiques
présentes dans la liste :
Si le Canada se joint à la communauté internationale pour lutter contre les
changements climatiques et limiter le réchauffement global à 2 degrés Celsius, le
besoin pour une infrastructure comme Énergie Est disparait en raison de la nécessité
de plafonner l’expansion des sables bitumineux ( http://bit.ly/14wgVB4 &
http://bit.ly/SccvIZ ). La faisabilité économique est aussi liée aux changements
climatiques, de par la relation à la bulle du carbone et d’un bas prix du pétrole
(http://bit.ly/14wgVB4).
Considérer les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques
potentiels du projet sans
prendre en compte les effets des changements climatiques comme impacts cumulatifs
est insensé dans la situation que nous vivons à l’heure actuelle à travers le monde.
Étant donné les conséquences des changements climatiques sur l’agriculture,
l’utilisation des terres et les modes de vie qui y sont liés, le projet aura des effets sur «
les intérêts des Autochtones » et sur « les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement
touchés ».
Pour toutes ces raisons, et parce que cette liste est loin d’être exhaustive, l’ONÉ doit
inclure les impacts d’Énergie Est sur le climat dans son évaluation. Échouer à le faire
équivaudrait pour les régulateurs à nier la responsabilité qu’ils ont envers les
Canadiens.

EPAC represents more than 200 companies, head-quartered in Canada, who are primarily junior and
intermediate oil and gas producers. Our members invest about $10 billion dollars each year in BC, Alberta,
Saskatchewan and Manitoba drilling new wells and building related infrastructure. This investment supports
tens of thousands of well paid jobs in Canada. Pipelines will remain the preferred and dominant option for
transporting oil and gas production to downstream markets from Western Canada.
Energy East promises access to new markets and new customers which in turn supports improved commodity
pricing and market optionality for all upstream oil and gas producers, including EPAC member companies.
Energy East is an "all Canadian" solution which enables Canada's upstream oil and gas producers to reach
both new domestic refiners in Quebec and New Brunswick but also to reach new international markets via
the proposed marine terminal in St. John, NB.
The need for the Energy East project thus directly affects EPAC members as a whole. In addition, and without
wishing to limit comments we may submit to the NEB, EPAC has particularly identified issues 1 to 7 and 16 as
ones that we think we can offer insight and information that will be relevant and useful for the NEB in
considering this application.
Gary Leach, President
The Explorers and Producers Association of Canada

There are several issues of importance in the Board process that I am concerned about. First, I am concerned
that the contribution to climate change posed by this proposal will not otherwise be considered in sufficient
depth. Second, the proposed pipeline is being touted as a way of supplying western oil to eastern Canada.
This is false since eastern Canada lacks the refining capacity to refine tar sands oil. Instead, the bitumen that
would be carried in the pipeline would be destined for export, thus denying Canada the jobs that come from
further processing and contributing to greater use of fossil fuels. Third, the track record of TransCanada is
extremely poor in respect of preventing and cleaning up spills from its pipelines. This issue and its attendant
costs are a major concern since it is known that the public would bear the bulk of the costs of a cleanup when
a spill occurs. Fourth, the integrity of the proposed pipeline is a serious concern since much of it has been a
natural gas pipeline and that its flow will be reversed to accommodate bitumen. Fifth, increased oil tanker
traffic on the St. Lawrence River carries greater risks of spills and mishaps with consequent damage to the
environment and flora and fauna. Sixth, in many instances, the pipeline will cross First Nations territory. As a
retired legal academic, I am very concerned about breaches of Canada's constitutional, legal, and moral
responsibility towards First Nations that may well occur if this proposal is allowed to proceed.

 1.     La nécessité du projet
2.     La faisabilité économique du projet
7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
11. Les effets éventuels du projet sur les intérêts des Autochtones
12. L’incidence possible du projet sur les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement touchés et sur leur
       utilisation des terres
13. La sécurité et la sûreté associées à la construction et à l’exploitation du projet, y compris la planification
       de l’intervention d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés par des tiers
En plus d'être touché par le passage du pipeline qui passe a proximité de mes propriétés et de risqué d'être
contaminé par un éventuel déversement; Énergie Est pourrait générer 32 millions de tonnes de GES par
année, soit l’équivalent
d’ajouter 7 millions de voitures sur les routes du Canada, une empreinte carbone plus
grande que celle des Maritimes (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE).
L’impact d’Énergie Est serait même plus important que celui du pipeline Keystone XL,
un autre projet de TransCanada que l’Agence de la Protection environnementale des
États-Unis a déterminé comme ayant un impact significatif sur la situation climatique.
L’Office national de l’énergie doit prendre en compte les impacts climatiques en amont,
car il n’existe aucun autre processus fédéral d’évaluation des impacts climatiques des
projets liés à l’énergie au Canada.
Les impacts d’Énergie Est sur le climat touchent à peu près toutes les problématiques
présentes dans la liste :Si le Canada se joint à la communauté internationale pour lutter contre les
changements climatiques et limiter le réchauffement global à 2 degrés Celsius, le
besoin pour une infrastructure comme Énergie Est disparait en raison de la nécessité
de plafonner l’expansion des sables bitumineux (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4 &
http://bit.ly/SccvIZ). La faisabilité économique est aussi liée aux changements
climatiques, de par la relation à la bulle du carbone et d’un bas prix du pétrole
(http://bit.ly/14wgVB4).
Considérer les effets environnementaux et socio-économiques potentiels du projet sans
prendre en compte les effets des changements climatiques comme impacts cumulatifs
est insensé dans la situation que nous vivons à l’heure actuelle à travers le monde.
Étant donné les conséquences des changements climatiques sur l’agriculture,
l’utilisation des terres et les modes de vie qui y sont liés, le projet aura des effets sur «
les intérêts des Autochtones » et sur « les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement
touchés ».
Pour toutes ces raisons, et parce que cette liste est loin d’être exhaustive, l’ONÉ doit
inclure les impacts d’Énergie Est sur le climat dans son évaluation. Échouer à le faire
équivaudrait pour les régulateurs à nier la responsabilité qu’ils ont envers les
Canadiens.

Le Collectif en environnement Mercier-Est regroupe des citoyens qui résident dans le quartier Mercier-Est à
Montréal, à quelques dizaines de mètres du terminal du projet Énergie-Est, dans l'est de Montréal.
En cas de défaillance, d'accident ou de déversement, nous serions directement touchés. Nous vivons
également à proximité du terminal maritime qui recevra le pétrole destiné à l'exportation. Ce projet s'insère
dans une zone industrielle à haut risque où sont stockés et transportés de nombreux produits dangereux.
Par conséquent, ce projet représente des risques pour notre santé et notre sécurité.
Nous nous interrogeons également sur les effets de ce projet sur les émissions de gaz à effet de serres et les
changements climatiques ainsi que sur la qualité de l'air, advenant que du dilbit dilué soit raffiné à la
raffinerie Suncor dans l'est de Montréal.

2.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet proposé.
3.     Les répercussions possibles du projet proposé sur les propriétaires fonciers et leur utilisation des terres.
Ma propriété est un lot boisé (no 3 831 205 ) situé à Neuville. (PORT-0199 pour TCP).
Initialement, M. Michel Hudon a présenté un plan mentionnant une largeur de 23 mètres adossée à la limite
de l'oléoduc déjà existant et empiétant sur ma propriété du côté nord. Le 9 février 2015, Mme Manon
Mérineau me présenta un 2e plan où le tracé est large de 25 mètres plus 15 mètres supplémentaires pour les
débris et comportant un déplacement vers le sud, à l'entrée ouest de mon lot, créant un espace libre entre
l'oléoduc et ma propriété.
/
Le déplacement du tracé et son élargissement de 15 mètres supplémentaires ont plusieurs effets négatifs
notamment la destruction:
1. d'une partie beaucoup plus importante de ma plantation de 15 ans;
2. d'une partie plus grande de forêt qui alimente mon commerce de bois de chauffage et qui entraînera la
perte des revenus en découlant;
3. des abris à bois servant au commerce de bois de chauffage et dont la relocalisation détruira une nouvelle
zone de forêt;
4. du chemin d'accès dont le remplacement amènera à détruire une nouvelle zone de forêt dont notamment
une plantation;
5. d'une partie beaucoup plus significative de mon érablière entraînant une diminution importante de la
production et du potentiel de régénération.
Ce nouveau tracé créera un espace inutilisable de terrain entre la limite ouest du tracé et celle de mon lot. Il
obligera à déplacer l'entrepôt et à détruire une zone de forêt supplémentaire. Les arbres détruits ne pourront
être remis en état. J'améliore mon lot depuis 25 ans au point de recevoir une offre de 125 000$ il y a quatre
ans. Le projet réduit significativement le potentiel de vente de ma propriété.
/
Je m'oppose au nouveau tracé car il lèse de façon abusive mon droit à la jouissance de ma propriété. Le
projet peut se réaliser sans être aussi dérangeant pour moi.
Compte tenu de ce qui précède, je demande le retour au tracé initial en l'adossant à celui du gazoduc existant
sur toute la limite nord de mon lot au lieu de le déplacer
vers le sud à l'extrémité ouest et en limitant la servitude au strict minimum, c'est-à-dire à 11-12 mètres à
partir du gazoduc existant.

take this into heavy consideration.
The Energy East pipeline is a unnecessary risk to my family and to the Canadian Public, therefore I should be
allowed to participate in the National Energy Board hearing.

 1.     The need for the Project

       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
9.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the Project
10. The engineering design and integrity of the Project
11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
The Thunder Bay Chapter of the Council of Canadians would like to submit a Letter of Concern to the National
Energy Board with regard to the Energy East proposal by TransCanada Limited.
We have supporters not only in the City of Thunder Bay, but throughout the region around the city where the
proposed project will be located. However, we feel that all of the citizens of this region will be directly
affected if this proposal is allowed to be developed. Given TransCanada Pipelines’ abysmal safety record, and
in particular its safety record in NorthWestern Ontario, there is a high likelihood of a spill of whatever oil the
pipeline is carrying. The two major watersheds the pipeline crosses in this area are the source for drinking
water for thousands of people, as well as the home for many species of plants and animals, some of which
are endangered. A spill, particularly of diluted bitumen would be a disaster for this area, and would threaten
the livelihoods of many and the drinking water for many more.
In addition, we believe that the greenhouse gas emissions engendered by the extraction and shipping of the
Tar Sands oil, which this pipeline would expedite, are a clear and present danger to all life on the planet. We
as a species can no longer afford to contribute to climate change. Residents across Canada have already felt
the negative effects of extreme weather events brought on by climate destabilization. These are reliably
predicted to become worse unless we reduce our carbon usage. We are all of us directly affected by the
climate change contribution of this pipeline proposal.
In brief, we believe we would be directly affected by the development of the Energy East pipeline through
threats to our drinking water, economic effects through damage to tourism, fishing, hunting and farming, and
thus the development of a sustainable local economy. We all will be directly and imminently affected by
increased climate change which will be exacerbated by the greenhouse gas emissions occasioned by the
development of this project.
