 Considérant
• les informations transmises par l’Office national de l’énergie à propos du projet Oléoduc Énergie Est de
TransCanada Pipelines;
• que le tracé de cet oléoduc traverse la rivière Saint-Maurice en amont de la prise d’eau de surface de la
Ville de Trois-Rivières;
• la faible distance séparant le tracé de cet oléoduc des zones de recharge des nappes phréatiques utilisées
pour le prélèvement d’eau potable par la Ville de Trois-Rivières;
• la vulnérabilité élevée de ces zones de recharge des nappes phréatiques;
• les impacts économiques occasionnés par la présence de cet oléoduc sur les activités de la Ville de Trois-
Rivières en matière de surveillance de la qualité des eaux de surface et souterraine et en matière de sécurité
publique;
• les impacts économiques occasionnés par la présence de cet oléoduc sur le développement de la Ville de
Trois-Rivières;
• les impacts économiques, sociaux et environnementaux importants qu’un déversement majeur
occasionnerait pour la Ville de Trois-Rivières;
La Ville demande que TransCanada Pipelines :
• construise la station de pompage sur le territoire de la Ville loin des zones de prélèvement d’eau potable;
• prévoie les réservoirs et les bassins de récupération d’hydrocarbures positionnés au long de l’oléoduc et à
la station de pompage ayant des volumes suffisants pour éviter la contamination du sol;
• prévoie l’installation de clapets antiretour et qu’ils soient installés dans les sections descendantes de
l'oléoduc près des sources d’approvisionnement en eau potable et des milieux humides pour éviter un
drainage entre 2 vannes de sectionnement en cas de rupture;
• prévoie un système de détection des fuites sous le seuil de 1,5 % dans les traversées de cours d’eau et à
proximité des milieux humides;
• finance une évaluation indépendante des impacts de déversements sur la prise d'eau potable et la St-
Maurice afin que des mesures de mitigation des risques soient identifiées tels qu'un franchissement aérien
avec des mesures spécifiques de protection du pipeline et de détection des fuites ou un repositionnement de
la traversée de la St-Maurice en amont du barrage de la Gabelle;
• finance une évaluation indépendante des impacts de déversements sur les zones de recharge des puits et
les secteurs à protéger pour la recherche d'eau potable pour une zone tampon de 8 km avant l’implantation
du pipeline afin de modifier le tracé ou d’appliquer des mesures d’atténuation des risques;
• modifie son tracé afin de contourner les milieux humides;
• protège et aménage sur le territoire de la Ville de Trois-Rivières une superficie de milieux naturels de haute
valeur écologique équivalente à l’emprise déboisée du pipeline sur le territoire de la Ville;
• rembourse les frais inhérents à la mise à jour des outils de planification (notamment le schéma de
couverture de risque et le plan des mesures d’urgence) ainsi que les frais associés à la formation du
personnel et à l’acquisition d’équipements requis pour assurer la sécurité des citoyens.

As a landowner who has a recreational property on the Bay of Fundy, I'm very concerned with the increased
shipping traffic proposed if Transcanada's Energy East Pipeline is built. There will be a much greater risk of an
accident and subsequent spill and the nature of the cargo is more hazardous to the environment than
conventional oil. We have a lengthy shoreline which is adjacent to a commercial fishing wharf where we can
obtain lobster and herring fresh from the sea. We dig clams on our beach. A spill would devastate this fishery
and affect the tourists who come to the seaside to partake of this seafood and enjoy the beautiful ocean and
the marine life. I know because I do this myself. I've watched many sea birds, ducks and seals from my
property. Our property would be worthless with a spill in the Bay of Fundy. Our enjoyment of our natural
seascape would be lost forever, as it would for many people.

Impact on our personal property. With the proposed pipeline we will loose both barns on our property, as
well as or septic bed.
Our septic bed will have to be relocated to the rear of the house, which is upgrade from the house and in a
wet area of the land. Both are not ideal for septic drain fields, and we will have continued problems due to
this. The second issue is loosing both barns, we will have no place to relocate either of them since your
pipeline will take up the property that they are now on, and we can't build over the pipeline loosing valuable
storage for various vehicles, and loosing privacy due to trees being removed between us and our neighbour.
The barns and the privacy of the land was the main reason we purchased this property. There is also a small
creek that flows around the property (north side), that roots run off water away from the house to the
property south. The pipeline would cut this creek off, where is the water going to drain to and this is the area
that the septic would have to go since there is no other available land.

As Co-Director of the Climate Justice Project, a multi-year research initiative funded by SSHRC, I have
developed expertise in the economic costs and benefits of pipelines and other fossil fuel infrastructure
projects. A full accounting of economic costs and benefits must include external costs of production -- in
particular, the impact on existing economic activity, potential impacts due to spills, and impacts on human
populations associated with climate change impacts.

12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
My wife and I jointly own a bush property that is crossed by the Mainline East pipeline. The property is in
Papineau-Cameron Township, Ontario. We have been restoring the post-logged bush and inclining it toward
native species for the past four years. I am a member of the Ontario Woodlot Association and receive
professional forester consultations through local and other contacts. I have detailed knowledge of local
habitat and conditions.
The land is important. It functions as a buffer between less developed and more disturbed land. At present a
full range of flora and fauna and land forms characteristic of natural bush are still present on our property.
Further disturbance may have potential for negatively impacting a wider area that contains a Provincial
conservation reserve, Algonquin Park and both crown and private wood lots. An adjacent 400 acres are under
conservation easement issued by a private land trust. Part of our property is regulated by a Provincial
Conservation Authority. Our ephemeral pools maintain the base flows of waterways and charge aquifers that
supply drinking water to many area residents. And oil from a spill could contaminate national heritage rivers
within minutes. Much of the high-value developable land that townships depend on for future tax revenues
could be lost for many decades as well as recreational land use. The consequence of crude oil spills would be
considerable to the environment local economy. My personal land-use and life-long dream, would be
shattered.
I can address the above and similar issues from my current experience. During my career I worked as a
applied statistician, data modeller and economist.

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
7.     Safety and security during construction of the proposed project and operation of the project, including
       emergency response planning and third-party damage prevention.
Murray Township Farms Limited farms land adjacent to, and in close proximity to the proposed route. Our
farm has past negative experience with silting of our pond and streams from water runoff from highway 401.
Therefore, I am familiar with the natural pattern of contamination in the case of a spill. Lands drain naturally
in a southerly direction from the proposed route. Farmland and waterways would also be contaminated by
groundwater contamination from a spill as oil filters through the soil over time. A poorly controlled spill
would contaminate the farmland, wells and the waterways, rendering the property unsuitable for agriculture.
I request that considerations under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, as well as emergency
response planning and contingency plans for spills during construction and operation of the proposed
project, be designed to prevent short term and long term damage to farmland. It is essential that emergency
response plans and contingency plans for future spills, be designed by someone familiar with the needs of
agriculture. I would also request that these emergency and contingency plans be reviewed by specialists at
the Ontario Federation of Agriculture.

 Je m'inscris comme intervenant, sur les points suivants.
- comme propriétaire foncier en lien avec le point 12 des questions prises en considération;
- le projet OEE risque de faire diminuer la valeur foncière globale de la ville où je demeure soit Lévis. Cette
diminuation éventuelle de la valeur foncière risque de faire augmenter le compte de taxes de tous les
Lévisiens.
- l'OEE peut avoir des impacts sur la sécurité des résidents, travailleurs et voyageurs. Une partie du tracé
passe trop près de l'autoroute 20, le seul axe autoroutier entre l'Ontario et les Maritimes. En cas de
fermeture prolongé de la 20 suite à un déversement, cela va affecter la vie et la circulation des résidents;
l'accès à leur lieu de travail pour plusieurs gens vivant hors de Lévis; nuire au passage des voyageurs vers ou
en provenance des Maritimes. Les voyageurs et routiers devront passer par la route 138 en cas d'accident sur
le pipeline, pendant sa construction ou son explotation. Ceci risque de nuire à la sécurité routière dans la ville
de Lévis.
- l'OEE peut avoir un impact négatif sur l'économie de Lévis. Le projet étant en concurrence directe et/ou
indirecte avec la raffinerie Valero située à Lévis, il pourrait faire diminuer la quantité de raffinage, le nombre
d'heures travaillées sur le site et les résultats financiers de la raffinerie actuelle Valéro. Cet éventuel impact
négatif peut se traduire par une baisse du pouvoir d'achat des employés de Valéro, un des employeurs
majeurs de Lévis. Cet impact peut aussi faire diminuer la valeur foncière des terrains et installations de Valéro
et par ricochet, leur contribution au compte de taxes à la Ville de Lévis.
J'aimerais bien être entendu en audience à l'ONE sur ces aspects de questions foncières et économiques qui
peuvent influencer mon taux de taxation en tant que propriétaire foncier à Lévis.
Je m'inscris aussi pour mon expertise suivante :
- je travaille comme intervenant touristique depuis 1995. J'ai travaillé au Québec, en Ontario, aux É-U. et en
France. Je connais les impacts sur le tourisme et le tourisme durable de tels projets et installations. En
tourisme, les gens évitent les régions où ils sentent que leur sécurité personnelle pourrait être mise en
danger.
- je possède une bonne connaissance régionale de l'économie touristique ayant eu à travailler sur
d'importants projets à Québec, dans Portneuf, sur la Cote-de-Beaupré, en Mauricie et à Lévis. Parmi les
projets importants sur lesquels j'ai eu le plaisir de travailler : le Sommet des Amériques, le Sommet de la
Francophonie, le développement des nouvelles clientèles touristiques européennes, la création de nouveaux
circuits touristiques.
- j'ai fait des études de niveau maîtrise à l'UQTR en loisir, culture et tourisme. Je connais donc l'aspect
théorique du développement touristique. Je pense donc humblement avoir une expertise sur le tourisme et
sur les effets d'un tel projet sur l'économie régionale.
L'OEE pourrait influencer l'économie manufacturière ET touristique de la région de Lévis où j'habite, je
travaille et je vis.
Guy Robert
Conseiller touristique

               Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
12. L’incidence possible du projet sur les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement touchés et sur leur
       utilisation des terres
Considérant les éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques du projet proposé, sans prendre en
compte les effets des changements climatiques comme impacts cumulatifs est insensé dans la situation que
nous vivons à l'heure actuelle à travers le monde. Étant donné les conséquences des changements
climatiques sur l'agriculture, l'utilisation des terres et les modes de vie qui y sont liés, le projet aura des effets
sur les intérêts des Autochtones et sur les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement touchés.
Où j'habite, il y a de l'eau potable, une terre fertile où les êtres humains et les animaux peuvent vivre en
santé dans un environnement sain. Dans le cas d'un déversement, la nappe phréatique serait contaminée
ainsi que toute source d'eau provenant de cette nappe. L'approvisionnement en eau potable deviendrait
difficile voire impossible et dangereux. Suite à cette catastrophe, la valeur foncière des terrains, terres et
bâtisses deviendrait nulle car personne ne veut acquérir, ni vivre sur un terrain avec un sol souillé de
polluants chimiques toxiques et une eau imbuvable et empoisonnée. Aucune assurance ne veut couvrir les
dommages éventuels parce que trop importants et prévisibles.
Pour ces raisons qui me touchent particulièrement et parce que cette liste est loin d'être exhaustive, l'ONÉ
doit inclure les impacts d'Énergie Est sur le climat dans son évaluation. Échouer à le faire équivaudrait pour
les régulateurs à nier la responsabilité qu'ils ont envers les Canadiens.

 2.     La faisabilité économique du projet
13. La sécurité et la sûreté associées à la construction et à l’exploitation du projet, y compris la planification
       de l’intervention d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés par des tiers

Je suis une résidente d'un petit village situé le long du tracée du futur pipeline. Ma région est parsemée de
région boisée, de marécage, et de cour d'eau, qui allimentent les nappes fréaticques de nombreuses
personnes. La majorité des résidents de ma région s'approvisionnent en eau à partir de puis arthésien pour
leur consommation personnel, pour l'irrigation de leur champs ou l'élevage de leurs animaux. Il est donc
pertinent de mentionner qu'un seul incident pourrait gravement affecter les activités économique de ma
région en affectant non seulement la santé des citoyens mais affecte aussi à long terme la productivité et la
qualité de leur récolte et de leur élevage. Actuellement la distance prévu entre les valves laisse largement la
possibilité la possibilité de plusieurs miliers de littres dans le bassin versant environnant et nos cours d'eau.
Considérent que la fermeture de ces valves nécessite un délais de plusieurs minutes en raison des
oppérations technique de les fermers, il est inconcevable d'accepter ce projet à proximité de nos villages.
De plus, la faisabilité économique à long terme de ce projet est pratiquement impossible, car il encourage à
long terme l'expension des sables bitumineux de l'Alberta, alors que les experts exiges que 80% des
ressource connu du pétrole reste dans le sol pour ne pas augmenter les effets des changement climatique.
Considérent que de nombreux évènement météorologique fait en sorte qu'il est de plus en plus difficile de
rentrer dans les champs et qu'il est de plus en plus difficile d'en retirer des récolte. Considérent qu'il est
nécessaires de conserver une eau de qualité.
J'exige que l'office nationnal de l'énergie prenne une décision cohérente pour promouvoir la qualité de
l'environnement en refusant le projet énergie est afin d'avoir une économie canadienne forte
                                         Accès, avis et signification

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
My land backs onto the TransCanada pipelines which will change from natural gas in the proposed Energy
East bitumen/oil/etc. content conversion. When there is a small leak or a major leak or rupture it will have a
direct effect on my land and my well water (my neighbourhood of 26 homes are all on well water/septic with
my home being one of thirteen backing onto the lines to be converted. My family has been on the land
before the TransCanada Pipelines. I've seen construction and burial of the pipes to be converted in the
Energy East proposal and our well and neighbours wells were effected during the construction of the lines
therefore there is every chance our well water would be impacted by a leak. Before the construction we had
excellent water after construction and the redrilling of our well we have to have a water filtration system and
as it ages we have to pay for the equipment replacement not TransCanada (we wouldn't have had to have
this equipment/filtration system if our well hadn't been affected by the pipelines. When/if our land and well
water are contaminated how long would it take before there would be a clean-up? Would we ever be able to
grow vegetables, etc. on our land and use our water. At meetings we've been told that drinking water would
be supplied if there was a leak/rupture. Is this provision of water for life? Is it more than drinking water as
I'd like to bathe, water my vegetables, fruit & berry bushes, etc.? Our family chose this land as it was within
city limits, but has the benefits of being in a clean, healthy and natural area of beauty, and we don't want to
have to evacuate and leave our home and land (we were here before the pipelines). When there is a leak
and the land and water are contaminated/poisoned our land/home will be worthless. We should be
concentrating on finding alternative energy sources that don't create greenhouse gases. We should be
investing money in the railways to safely transport goods and people instead of highways which promote
vehicles and the production of pollution and pipelines that carry oil/bitumen/etc. There is no economic
benefit to our area as the pipelines already exist and no new jobs will be created - the provinces to benefit
the most will be Alberta, New Brunswick and Quebec and corporations/stockholders. Is there a 100%
guarantee that my land and water will not be polluted/contaminated and I won't have to leave my home and
land? I love my home, my land and my well water (water is a more precious commodity than oil) and don't
want that taken away from me.

16. Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office à l’égard du
       projet
La Fondation québécoise pour la protection du patrimoine naturel (FQPPN) est un organisme de conservation
à but non lucratif créé en vertu d’une charte provinciale. Son territoire d’intervention concerne
principalement la « Réserve naturelle des battures de Saint-Augustin-de-Desmaures (RNBSAD)», une aire
protégée en vertu de la Loi québécoise sur la protection du patrimoine naturel dont elle est le propriétaire
foncier. Cette réserve naturelle privée assure la protection de 12 km de rives et de battures le long du Saint-
Laurent à la hauteur de la Ville de Saint-Augustin-de-Desmaures (SAD), soit près de 400 hectares de terrains
de haute valeur pour la conservation. À ce compte, la RNBSAD abrite un cortège floristique d’exception dont
17 espèces en situation précaire reconnues par la Loi sur les espèces en péril du Canada et la Loi sur les
espèces menacées ou vulnérables du Québec. Le gentianopsis de Victorin, la cicutaire de Victorin, la
vergerette de Provancher et l’ériocaulon de Parker ont été désignées espèces menacées au Québec. Les deux
premières sont endémiques à l’estuaire du Saint-Laurent. À titre de gestionnaire d’une réserve naturelle et
en obligation de protéger ses attributs, la FQPPN se doit de présenter un dossier dans le projet Oléoduc
Énergie Est.
La FQPPN est particulièrement préoccupée par les impacts négatifs potentiels sur l’environnement et la
sécurité publique du transport de pétrole lourd en provenance des sables bitumineux par voie d’oléoduc,
mais aussi par les impacts négatifs potentiels d’un déversement important qui surviendrait suite à un
accident, à une erreur humaine ou à une défaillance technologique en cours d’opération de cet oléoduc.
Le tracé de l’oléoduc proposé par le projet Oléoduc Énergie Est touche directement la RNBSAD d’une part
parce qu’il est prévu que le pipeline traverse le fleuve Saint-Laurent à travers la RNBSAD et d’autre part la
présence du pipeline le long de l’auto 40 et son approche au Saint-Laurent qui traversera les terres, les boisés
riverains de haute valeur écologique, rivières et bassins versants qui se déversent dans la Réserve naturelle.
À la hauteur de la RNBSAD, il faut noter que le marnage atteint 5 m d’amplitude lors des grandes marées et
que la présence de la large batture peut nuire aux interventions sur le fleuve tel que nous l’avons déjà
expérimenté par le passé. À ce, il faut ajouter la présence de glaces hivernales qui nuisent à la récupération
des produits pétroliers.
D’un point de vue environnemental, de telles problématiques auraient des répercussions importantes sur les
milieux humides littoraux de l’estuaire d’eau douce à saumâtre, un point chaud de rareté en termes de
biodiversité, mais aussi une cible prioritaire en matière de conservation et de gestion pour les ministères
québécois et canadien de l’environnement et des groupes environnementaux dont nous faisons parti.
Enfin, la FQPPN souhaite voir certaines conditions être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation
de l’Office à l’égard du projet de TransCanada dont : la durée de vie utile d’un tel oléoduc et son plan de
démantèlement.

 1.     The need for the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
1. The dilbit oil in Energy East is headed for trans-shipment to Europe & Asia which means it will not be used
in Canada & will not reduce the price of gasoline in Canada. It will however displace natural gas moving from
west to east. Gaz Métro CEO Sophie Brochu states that unless a new pipeline is built, 3.6 million natural gas
customers could see a 150 per cent price increase over the course of a single winter.
7. Oil Spills from line ruptures will all be extremely large because it takes 20 minutes to shut sown the
pumping of the line. The Kalamzoo spill reveals how widely & severely the area is affected. In our area a
rupture would affect major water sources causing a damage to our source of clean water & a major
destruction of our tourism industry. Recovery from this damage takes many years & results in a reduction in
health & many lost jobs. . After shut down the contents of the line, leak out into the environment. Diluent is
highly toxic, carcinogenic, & poisonous. It is heavier than water & sinks. It is extremely hard & very
expensive to clean up.
11. The Cree downstream from the tar sands are suffering from rare forms of cancer in high numbers. It is
bulling by big companies to subject the Cree to these diseases for the company's profits.
14. In 2010 an Enbridge pipeline ruptured spilling 3.3 million litres of oil into Michigan’s Kalamazoo River. In
2013 the cleanup was still incomplete & had cost more than $1 billion. Most of the people living in the area
had to give up their homes & leave. After studying this spill of tar sands dilbit, the Environmental Protection
Agency says tar sands oil spills, are next to impossible to clean up. That crude sticks to everything it touches,
even rocks & it bio degrades poorly & everything needs to be disposed of.
In our area the pipeline would threaten a diluted bitumen spill into the Lake of the Woods, Darlington Bay,
Rabbit Lake and Black Sturgeon Lakes affecting drinking water sources and fishing and recreational waters.
Trans Canada should be forced to carry over $3 billion in insurance for spill cleanup & remediation as well as
looking after the people who suffer.
17. Burning the oil moved through the pipeline would unleash up to 32 million tonnes of greenhouse gases
into the atmosphere wherever it is burned. The effects of climate change are already affecting Canada's
weather severely with a high frequency of severe storms, wind damage & severe & frequent floods all across
Canada. The mountain pine beetle is spreading because the winters are too warm in BC resulting in severe
damage of the forest industry. We are seeing more severe fire seasons due to more droughts.

 16. The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue for
       the Project
Established in 1990, Save Our Seine River Environment Inc. (“SOS”) is a grassroots organization that speaks
for the urban Seine River (“SR”) in Winnipeg on behalf of approximately 500 active supporters including local
residents, members, volunteers, board members, advisors, alumni, and donors. SOS has local knowledge,
pertinent information, and relevant expertise (hydrology, impact analysis, GIS, ecology, socio-economics, and
environmental education) to offer on the specific impact of the project on the urban SR, its residents, and its
educational and recreational users (Issue #7).
The majority of SOS’s supporters live and/or work near the river. Many own property on the river – some
having lived there for many decades. They have unique local knowledge and would be directly affected by the
project (Issue #12). Other supporters live near the SR – using it on a regular basis for recreation (canoeing,
cycling, walking) and environmental education (Adopt-a-River). These uses would be affected by the project
(Issue #7). The Kalamazoo River spill suggests that a dilbit spill reaching the urban SR could contaminate the
river for several years and necessitate evacuation from homes along the river (Issue #13). This would affect
SOS and its supporters – their land, property value, health, and/or recreational use of the river and its parks
(Issue #15).
The Seine River enters Winnipeg through a unique inverted siphon beneath the Winnipeg Floodway. The river
meanders 26 km through the heart of St. Boniface/St. Vital (2006 population of 111,000) before joining the
Red River. Most private properties along the urban SR are residential – homes, apartments, and condos.
Sixteen neighbourhoods directly abut the SR (2006 population of 46,010). Portions of nine other
neighbourhoods are within one km of the river. Tens of thousands of residents on the SR could conceivably
be affected by contamination of the river (Issue #15).
The project’s proposed location (Issue #9) is very close to the siphon where the SR enters Winnipeg. If a spill
occurred near the siphon, drainage ditches would quickly carry contaminated water a short distance (6-12
km) to the SR and the siphon. Contaminants accumulating inside the 0.5 km underground siphon would be
extremely difficult and costly to remove (Issues #14 and #15) and would affect the hydrology and water
quality of the urban SR for many years. The pipeline parallels the rural SR for 45 kilometers – crossing the
river at St. Anne, MB. A spill into any ditch along this length would be carried into the SR and its effects could
reach the urban SR. A spill into Winnipeg’s Red River could also back-flood the urban SR for 10 kilometers
(Issue #7).
Project siting, design, and operation must ensure that potential dilbit spills near Winnipeg would be detected,
stopped, and cleaned up quickly to prevent contaminants from reaching and/or blocking the siphon or
entering the urban SR (Issue #14 and #16). Because of the very serious implications if oil gets to and into the
SR siphon, a special response plan is needed to address this contingency (Issue #14 and #16).

My name is Shane Furze and I believe that I should be included in the hearing process of this project. I am an
avid fly fisherman on the Miramichi River, I am a licensed fishing and hunting guide focusing on the Miramichi
and St. John Rivers. My parents are property owners on Route 112 and within the Miramichi watershed. Also,
I am a PhD candidate focusing on better mapping natural resources in N.B. to reduce the ecological and
environmental impacts of our actions. My Masters degree was directed toward assessing the impacts of road-
stream crossings and soil erosion on Atlantic Salmon populations within the Northwest Miramichi watershed.
In regards to the list of issues:
7. Upon reviewing the map of the proposed location of the pipeline, I realized that this project will directly
have an impact on both the watersheds of the St. John River and Southwest Miramichi. Both of these rivers
are home to native populations of Atlantic Salmon and populations of this species have been in a consistent
decline over the past decade with 2014 recording some of the lowest populations in recorded history. The
ecological, cultural and economic importance of this species is of significant concern in this province. For
example, in 1995, the Atlantic salmon recreational fishery was responsible for $100 million in annual revenue
(source: Miramichi River Environmental Assessment Committee). With this being said, it is important that we
keep in mind the economic benefit and revenue stream associated with the recreational sports within N.B.
that will be directly impacted by this project. If this project is completed and there was a spill then this could
be detrimental to many business owners (including myself as a licensed guide).
8. Atlantic salmon, being an anadromous species, complete an annual migration from watercourse to ocean
and back to watercourse to fulfill their spawning/ feeding requirements. By increasing the traffic of marine
vessels within the Bay of Fundy will increase the pressure on an already- dwindling population of native
salmonids. Keep in mind that the Petitcodiac Causeway had extirpated these species from the watercourse in
the late 1970’s but these species are beginning to return.
9+14. I am interested in the measures proposed to avoid and mitigate any spill if it was to occur. I am a
student and employee with a watershed research center and understand the hydrography of a landscape. I
want to know what the plan of actions is to reduce the adverse effects of a spill or fracture in the pipeline?
Also, I am curious in the proposed layout and route of the pipeline. What about steep slopes, areas of rich
biodiversity, wet areas, watercourses, mature forest stands? How will these be avoided or dealt with?
I believe I can bring not only ideas but insight into the hearing process I would appreciate the opportunity to
be included in this project, not only because of my educational background but also the direct impact this
project will have on my family and myself.

 The New Brunswick Business Council is a collection of non-partisan business leaders who work to promote
economic growth and community development in the province. The New Brunswick Business Council's
mission is to help build a competitive and growing economy that provides opportunities for all who invest,
work and live in New Brunswick. In recent years, the Business Council focussed on three priority areas:
promoting entrepreneurship, growing productive employment, and promoting economic policy debate and
development.
The Council is gravely concerned about New Brunswick’s fiscal challenges. With a growing $400 million
structural deficit, the province also faces demographic pressures resulting from an aging population and
migration outflows that are pushing the economic growth potential below the long-term historical average
growth rate. These challenges can be offset by maximizing the benefits of projects like Energy East
The members of the NBBC, who are owners of both large and small businesses in New Brunswick, have a
direct interest in many of the issues identified by the Board that will be part of the regulatory review of the
Energy East Pipeline Project.
NBBC members who operate their businesses along or in the vicinity of the proposed pipeline route are often
major landholders and therefore interested in the appropriateness of the route, land use issues and
restrictions on land use during the construction and operation phase of the pipeline in various regions of the
province. For example, McCain Foods is one such corporation that relies on the supply of potatoes from
farmers in northwest NB, an area in which the route is proposed.
NBBC members have a direct interest in the potential economic and commercial issues related to the project.
NBBC members also have a direct interest in issues related to the supply chain and workforce development
during the construction phase. NBBC members, as major taxpayers and employers, have an interest in
emergency response systems and ensuring that the pipeline is constructed and operated in a safe, reliable,
and environmentally responsible manner for the benefit of the communities where they live and operate
their businesses.
NBBC members also have an interest in any terms and conditions that might be included in a
recommendation from the NEB.
The NBBC is applying to participate in these proceedings to represent to the Board the interests of its
members in the Energy East project.

economic feasibility of the project as it relates to contingency planning, during both the pre-implementation

accidents or malfunctions, ways to mitigate those risks through consideration of both the route and
engineering design, and suggestions for both preventative and restorative aspects of the contingency
planning.

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.
2.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the proposed project.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
7.     Safety and security during construction of the proposed project and operation of the project, including
       emergency response planning and third-party damage prevention.
Toronto and Region Conservation Authority (TRCA) is mandated by the Province of Ontario to establish and
undertake programs to promote the conservation, restoration, development and management of natural
resources in partnership with local municipalities and the province for its watersheds. TRCA has statutory
authority to issue permits for construction, development and inspection activities for municipal and private
projects, including TransCanada. Accordingly, TRCA may also prosecute for harm to ecosystems, including
watersheds within TRCA's jurisdiction.
In a letter of comment, TRCA will discuss how route selection, construction techniques, monitoring and
pipeline integrity will affect the natural heritage system, including valley and stream corridors, woodlots and
wetlands within its jurisdiction. TRCA also works closely with Parks Canada, and will continue to do so as
related to the pipeline crossing of Rouge Park. TRCA may also address issues of mutual concern related to
park interests in its letter.
In accordance with Ontario Regulation 166/06, TransCanada is required to obtain permits from TRCA for
numerous locations of pipeline construction within its jurisdiction. As such, TRCA has a vested interest in
ensuring that the route selection will minimize impacts to valley and stream corridors, as well as the natural
heritage system and natural hazards. During the detailed design stage of the project, TRCA will work with
TransCanada to confirm that our regulatory obligations related to control of flooding, erosion, conservation
of land and pollution are addressed. Through the NEB process, TRCA will make comment related to the timing
of route selection, permit application and review, as well as permit approval to ensure that there is sufficient
time allocated for permit review in advance of the tendering and construction phases of the project.
Additionally, TRCA is concerned with long-term pipeline integrity, including exposure, third party damage,
failures and/or spills and emergency response as related to valley and stream corridor management, natural
hazards, and terrestrial and aquatic environments within its jurisdiction. Proactive mitigation and monitoring
strategies of the natural systems are important tools for ensuring that issues are corrected before the
pipeline is exposed or, in the worst case scenario, breached. These tools include analysis of forest and
wetland ecosystems; geotechnical and soil cover evaluations; hydrogeological, hydrologic and hydraulic
evaluations (including stream geomorphology); and emergency access and response protocols.

 En tant que depute de Rimouski-Neigette—Témiscouata—Les Basques, je m’inscris afin de représenter
l’Opposition officielle, le Nouveau Parti démocratique du Canada (NPD) et ses députés, qui représentent des
circonscriptions directement affectées par le projet Énergie Est de TransCanada. En tant que groupe, nous
vivons et travaillons dans les régions traversées par ce projet d’oléoduc et nous représentons nos
commettants et nos communautés qui vivent en bordure du tracé proposé. Mon intérêt pour ce projet vient
des intérêts des citoyens de ces circonscriptions, en vertu des impacts environnementaux, sociaux et
économiques du projet.
Les informations que je fournirai incluront des perspectives sur les impacts potentiels sur la sécurité
énergétique du Canada, les emplois à valeur ajoutée, le développement économique, les ramifications
environnementales, en plus des consultations avec les communautés, la sécurité et, finalement, des points de
vue locaux pour conserver de bons emplois.
Je fournirai également de l’information et une expertise sur les enjeux sociaux, économiques et
environnementaux reliés à ce projet. Cela comprendra des commentaires sur les questions
environnementales en vertu des risques pour la biodiversité et des risques d’accident, les impacts sociaux du
projet, y compris de l’information sur l’obligation de Couronne de consulter et de se conformer aux traités
avec les Premières Nations, un résumé des préoccupations des propriétaires (résidences et terres) et des
résidents dans le cas d’un malfonctionnement, ainsi que les impacts économiques pour les communautés en
bordure du projet.
Je partagerai de l’information obtenue auprès des député(e)s que je représente qui démontre l’importance
de tenir un processus ouvert et transparent pour ce projet, y compris des points de vue locaux sur la manière
dont une participation significative du public augmente la crédibilité du processus d’évaluation auprès de la
population et aide l’Office à prendre des décisions responsables. J’aborderai également la question de la
manière dont la qualité de la consultation auprès des communautés et de la portion de l’évaluation
environnementale dans l’étude de l’Office peut aider à prévenir et atténuer tout effet indésirables reliés au
projet proposé.

February 26, 2015
To Whom It May Concern:
As a member of the Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick (Fredericton-South), together with my colleagues,
I have a responsibility to ensure that the treaty relationship New Brunswick has with the Wolastoqiyik in the
face of this proposal is respected, and that matters concerning aboriginal, treaty and land rights are
appropriately addressed. The Peace and Friendship Treaties that govern our relationship with First Nations in
New Brunswick were signed by representatives of the First Nations and of the Crown. All parties have
responsibilities and obligations under the treaties. As an MLA I swore an oath of Allegiance to Her Majesty
Queen Elizabeth the Second and have a responsibility to uphold the honour of the Crown in this matter.
Further there are New Brunswick landowners along the proposed pipeline route who cast their vote for
candidates representing my party during the recent provincial election, and I have an obligation to them to
ensure their interests are fully addressed by the National Energy Board.
Yours truly
David Coon
MLA, Fredericton-South
Leader, Green Party of New Brunswick

 3.     The commercial, economic, supply and market impacts of the Project
16. The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue for
       the Project
Grand Lake Growth Committee represents businesses, community leaders, educators, mayors and councillors
in and around the villages of Chipman and Minto, New Brunswick. The Grand Lake Growth Committee has a
mandate to promote and facilitate economic development in the Grand Lake region; home to the largest
freshwater lake in the Maritime provinces. Chipman, located about 75 kilometres from the capital city of
Fredericton, has a population of 1,200 and is located on the banks of Salmon River at the head of Grand Lake.
Minto has a population of ~2,500 and is situated on the north shore of Grand Lake; approximately 50
kilometres from Fredericton.
The proposed Energy East Pipeline route runs between Chipman and Minto. The route is ~5 kilometres from
the municipal boundary of Chipman and ~12 kilometres from the municipal boundary of Minto.
The Growth Committee, and its members, have a direct interest in the commercial, economic, supply and
market impacts of the project on the local region. The Growth Committee has been informing its members
about the Energy East Pipeline Project for over two years and has attended open houses and information
sessions over this period. The Growth Committee has examined the potential economic benefits of the
project on their local communities and has also assessed its associated challenges. The committee has unique
insight into the economic impacts that this project will have on their local area and are interested in sharing
these findings with the Board for consideration. Furthermore, they would like to express their opinions as to
specific terms and conditions to be considered by the Board in any recommendation or approval that they
may issue. The Committee believes that terms and conditions should be in place that would ensure that
communities most impacted by the pipeline would be positioned to receive the most economic benefit from
the building of the pipeline (in terms of employment, supply chain spending, maintenance, industrial benefits
etc).
The Grand Lake Growth Committee is seeking the opportunity to participate in these proceedings to fully
articulate to the Board the interests of its members in the Energy East Project.

 The proposed pipeline traverses the Municipality of Clarington from east to west for 32 kilometres. The
matters that are important to the Municipality are justification of the need for a second easement. We have
been informed that the NEB has a regulation restricting the existing easement to the two pipes it contains;
thus the requirement for an additional easement. In the meetings over the past two years, Staff from
Planning Services and Engineering Services have had with representatives of TransCanada they have not
provided a clear justification as to why an additional easement is required. If the restriction is in relation to
an NEB regulation, what is the justification and when was it last reviewed? With newer construction
techniques the proposed 36 inch pipeline could be accommodated in the existing easement; particularly
when coupled with the additional monitoring, detection technology and other safety improvements that
have been realized since the previous pipelines were installed; the need for separation should be alleviated
and would make wise and compact use of the existing easement.
The proposed route which is for the most part adjacent to the existing easement. The lands the proposed
new easement is to be routed through are mostly agricultural and environmental protection in the Official
Plan; the lands are within the Greenbelt as designated by the Province of Ontario. Land reclamation for the
affected farmers is an important issue, as is the need to work with the farming community to avoid crop
damage, provide compensation and repair damage to tile drainage.
The Municipality is concerned as to how environmental impacts will be avoided and particularly in the Areas
of Natural and Scientific Importance such as Stephen's Gulch and other valley and creek systems that will
have to be traversed as part of this proposal. We support the comments and requests that are being made
by the Conservation Authority(s) with regard to the routing, and how construction will be carried out in
proximity to sensitive landscape features.
The proposed and existing easements crosses under 26 local roads, 5 Regional Roads and a Provincial
Highway within the Municipality. We are requesting that TransCanada provide their proposed routes for all
equipment and materials haulage and must provide funds for pre/post road assessments and rectification of
any deemed damages.
The timing and co-ordination of the construction with other major projects (Highway 407, Clarington
Transformer Station), particularly in the western portion of the Municipality will be a key requirement to
avoid disruption and mitigate socio-economic impacts. This is the location of Compressor Station #134 which
will require a site plan approval by the Municipality.
Of particular importance will be the terms and conditions set out by the NEB in any recommendation or
approval. These recommendations should include requirements that TransCanada meet or exceed the
engineering, safety and construction standards and adhere to the requirements of local municipalities.

1.     Les éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques du projet proposé, notamment ceux qui
       sont décrits dans la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation environnementale.
3.     Les répercussions possibles du projet proposé sur les propriétaires fonciers et leur utilisation des terres.
Considérant les éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques du projet proposé, sans prendre en
compte les effets des changements climatiques comme impacts cumulatifs est insensé dans la situation que
nous vivons à l'heure actuelle à travers le monde. Étant donné les conséquences des changements
climatiques sur l'agriculture, l'utilisation des terres et les modes de vie qui y sont liés, le projet aura des effets
sur les intérêts des Autochtones et sur les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement touchés.
Où j'habite, il y a de l'eau potable, une terre fertile où les êtres humains et les animaux peuvent vivre en
santé dans un environnement sain. Dans le cas d'un déversement, la nappe phréatique serait contaminée
ainsi que toute source d'eau provenant de cette nappe. L'approvisionnement en eau potable deviendrait
difficile voire impossible et dangereux. Suite à cette catastrophe, la valeur foncière des terrains, terres et
bâtisses deviendrait nulle car personne ne veut acquérir, ni vivre sur un terrain avec un sol souillé de
polluants chimiques toxiques et une eau imbuvable et empoisonnée. Aucune assurance ne veut couvrir les
dommages éventuels parce que trop importants et prévisibles.
Pour ces raisons qui me touchent particulièrement et parce que cette liste est loin d'être exhaustive, l'ONÉ
doit inclure les impacts d'Énergie Est sur le climat dans son évaluation. Échouer à le faire équivaudrait pour
les régulateurs à nier la responsabilité qu'ils ont envers les Canadiens.

supplémentaires tels que les coûts d'assurance domiciliaire.

obtenir l'argent nécessaire à sa représentation par une firme d'avocats.

Calgary, (Alberta) T2R 0A8                                                                                                3
 The Town of Arnprior’s Water Filtration Plant Intake from the Madawaska River is located 8 km east and
downstream of the proposed pipeline crossing of the Madawaska River (Ontario) at Stewartville. The
Madawaska River is the Town's only source of drinking water for a population of approximately 8200 people.
The Town’s foremost concern is source water protection and the provision of safe drinking water. A release
of oil or other contaminants into the river during drilling operations or during the operation of the pipeline
could render the Town’s only water source unusable and force the shutdown of our water intake to the
Town’s Water Filtration Plant. This would impact not only drinking water for the Town, but also fire
protection which relies on the hydrants connected to our distribution system, and also local businesses and
industries which use water in their daily activities. For these reasons, it is clear that the Town of Arnprior is
directly affected by the Energy East project. A spill of almost any size, even one not considered to be
‘significant’ by TransCanada (less than 50 barrels), would be considered a significant threat to the Town’s
ability to provide a safe drinking water, fire protection and water used by local businesses and industries in
their processes.
Secondly, the Town is directly affected by the project because TransCanada has stated that the Town’s
resources, in the form of Arnprior’s emergency responders, would be responsible for providing significant
support in the case of an emergency. The Town of Arnprior’s resources would be called upon in the event of
a pipeline emergency. As such, the Town should be provided with an opportunity to provide comments
directly to the NEB on the details of the project that are of interest to first responders, including the ability to
provide final comment on any emergency response plans that the Town’s staff would be drawn into.
The need to be closely involved with the development of the emergency response plans and be provided with
an opportunity to provide final comment on said plans is not only critical to the first responders that will be
expected to provide support, but also for the operation of the Town’s Water Distribution system. As stated
above, source water protection is a high priority for the Town, and the Town feels that it is important that all
planning undertaken by Energy East continuously consider protection of the Town’s only water source.
It is anticipated that there could be direct and indirect financial burdens experienced by the Town as a result
of the Energy East project. The Town’s local economy is greatly tied to the Madawaska River due to its
recreational and leisure opportunities. Aside from the financial burdens that could develop as a result of a
forced shut-off of the Town’s water intake from the Madawaska River, additionally the Town’s local economy
could be devastated as a result of the loss of the river as a prime recreation and tourism destination.

Ma propriété est un lot boisé (no. 3 831 205) situé à Neuville (PORT-0199 pour TCP).
Initialement, M. Michel Hudon a présenté un plan mentionnant une largeur de 23 mètres adossée à la limite
de l'oléoduc déjà existant et empiétant sur ma propriété
du côté nord. Le 9 février 2015, Mme Manon Mérineau me présenta un 2e plan où le tracé est large de 25
mètres plus 15 mètres supplémentaires pour les débris et
un déplacement vers le sud, à l'entrée ouest de mon lot, créant un espace libre entre l'oléoduc et ma
propriété.
/
Le déplacement du tracé et son élargissement de 15 mètres supplémentaires ont plusieurs effets négatifs
notamment la destruction:
1. d'une partie beaucoup plus importante de ma plantation de 15 ans;
2. d'une partie plus grande de forêt qui alimente mon commerce de bois de chauffage et qui entraînera la
perte des revenus en découlant;
3. des abris à bois servant au commerce de bois de chauffage et dont la relocalisation détruira une nouvelle
zone de forêt;
4. du chemin d'accès dont le remplacement amènera à détruire une nouvelle zone de forêt dont notamment
une plantation;
5. d'une partie beaucoup plus significative de mon érablière entraînant une diminution importante de la
production et du potentiel de régénération.
Ce nouveau tracé créera un espace inutilisable de terrain entre la limite ouest du tracé et celle de mon lot. Il
obligera à déplacer l'entrepôt et à détruire une zone de
forêt supplémentaire. Les arbres détruits ne pourront être remis en état. J'améliore mon lot depuis 25 ans au
point de recevoir une offre de 125 000$ il y a quatre ans.
Le projet réduit significativement le potentiel de vente de ma propriété.
/
Je m'oppose au nouveau tracé car il lèse de façon abusive mon droit à la jouissance de ma propriété. Le
projet peut se réaliser sans être aussi dérangeant pour moi.
Compte tenu de ce qui précède, je demande le retour au tracé initial en l'adossant à celui du gazoduc existant
sur toute la limite nord de mon lot au lieu de le déplacer
vers le sud à l'extrémité ouest et en limitant la servitude au strict minimum, c'est-à-dire à 11-12 mètres à
partir du gazoduc existant.

The City     Project
               Ottawa represents over 900,000 residents in urban, suburban and rural areas, and has within it a
significant body of water, the Rideau River, under which the existing TransCanada gas pipeline flows.
The existing pipeline travels through a large portion of the City’s rural area, and inhabitants within the areas
are most affected by this Project.
The City is responsible for ensuring the health and safety of its residents and their property, and the
stewardship of the environment within its jurisdiction. Therefore the City is directly affected by the potential
environmental and socio-economic impacts of the project, including:
• potential contamination of the Rideau River; significant environmental features such as wetlands, wildlife
habitat and woodlands ; and vulnerable aquifers (a source of drinking water for private and communal wells);
• significant impacts to area-specific residents and public health in general due to the environmental effects
of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project;
• cumulative effects that may result from the Project together with impacts from the remediation of
vulnerable surface and ground water areas, wetlands, natural heritage features, fish and wildlife habitats,
agricultural lands, public and private property and monitoring thereafter of such remediation efforts;
• potential impacts of a pumping station located 600m north of a provincially significant wetland located
within the City.
Residents, businesses and industry within Ottawa rely on the existing gas supplied by the existing pipeline
and as consumers; the City has concerns of the availability of gas supply after conversion.
The City is located where there are mid-continental faults that underlie the region and the impacts of seismic
activity by the movements of tectonic plates within the Ottawa area on the pipeline may have significant
consequences.
The City is concerned that the following elements of the construction and operations could have a direct
affect on its residents:
• the monitoring and leak detection program including appropriate measures to detect (in addition to large
ruptures) small chronic leaks;
• the sufficiency of precautions taken for the conversion process and its emergency preparedness planning
where the pipeline is located near a sensitive or vulnerable component of the environment, such as small
creeks and streams and other headwater features;
• the public education campaign for reporting spills or issues related to the pipeline;
517 Tenth Avenue SW                                                                  Telephone/Téléphone : (403) 292-4800
Calgary, Alberta T2R 0A8                                                             Facsimile/Télécopieur : (403) 292-5503
                                                                                                http://www..neb-one.gc.ca
517, Dixième Avenue S.-O.                                                                                   1-800-899-1265
Calgary, (Alberta) T2R 0A8                                                                                                3
 • the lack of information on the potential long-term and short-term adverse human health and
environmental impacts resulting from exposure to products being shipped
The City is thoroughly familiar with its local environment and its departments can provide comments on the
environmental assessment and mitigation efforts concerning impacts from construction and operation of the
pipeline in the follows areas:
• safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
response planning, equipment and training needs and third-party damage prevention;
• contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the Project
and financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
and operations of the Project.

       travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet

       d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet

       projet
La MRC de Montmagny est située sur la rive sud du Saint-Laurent. Quatre municipalités du territoire de la
MRC de Montmagny sont traversées par le projet d'oléoduc Énergie Est. Même si il n'y a pas de position
générale d'opposition à la mise en place d'une infrastructure aussi importante qu'un oléoduc, les citoyens et
les élus qui les représentent émettent certaines inquiétudes devant l'éventuelle venue d'une telle
infrastructure.
Les principales préoccupations du milieu qui sont transmises par la MRC concernent les dangers de fuite sur
l'environnement. Y aura-t-il assez de mécanismes et des procédés adéquats pour éviter des accidents
écologiques? Qui financera la formation des responsables de mesures d'urgence? Les municipalités auront-
elles à s'équiper de matériel pour intervenir en cas d'urgence? Les interventions prévues pour arrêter les
déversements sont-ils adéquats? Comment est prévu le démantèlement après la durée de vie de
l'infrastructure?
Aussi, à Cap-Saint-Ignace, la municipalité aurait souhaité avoir plus d'information sur l'analyse d'un tracé
alternatif. Y-a-t-il eu vraiment une analyse sérieuse de TransCanada sur ce sujet?
Toujours dans cette municipalité, un poste de pompage est prévu. Les mesures de mitigation afin d'éviter
des impacts sur l'environnement, ont elles toutes été développées?
Une autre préoccupation concerne l'impact sur la valeur foncière des terrains de secteurs situés à proximité
d'un oléoduc. Est-ce que toutes les propriétés affectées ont obtenu un dédommagement?
Face à ce questionnement de ses citoyens, la MRC de Montmagny entend porter à l'attention de l'Office
national de l'Énergie des commentaires visant à faire du projet Énergie Est, un projet sécuritaire et
acceptable pour la communauté s'il se réalise.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
The Federation of Northern Ontario Municipalities (FONOM) is a municipal organization that represents 110
member municipalities across northeastern Ontario, many of which will be impacted by the Energy East
Project as the pipeline that will be converted runs through many communities. Further to our representation
of municipal governments, our Board of Directors consist of 11 elected officials. As local leaders within our
communities, FONOM has extensive experience with interacting with different levels of government as well
as the private sector and are held to the highest standards to ensure residents are safe and have a superior
quality of life.
As stewards of vast land across northern Ontario, we as northerners have a great interest in ensuring that all
potential environmental effects associated with the Project are appropriately addressed in both the short-
term and long-term. Most importantly, we want to ensure that protections are put in place especially in
regards to water crossings and sources of drinking water. Any negative impact to sources of drinking water
for a community could have devastating consequences that municipal governments would have to
communicate to their residents. Municipalities would also have to seek alternative solutions to ensure
residents have the services that municipal governments are mandated to provide.
FONOM also acknowledges the socio-economic impacts that the Energy East Project would have on many of
our member municipalities. As many residents of our municipalities would be working for TransCanada
Pipeline on the Energy East Project if it is to proceed, we acknowledge the opportunity to employ our citizens
with highly skilled jobs. As well, there are economic opportunities for the businesses in our communities who
would benefit from increased local commerce.
Our organization has a specific interest in regards to the safety and security measures that will be
implemented during both the construction and operation of the Project and how they will be communicated
to municipalities. Emergency response planning must be clearly communicated with municipal emergency
services such as fire and police. As an organization that understands municipal planning issues as they relate
to emergency services, we can assist in providing information in best practices and what needs to be in place.
In conclusion, our organization, representing the interests of 110 municipalities across the northeast, has a
strong interest in the process and outcome of this project. As local leaders, FONOM also has significant
experience and knowledge in regards to working with municipal governments.

 7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets

9.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet
L'Organisme de bassins versants de Kamouraska, L'Islet et Rivière-du-Loup est un organisme de concertation
chargée par le Gouvernement du Québec de mettre en oeuvre la gestion intégrée de l'eau par bassin versant
sur son territoire d'intervention, qui concerne principalement les MRC des Kamouraska et de Rivière-du-
Loup. Les membres de la table de concertation, en provenance des secteurs économique, municipal et
communautaire, travaillent à identifier des pistes de solutions aux problèmes associés à l'eau sur le territoire,
afin d'assurer la cohabitation des différents usages dans une perspective de développement durable de la
ressource. Dans ce contexte, le tracé de l'oléoduc sur notre territoire (segment Saint-Gabriel-Lalemant -
Cacouna principalement) sera analysé et mis en relation avec les autres usages du territoire relié à l'eau afin
d'identifier les conflits possibles. L'Organisme a accumulé beaucoup d'information et dispose du savoir local
de ses participants afin d'avoir une vue élargie du projet et de ses impacts sur le territoire et ainsi affiner les
recommandations qu'il pourra faire.
Le document que l'Organisme préparera pour l'Office national de l'énergie contiendra ses recommandations
précises concernant le tracé de l'oléoduc sur son territoire, sur les aspects reliés à la protection de l'eau et
des milieux associés. Il mettra également le projet en relation avec les autres usages de l'eau et pourra
proposer des alternatives au tracé, des pistes d'action ou tout autre élément qui feront consensus auprès des
membres de la table de concertation.

 2.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the proposed project.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
The proposed pipeline does not follow the existing route of TransCanada’s pipelines through Oshawa but
rather follows a more northerly route.
The proposed route bisects lands in Oshawa’s future urban expansion area (“UAE”) planned for residential
development. The location and orientation of the route relative to existing roads and components of the
Natural Heritage System (NHS) in the area will result in land use and development inefficiencies, including
constrained interstitial development areas situated between the pipeline and existing transportation
infrastructure and the NHS. This will hinder optimizing the use of existing and planned infrastructure and
achieving mandated Greenfield density targets for jobs and population required by the Provincial plan Places
to Grow: Growth Plan for the Greater Golden Horseshoe.
Realigning the pipeline further north outside of the UAE is equally problematic as shifting the route from
south to north of Howden Road places the pipeline directly within the Greenbelt Protected Countryside Area
as set out in the Provincial Greenbelt Plan. The Greenbelt Plan contains policies related to the provision of
infrastructure and utilities (including pipelines) that seek, as a first principle, to prevent infrastructure or
utilities from traversing the Greenbelt unless there is a demonstrable need for the project and no reasonable
alternative.
The proposed route also traverses part of the Oak Ridges Moraine (ORM) through Oshawa. The Provincial
Oak Ridges Moraine Conservation Plan (ORMCP) sets a clear policy framework for protecting the ORM. Like
the Greenbelt Plan, the ORMCP contains policies that prevent infrastructure or utilities from traversing the
ORM unless there is a demonstrable need and no reasonable alternative. Rerouting the pipeline north to
avoid the City’s UAE would exacerbate impacts on the ORM.
Given that the proposed route significantly impacts the UAE, that the proposed alignment traverses the ORM,
and that a more northerly alignment to avoid the UAE would impact an even greater portion of the ORM as
well as the Protected Countryside Area of the Greenbelt, the City proposes an alternative route for the
pipeline. This alternative is a southerly route that is parallel and adjacent to the north limit of Highway 407
across much of the City.
TransCanada and the MTO have been evaluating the City’s proposal since October 2014 given its promise as a
reasonable alternative that avoids the ORM and the bisection of the UAE. By “bundling” the route with
Highway 407, development efficiencies can be achieved, land area constraints eliminated and the impacts of
the pipeline on the NHS reduced by half, since the southerly edge of the pipeline will be adjacent to the
highway rather than the NHS. As well, there is an opportunity to make use of the work undertaken as part of
the Highway 407 East extension environmental assessment to evaluate the impact of a pipeline adjacent to
and parallel to the same broad corridor. TransCanada has installed pipeline facilities in a freeway setting with
adjacent urban development elsewhere within the GTHA, including along Highway 407 across the north of
Toronto and in Peel and Halton Regions.

My grandson drinks the water in North Bay as does my son, my parents and myself. We must continue to
drink the pure water of Trout Lake in North Bay. Supplying bottled water with contaminants from the plastic
and lack of regulation for bottled water puts us all at risk. We must protect North Bay's drinking water. Trout
Lake is a source of drinking water and should never have been taken off the List of Protected Canadian Lakes.
In TC's application, it is stated that a small level of toluene and benzene is acceptable in our water. This can
be disputed with science. No amount of toxins or toxicants from a spill of dilbit--bitumen and diluents, or
dispersant chemical is at all acceptable due to the impact on our health in our communities.
In the TC's application, it is stated that the flow of Trout Lake goes away from the drinking intake pipe. There
is science claiming this is untrue.
Where is the health report with impacts?
Where is the study of spills of sinking dilbit in a lake deeper than the Vice President of Transcanada, Steve
said was possible to clean?
Where is the accountability when Transcanada put Trout Lake at dire straights with the huge silt
contamination?
There is little responsible, ethical regard for the impact a spill could have on our land, private or crown.
Where is a proper material data info sheet to help our first responders prepare?
Why hasn't the Health Unit been given this information?
Why and how can the federal government disregard the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and put
Canadian Citizens at dangerous risk in contaminating the drinking water by running toxins and toxicants
through Trout Lake?
How can the federal government trample my right to life by threatening my drinking water?
How can the federal government of Stephen Harper trample the hard won laws for source water protection
in Ontario?
I am impacted by the threat to my drinking water. So are my loved ones and my neighbors, friends and
community.

I am a North Bay small business owner and citizen of North Bay for the past 25 years and I live on Four Mile
Bay (Trout Lake). My home is within 500 meters of a major outlet creek and turtle sanctuary and 2.5
kilometers directly below the pipeline conversion route. This outlet creek has dozens of tributary sources all
flowing downhill from the pipeline, the elevation drop is close to 200 meters over the 2.5 Kilometers. Our
home is near to many other major creeks directly below the pipeline such as Four Mile Creek and dozens of
minor creeks leading directly into Four Mile Bay. My home's water intake is from Four Mile Bay. We live and
play on Four Mile Bay. My family and I bike, cross country ski and snowshoe on and around the pipeline route
throughout the year. We swim, paddle, sail and fish Four Mile Bay in the summer. I worry that a breach will
poison my source drinking water, devalue my property value enormously and make this little part of paradise
inhabitable. I have worked for years to be close to paying off my mortgage in order to live in this house. It is
valued at over $750,000.
There are hundreds of other properties on Four Mile Bay and even more on Trout Lake. What happens to the
city of North Bay and residents on these water bodies should a breach happen? A breach during spring break-
up and fall freeze up will be impossible to manage once it hits our lake and drinking water. This represents
about 10-12 weeks throughout the year. At the 2nd OEB hearing held on January 29th, 2015 a spokesman
said that TransCanada would supply drinking water to the city of North Bay, what complete arrogance and
white washing of the unmitigated disaster that a breach would create for this city.
If the project goes ahead, it places a sword of doom over the city of North Bay. As a result, I will close my
specialized manufacturing business and move to another city as will many others businesses. Who will invest
in this city? This project will kill North Bay, one of the most beautiful cities in Ontario. Personally, I have
nightmares about living within 2.5 kilometers downhill from 175,000,000 liters (1.1 million barrels) of diluted
bitumen flowing through an aging pipeline each and everyday. Our drinking water is at risk as is hundreds of
other water sources in this Province including Lake Superior. This is pure corporate greed over all else. It is
madness and it has to be stopped.

Letter of Comment
1. Pipeline to go through section presently rented to farmer to grow crops (approximately 20 acres in north
pasture/field)
2. Land would be rendered unusable during proposed construction of pipeline, should it be determined that
that is the final route of said pipeline
3. After pipeline has been laid and land returned to its agricultural basis, land could NOT be used for other
possible future considerations
4. Possible future considerations of land
a. At present land is zoned agricultural and being used as such
b. However it has always been our plan that that section (fronting Harmony R. N. ) would make a building lot
c. Two residential properties: one on the north; other on south of proposed pipeline route, already exist with
road frontage on Harmony Rd. and have been there for 28 years or more
d. These properties were sold off from original farm property prior to our acquisition of farm in 1985 (when
purchase was made—moved to farm in 1986)
5. With the impending completion of the 407ETR highway directly to the south of our residence (18.3 acres
were expropriated from our property to facilitate the construction of 407), and given the City of Oshawa’s
long range development plans for the area immediately south of the 407 and Winchester Rd., I anticipate the
eventual change from an agricultural area to a more urbanized environment
6. This parcel of land (where the proposed pipeline route lies) would be an ideal building lot for a country
residence
a. Putting a pipeline basically through the middle of this parcel severely compromises this plan, if not entirely
negating            it—meaning loss of potential income from the sale of said parcel, and/or possible construction
of a residence in my capacity as a builder and general contractor after required zoning changes—these are
long-range plans
b. Constructing a pipeline close between the two residential properties would not be an appropriate
placement of said pipeline
7. Other options to preferred route mapped out by Trans-Canada Pipeline Energy East:
a. Could the pipeline not continue north of Columbus Rd (Conc. 7)—north of said properties that front onto
Columbus Rd. so that their access to the road would not be affected, through what is mainly brush) instead
of coming down Wilson Rd. N. onto our property?
b. Along the 407 corridor?
c. Along the Hydro right-of-way?
d. Along the existing pipeline corridor south of Winchester Rd.?
8. The City of Oshawa would like to see another route for the pipeline, other than the one that is presently
being proposed
9. Were these other options seriously considered by Trans-Canada Pipeline, and if so, how seriously?
10. Should said pipeline, in spite of my objections, be determined to go through my property, what is the
compensation—simply the land, or would my future consideration of a building lot and/or building a
residence be compensated?

 1.     The need for the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
10. The engineering design and integrity of the Project
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
The Energy East project would have many important benefits to Canada, given various international
considerations of geopolitics and national energy security, as well as public safety of reliable pipelines versus
rail transport. North American energy independence in oil and natural gas is a critical issue for Canada that
can be addressed safely by such a domestic/export project. Apart from those positive aspects on Issue #1,
my specific comments below (on Issues # 7,10 and 13) are drawn from eleven years of my National Energy
Board experience in pipeline regulation and construction inspection (1980-91), as well as my next 22 years at
Environment Canada and the National Research Council on various Clean Energy topics.
In assessing the Canadian public interest, we knew from our field experience that the TCPL pipeline projects
were well built and designed for maximum reliability and safety, for sure during the 1980’s, likely later in the
1990's as well. As NEB technical staff, we had to balance that with critical reviews of some aspects of
additional costs involved in Class 1 and 3 Population Density Pipe replacements, dual river crossings, more
pipe loop vs compression, extra loop for compressor ‘Loss of Unit Protection’, and other extra items that we
judged to be sometimes not really necessary at that time.
My personal involvement included the initial North Bay Shortcut pipeline system, a high profile brand new
part of the TCPL system. This was one of the first major projects in North America using automatic welding
systems qualified by extensive testing in Winnipeg. Together with the new epoxy coatings, internal coatings,
weld inspection, hydrostatic testing, automatic valves, pipe pigging, and a high degree of construction
inspection with very good TCPL staff, I can attest that 1982-83 work on the 36" Line 1 was of high quality and
safety. I believe that the 1990’s 42” second line and compression additions were of similar or better quality.
Over the past 25 years I have also dealt with environmental and energy efficiency issues for various
industries. TransCanada’s balanced portfolio of natural gas, power and renewables has also contributed a lot
to Canada's cleaner energy systems. It has pioneered dozens of initiatives on gas compression,
environmental solutions for methane leakage, dry seals and gas transfer units, as well as power plant
efficiency, waste heat recovery CO2 reductions, and aero-derived engines with low NOx combustion. In
terms its carbon and air emission footprint and many future clean energy opportunities, there is an extensive
history of examples that can confidently support future safe and reliable gas-oil and pump station
conversions from Alberta to New Brunswick.
Short Bio; Manfred Klein is an energy & environment consultant, retired in 2013 after 33 years at the NEB,
Environment Canada and the National Research Council. With an Engineering degree from Carleton
University (1980), he has been involved in pipeline regulatory work, and federal policies and training with the
natural gas industry on environmental issues, industrial gas turbine and pipeline technologies, and
cogeneration systems.
