 1.     La nécessité du projet
2.     La faisabilité économique du projet
7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
11. Les effets éventuels du projet sur les intérêts des Autochtones
12. L’incidence possible du projet sur les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement touchés et sur leur
       utilisation des terres
Énergie Est pourrait générer 32 millions de tonnes de GES par année, soit l’équivalent
d’ajouter 7 millions de voitures sur les routes du Canada, une empreinte carbone plus
grande que celle des Maritimes (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE).
L’impact d’Énergie Est serait même plus important que celui du pipeline Keystone XL,
un autre projet de TransCanada que l’Agence de la Protection environnementale des
ÉtatsUnis a déterminé comme ayant un impact significatif sur la situation climatique.
L’Office national de l’énergie doit prendre en compte les impacts climatiques en amont,
car il n’existe aucun autre processus fédéral d’évaluation des impacts climatiques des
projets liés à l’énergie au Canada.
Les impacts d’Énergie Est sur le climat touchent à peu près toutes les problématiques
présentes dans la liste :
Si le Canada se joint à la communauté internationale pour lutter contre les
changements climatiques et limiter le réchauffement global à 2 degrés Celsius, le
besoin pour une infrastructure comme Énergie Est disparait en raison de la nécessité
de plafonner l’expansion des sables bitumineux ( http://bit.ly/14wgVB4 &
http://bit.ly/SccvIZ ).
La faisabilité économique est aussi liée aux changements climatiques, de par la relation à la bulle du carbone
et d’un bas prix du pétrole (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4).
Considérer les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques
potentiels du projet sans
prendre en compte les effets des changements climatiques comme impacts cumulatifs
est insensé dans la situation que nous vivons à l’heure actuelle à travers le monde.
Étant donné les conséquences des changements climatiques sur l’agriculture,
l’utilisation des terres et les modes de vie qui y sont liés, le projet aura des effets sur «
les intérêts des Autochtones » et sur « les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement
touchés ».
Pour toutes ces raisons, et parce que cette liste est loin d’être exhaustive, l’ONÉ doit
inclure les impacts d’Énergie Est sur le climat dans son évaluation. Échouer à le faire
équivaudrait pour les régulateurs à nier la responsabilité qu’ils ont envers les
Canadiens.

3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
7.     Safety and security during construction of the proposed project and operation of the project, including
       emergency response planning and third-party damage prevention.
Bitumen from the oil sands is heavy and requires toxic chemicals to dilute it. In 2010, a pipeline carrying
bitumen ruptured, flooding the Kalamazoo River in Michigan with 3.8 million litres of diluted bitumen.
Conventional clean-up methods have not worked and, despite almost $1 billion in clean-up costs, the river is
still polluted.
At the same time, there is evidence to suggest that it is not sufficient to leave environmental care in the
hands of the National Energy Board. Prior to the NEB’s approval of Enbridge’s Line 9b reversal, CTV’s W5
program found that the NEB only knew of seven spills along this pipeline, while Enbridge admitted to 13. In
fact, W5 discovered that the pipeline had a total of 35 spills, five times as much as the NEB indicated and
more than three times as much as Enbridge admitted.
In areas such as the Trout Lake watershed, these threats to source water contamination are unacceptable.
Trout Lake provides North Bay’s sole source of drinking water. It must be protected.
If we weigh the need to protect watersheds such as Trout Lake against the reality that the bitumen that
would flow through the Energy East pipeline would most likely be shipped, unrefined, to places like India,
Europe or possibly the United States, it becomes clear that this pipeline is not about needs in Canada but
profit. The value of protecting sole sources of drinking water far outweighs the value of profit-making.

I am directly affected by this Project as it passes through areas of Manitoba where I work and pursue
recreational activities such as swimming, hiking, canoeing, wildlife viewing and fishing.
I have lived in Manitoba most of my life and have a vested interest in these areas as a citizen of Canadian and
resident of Manitoba.
I work in Winnipeg and I have many friends and relations who live and work in Winnipeg and the surrounding
areas affected by the pipeline.
I am a professional biologist raised and educated in Manitoba and working as an environmental consultant. I
am certified as a Professional Biologist in Fisheries and Wildlife by Eco-Canada.
I have information and expertise that is valuable for the review of the Project as I have been practicing
biology in Manitoba since 1987 and I have been working as an environmental consultant since 2000. I have a
B.Sc. (4 year) from the University of Winnipeg in Biology (graduated 1998), and a MSc. from the University of
Manitoba in Zoology (graduated 2004).
My work has included conducting environmental assessments, construction monitoring and post-
construction monitoring for a number of oil and gas pipeline projects in Manitoba, Alberta and Siberia,
Russia. As such, I have first hand knowledge and expertise in the field studies, data collection, assessment
methodologies, regulatory requirements and monitoring requirements for the Environmental Assessment of
oil and gas pipeline projects.

I am a spatial analyst and forest ecologist with expertise in modeling the flow of contaminants into affected
watersheds. The pipeline route in New Brunswick traverses multiple watersheds of significant economic and
ecological importance. A thorough review of past spills is essential to predicting the likelihood and probable
severity of pipeline spills in these watersheds. Knowing the likely dynamic behaviour and extent of future
spills is essential to guage the economic and ecological impact of the pipeline.
My GIS and analytical expertise will shed light on these aspects of the project in New Brunswick to assist in
determining acceptable risk.
In addition I have been heavily involved in pressuring the New Brunswick Government to formally classify its
watersheds under the Water Classification Regulation of NB's Clean Water Act. The failure of the government
to properly enforce this regulation has been criticised by the provincial Ombudsman. The proper
enforcement of the regulation will have serious implications for the proposed pipeline. My experience with,
and knowledge of the Classification Regulation will faciltate my comments on the impact of spills within the
Nashwaak Watershed. Knowledge of the potential impact of spills will inform the government as to bonding

       Project

       and operations of the Project
Our organization represents thousands of members in the Ottawa area, including many who live along the
proposed pipeline route. Collectively, we have staff and members who are knowledgeable on environmental
issues, engineering, water issues in the Ottawa area, local ecology, as well as climate change.
The proposed project would see a tremendous amount of oil passing through the Ottawa area, passing
through a number of local watersheds, rivers, wetlands and over a number of aquifers, and we are concerned
for potential impacts on those areas and on the economic activity of people who live in those areas. There
are many concerns about the potentials for oil spills in the Ottawa area which could have dramatic and long-
lasting impacts on the local ecology and economy.
We also remain concerned about the projected increase in greenhouse gas emissions that is associated with
this project, which we consider to be of concern nationally both economically and environmentally, and
remains a concern of many of our members who would be impacted by such a growth in emissions.

The water coming out of my tap comes from Trout Lake, and I live within 200 feet of Lake Nipissing. There is
no alternative to fresh clean water. It is absolutely essential to protect the pristine waters of Trout Lake, the
source water for North Bay. Our entire community is put at risk by the proposed re-purposing of Energy East
Pipeline crossing through Trout Lake and threatening the watershed for both Trout Lake and Lake Nipissing.
Any rupture in the pipeline would devalue my property. In my letter I also intend to address the terms of
TransCanada approval.

 4. The apropriatness of tolling and methodology as it applies to the facilities, imperative to the project such
as (a) construction and operation and ownership of the on shore storage, on shore and attached piping
(laterals) and combined use of Canaport facilities, including pumping and shared use of monobouy facilities,
docking, onloading pipelines, and general operation of onshore equipment, personnel and safety. It would
appear that Irving Oil should also be listed as applicant, along with TCPL, particularly in terms of liability and
operational aspects related to tolls.
5. The end use of the product and the breakdown of separation of product for Canada refinery consumption
versus export, and the necessary proof of ownership of the product, who it is to be owned by, up and until
custody transfer to Irving or others.detailed ownership of the product and the toll of use of the facilities.
6. As above, with the contingent liability at every stage, and toll and taxation jurisdiction.
7.and 16. It is well known that accidents can happen. The major construction contractor and constructors in
particular, must be under contracts for individual liability for accidents and prevention. the numerous
contractors and subcontractors on this project,must adhere to all provisions of contract, including those
related to particular issues and responses to landowner and stakeholder requests and agreements, above
and beyond the technical and engineering requirements. In other Energy Board jurisdictions a lands relations
agent is required, for example, by a one line sentence in a Board order that requires the Company to provide
independent oversight and communication, day to day on landowner and stakeholder issues, during
construction, on clean up and to full and final releases. My expertise relates to over 30 years as a professional
land agent, and right of way supervisor, for numerous pipeline projects including those under NEB
jurisdiction.
8. and 9. There is no reference to potential alternates to the route; one possible potential is to change the
portion from Hampton to Evandale and to the west side of Saint John(Lorneville) and to an industrial
property already expropriated and owned by the City, and permitted for a terminal location, well removed
from the residential areas of Hampton and east Saint John. The area is large enough to include all the
facilities as well as construction yard pipe offloading and infrastructure, and would avoid major traffic in the
City. The use of this same location for an export terminal would reduce the impact of increased tanker traffic,
at the port entrance,in the Bay of fundy.

 I am directly effected by this project at both my permanent residence is south Winnipeg (along Red River) 5
km north of the pipeline and most directly at my cottage on the north shore of Falcon Lake that will be my
future permanent residence in 2017. My 4 season cottage at Block 4 Lot 5 Falcon Lake is one of the closest
cottages to TransCanada Line 1 (40 meters south of the pipeline) between Faloma and Toniata on the north
shore of Falcon Lake. The TransCanada pipeline #4 that is proposed to be re-purposed for Dilbit is also very
close to my cottage lot (1.35 km). I walk, cross-country ski, and bike on both of these pipelines on a regular
basis. I am very familiar with the topography and location of both of these pipelines for a 5-10km section
both east and west of my cottage.
I have information and expertise that I think is valuable to the NEB.
1. I am a director on the board of the Whiteshell Trail Association and have been directly involved in the site
location and development of 100 km of hiking/biking/skiing trails in the south Whiteshell that cross both
pipelines at several locations. Our association works directly with Trails Manitoba and TransCanada Trail
Association
2. I have a Masters of Science degree in Environmental Biology from the University of Guelph (1981) and a
BSc in Agricultural Plant Science from University of Manitoba (1979).
3. I worked as a senior research scientist for Dow AgroSciences for 31 years throughout southern Manitoba
and Saskatchewan.
4. I am most interested in contributing knowledge about pipeline safe guards and environmental risks of
pipeline breaches.
5. As a research scientist I have valuable analytical and fact based objectivity skills that I would like to
contribute to the NEB evaluation of this project.

I am an individual living in a community (North Bay) where TCPL proposes to convert an existing and aging
natural gas pipeline to carry diluted bitumen. The pipeline runs very close to Trout Lake (our municipalities
sources of drinking water) and at one point runs under the lake. In addition the pipeline crosses source water
that leads into the other large lake in our municipality, Lake Nipissing. The company is asking us to trust
them but their track record is less than stellar as a review of the Transportation Safety board record soon
points out. In addition, the company has been less than forth coming in explaining how it intends to clean
up a spill in our lake system should it occur. If they ruin our Lake(s) they ruin our City. Not only will this
community of 55,000 be without its source of potable drinking water but we may very well lose our tourist
industry - one of the basic components of our economic life here in the north

 I live in the community of Fort Richmond in the south end of Winnipeg, very close to the Red River, which I
cross twice ever day to get to and from work. During the summer I get much of my food from Aurora Farm in
the adjacent community of St.Norbert. I actually cross over the existing gas pipeline on my way to pick up
groceries there. I enjoy the many waterways in my area including the La Salle River which runs through the
nearby La Barriere Park. The following risks exist for all Winnipegers and absolutely makes me a directly
affected person.
1) risk of fire and explosion exacerbated by the nearby parallel natural gas lines
2) sulphur and hydrogen sulphide (H2S) in the line – hydrogen sulphide will corrode the line internally and eat
its way out. It is a deadly toxic gas.
3) the extensive failure history of TransCanada’s lines in Canada
4) TransCanada PipeLines is relying solely on uncertain and infrequent inspection using “smart pigs” and
ineffective pressure monitoring from Edmonton to prevent failures
5) unappreciated risk to drinking water of many communities and of two major aquifers, the Assiniboine
Delta and the Sandilands Aquifer
6) extensive drainage into the LaSalle and Seine Rivers near Winnipeg that extend the spill reach far beyond
city boundaries and render ineffective shut-off valve protection
7) evacuation risk from toxic fumes from a dilbit spill
8) expense and extreme difficulty of cleaning up dilbit spills as experienced in the Kalamazoo spill – the
bitumen portion sinks
9) long term ecological damage and contamination of the food chain
10) liability issues relating in particular to compensation claims and the fact that bill C-46 extending liability
protection for pipeline spills is not yet passed and that the EnergyEast subsidiary bears the spill liability not
TransCanada PipeLines
Also, The climate impacts of Energy East will affect nearly every issue on the list of issues: If Canada joins the
world in taking meaningful action to limit global warming to 2 degree Celsius there will be no proven need for
Energy East as tar sands expansion will need to be capped.
The economic feasibility of the project is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble
and the low price of oil.
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and on ways of life.
For these reasons the NEB needs to include climate change in its review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an
abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across Canada.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
I am applying to submit a letter of comment on the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of
the Energy East project. I am doing so as (1.) someone directly affected by it, and (2.) as an expert willing to
provide an ethical analysis to the National Energy Board of the Application. I believe both perspectives would
be helpful in the Board’s deliberations.
(1.) As someone directly affected: -
I am a citizen of North Bay, Ontario. After two years of following studies by different organizations, including
the material published by the Proponent, of the possibility of a spill of dilbit or other crude oil product into
Trout Lake, our city’s water supply, I regard the risk as seriously high during the lifetime of this particular
project. Any such event would dramatically compromise my personal drinking water supply and that of over
54,000 others.
Though a liability fund is proposed in the event of a spill, previous history of realizing a total financial
recovery from such accidents is not encouraging. In addition to the social trauma of such an event, as many
past pipeline spills have demonstrated, every citizen like myself would be subject to significant upheaval and
stress as well as possible major additional - and more obscure - costs. A spill that badly damaged
infrastructure or water quality would cause major harm to our civic economy. As a fellow citizen declared at
a local OEB hearing, “You ruin our lake, you ruin our city.”
(2.) As a person with expertise: -
I am a retired General Secretary (CEO) of The United Church of Canada, the nation’s largest Protestant
denomination. Regularly, that role involved assisting the institution itself and related organizations in seeking
a solid ethical foundation for policies and practices. Such criteria have been used both in terms of supporting
developmental work overseas as well as for programs and projects here in Canada.
One of the important challenges that lies ahead of TransCanada and the Board itself is achieving the trust of
the constituency most directly affected. The NEB’s list of responsibilities acknowledges the importance “of
social considerations in [its] decision-making process” and declares “The Canadian public expects us to hold
companies we regulate accountable for the safe operation of NEB-regulated energy infrastructures.” The
expertise I am able to offer the NEB in its evaluation of the Energy East application is to provide a way of
assessing the Applicant’s submission using criteria that would evaluate the level of ethical integrity
supporting this initiative.

1.     The need for the Project
2.     The economic feasibility of the Project
9.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the Project
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year, the
same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads, and greater than the climate footprint of an Atlantic
province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE). This is also 10 million tonnes per year greater than the Keystone XL pipeline,
which the United States Environmental Protection Agency has determined to have a significant impact on
climate change. The National Energy Board needs to take the climate impacts of Energy East into
consideration as there is no other federal review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East will affect nearly every issue on the list of issues:
If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit global warming to 2 degree Celsius there will be
no proven need for Energy East as tar sands expansion will need to be capped (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
The economic feasibility of the project is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble
and the low price of oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and on ways of life.
For these reasons the NEB needs to include climate change in its review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an
abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across Canada.
I also have a personal interest in that I live on the banks of the Red River and could face serious health risks
and financial losses if a spill occurred.

As stakeholders in the Eastern Mainline Project, we are gravely concerned about the process that has been
followed by the Trans Canada Pipeline (TCP) people. Delay and stall tactics have been practiced and
compliance with the NEB Act has not been followed. This has not only affected us, but our neighbours as
well. (Evidence to be sent in)
The existing route would literally cut our land in half. As landowners, we have future plans for our land and
cutting it in half would have a severe impact and consequences for our personal future. In trying to work
with the TCP we have offered several suggestions for a revised route and we have made numerous attempts
to obtain information about revised plans and maps but no new proposed route map has been sent to us yet
nor do we see any evidence of a route change for our property on the websites.
If we do not have the opportunity to be included in the Public Hearings, we would be unheard and the TCP
would have another opportunity to move forward with the heavy handed techniques that they have used
and tactics that they have employed to operate other than in good faith. One unnecessary delay after
another, as well as lack of information has left us with no other option but to ask to be included in the
hearing in order to voice our concerns.

 As a concerned Canadian, not just for our present society, but for Canadians in the generations to come, I feel
our real need is to quickly diversify our sources of energy, not to ever-more aggressively extract this one
source for the benefit of the present list of oil companies.
The aim of oil companies is to get their product to tidewater and to overseas markets where the oil would
command higher prices than present circumstances allow. The companies are doing this for themselves and
their investors, as companies all do and should, but not for Canada. Most of the big companies aren’t
Canadian. If they wanted to build this for Canadians why did they first propose to pipe out their dilbit by
way of Keystone? And if they don’t get approval for this EE proposal, why are they saying they will next try to
get it out through Alaska?
The environmental risks of spills along the route are significant when considered over the course of the
decades ahead. Much of the pipe is already 40 years old. Under pressure at 1000 psi, the chance that
ruptures at points along the route will occur in the next 40 years is certain. Slight drops in pressure and slow
leaks won’t easily be detected back in Calgary, and major damage can occur before detection. A break in the
line by the Rideau River near my home in Ottawa would have devastating and long-lasting consequences to
my city. Seepage into the Oxford-Mills aquifer at our south end of Ottawa would destroy drinking water
sources for thousands of people.
  TransCanada reports that in the 7-year building phase they will employ 13, 690 workers, and in the 20 years
of operation after that, they would be employing 3,273 people. Clearly, TransCanada’s contribution to jobs
is but a ‘drop in the oil bucket’. Further, the jobs they support in the building phase will be jobs requiring
certain skills such as welding, big machine operators, and others. These will be jobs that are taken away from
other parts of our job market, thus not making much difference to our overall unemployment rate. When we
take into account the amount of money that will have to go into paying for the damages caused by oil spills
and climate change in the years ahead, the revenues generated from this project are far outweighed by such
expenses.
I feel that all Canadians are directly affected by this proposed pipeline expansion because of the climate
impact. We can’t divide the environment into different parts and consider them in isolation. There’s been
an effort to say that isolated economic benefits for people along the route mean a benefit for all Canadians,
but that negative impacts can only be considered by local stakeholders even if everyone’s taxes help pay the
expenses incurred when problems occur. Climate change directly affects us all and should be a part of this
discussion.
Thank you for considering these perspectives.

1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.
2.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the proposed project.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
7.     Safety and security during construction of the proposed project and operation of the project, including
       emergency response planning and third-party damage prevention.
Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year, the
same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads, and greater than the climate footprint of an Atlantic
province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE). This is also 10 million tonnes per year greater than the Keystone XL pipeline,
which the United States Environmental Protection Agency has determined to have a significant impact on
climate change. The National Energy Board needs to take the climate impacts of Energy East into
consideration as there is no other federal review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East will affect nearly every issue on the list of issues:
If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit global warming to 2 degree Celsius there will be
no proven need for Energy East as tar sands expansion will need to be capped (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
The economic feasibility of the project is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble
and the low price of oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and on ways of life.
For these reasons the NEB needs to include climate change in its review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an
abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across Canada.
I am also personally affected in that I live along the Red River and could be seriously affected, both health
wise and financially, if a spill occurred.

 The Friends of Temagami (“FOT”) was founded in 1995. In 2007 it amalgamated with the Friends of Chiniguchi
and the Nastawgan Network to form a single voice for the Temagami Region. FOT represents hundreds of
outdoor enthusiasts for whom Temagami has become a second (or in some cases first) home. Our members
are passionate about the promotion of the Temagami experience, and the protection of the land for future
generations. FOT is thus directly affected by the proposal to pump heavy crude oil trough the heart of
Temagami.
The proposed Energy East project would run through the heart of Temagami, one of North America’s most
popular canoeing, cottaging, and eco-tourism areas. Thousands of wilderness enthusiasts from all over the
world flock to the region every year to explore its rugged landscape of rocky shores, old-growth red and
white pine, waterfalls, high elevations, and the vast network of nastawgan — the ancient portages and routes
by lake and river — opened by the Temagami Anishnabe.
FOT has acquired intimate knowledge of Temagami’s recreational, cultural, and ecological values through its
decades of conservation work. For example, FOT developed and produced the most detailed and
comprehensive maps of the Temagami area available today, and engages in regular maintenance of
backcountry trails, portage and campsites. It is thus uniquely placed to inform the NEB regarding how the oil
pipeline, and any oil spill, would affect these values. Where additional expert information is required, for
example regarding biological and economic issues, FOT is committed to assisting the NEB by retaining
appropriate experts, with resources under the participant funding program.
FOT will address, though its own knowledge and with the assistance of experts, the following effects of the
project on Temagami, which are considered in the Environmental Assessment Act, 2012:
the land, water, air, flora, fauna, and interactions between them;
the fish and fish habitat;
migratory birds;
health and socio-economic conditions, including the local ecotourism industry;
physical and cultural heritage, including with respect to aboriginal peoples; and
structures and sites of historical and archaeological significance, including with respect to aboriginal peoples.
FOT will inform the NEB regarding the unique nature of the environment through and around which the
pipeline runs, and will address the appropriateness of routing heavy crude oil through such areas. FOT is
prepared to provide detailed information about the waterways and forested areas through which the
pipeline runs, and to explain the economic and cultural uses of these areas, with reference to the Temagami
Land Use Plan (“TLUP”) and other regulations governing the uses of land in the Temagami area. FOT will
evaluate for the NEB whether an oil pipeline conforms with such designated uses, and with the continued
preservation of unique ecosystems.
In addition, FOT is participating in a broader collaborative effort among several northeastern Ontario
intervenors which will allow synthesis and integration at a regional level. Partners in the Intervention
Coalition are groups who wish to work collaboratively with other northeastern Ontario based organizations,
and share responsibility for hearing filings.

Whereas TransCanada Pipelines has submitted an application for the Energy East Oil Pipeline Project to the
National Energy Board (NEB); the Municipality of Temagami wishes to participate as a commenter.
The Municipality feels it meets the requirements for commenter status as per the following:
The Energy East project will run approximately 60 Km through the Municipality of Temagami from Best
Township in the north to Sisk Township in the south. The existing right of way passes through the urban
Neighborhood of Temagami South in close proximity to commercial and residential properties.
The Temagami North water supply comes from Net Lake with its intake being downstream from the Existing
Trans Canada Pipeline crossing.
Further Temagami has long been a destination for those seeking the wilderness experience. Local outfitters
and Tourist operators rely on Temagami’s pristine landscape for their livelihood. The pipeline crosses
numerous streams, rivers and lakes in Temagami, many of which have full time and seasonal residents that
are impacted by the conversion of the pipeline.
Therefore the Municipality of Temagami wishes to participate in the hearing process to ensure that the safety
of its residents and their livelihoods are protected.

En vertu de leur mandat légal (article 373 de la Loi sur les services de santé et les services sociaux, L.R.Q., c.
S-4.2), les directions de santé publique (DSP) ont pour responsabilité d'informer la population des principaux
facteurs de risque, d’identifier les situations susceptibles de mettre en danger la santé de la population et de
voir à la mise en place des mesures nécessaires à sa protection. Conséquemment, les DSP sont appelées
régulièrement à émettre leurs recommandations dans le cadre du processus québécois d’évaluation et
d’examen des impacts sur l’environnement examinant des projets énergétiques et industriels.
Au Québec, le projet Oléoduc Énergie Est soulève plusieurs défis sociaux et environnementaux, tout
particulièrement dans les régions qui seront traversées par le tracé du tronçon principal du pipeline
(Montérégie, Laurentides, Lanaudière, Mauricie-Centre-du-Québec, Capitale-Nationale, Chaudière-
Appalaches et Bas-Saint-Laurent) et le tracé d’un tronçon latéral (Laval et Montréal). Dans ce contexte, les
DSP des régions concernées ont travaillé de concert à l’analyse du projet. Elles souhaitent alimenter la
réflexion de l’ONÉ, sur la base d’un cadre de gestion des risques pour la santé appliqué au projet à l’étude.
Concrètement, les DSP souhaitent faire part de leurs recommandations en matière de santé publique à
l’ONÉ. Ces recommandations viseront notamment à garantir que le projet réponde à des exigences de
réduction des impacts potentiels pour la santé de la population en s’assurant de l’adéquation des mesures de
prévention et d’intervention. Notre mémoire portera donc sur plusieurs enjeux de santé publique en lien
avec les questions soumises par l’ONÉ, dont :
• la qualité de l’air, incluant la production de gaz à effet de serre ;
• la qualité de l’eau ;
• le climat sonore et la qualité de vie ;
• les aspects psychologiques et sociaux, notamment pour les propriétaires fonciers directement touchés ;
• la gestion des risques d’accidents et de défaillances, incluant les plans de mesures d’urgence ;
• les impacts temporaires.

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.

The Eastern mainline will be travelling directly through our Traditonal and Treaty Territory.(The Williams
Treaties Territory) All First Nations have a unique and compassionate connection with Mother Earth and the
blood of Mother Earth (the water) is very sacred to us. We have been given the job of caretaker for Mother
Earth and protector of our environment. Our concerns are therefore directed to the harmful effects this may
have on our traditions(hunting, fishing and gathering) if and when there is a malfunction or accident, as the
damage could be irreversible to our land, flora, fauna and water. Our traditional ways are derived from the
land and need to be respected and preserved for future generations. Development and settlement has
already altered our use and occupancy of the natural resources as well as our land and water. Our way of life
has been dramatically impacted and our livelihood, health, spirituality and overall quality of life affected by
ongoing development of our traditional lands. We have witnessed first hand the damage that can be caused
by ruptured pipelines on First Nation lands and the minimal efforts taken to rehabilitate the environment,
dead and poisoned wildlife and waterways back to a healthy state of well being. We must ensure that every
possible step and safeguard is being taken to ensure these disasters do not reoccur and that those
responsible are held accountable for the ongoing protection of Mother Earth. Our children's future must be a
priority so that they can continue to cultivate the bounties of the land, prosper in a clean air environment
and flourish with an abundance of healthy waterways, essential to our tradittional way of life and survival.

9.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet
L'Organisme de bassin versant du fleuve Saint-Jean (OBVFSJ) est un OBNL indépendant mandaté par le
Gouvernement du Québec pour mettre en oeuvre la gestion intégrée de l'eau dans le bassin versant qui lui
est désigné. Dans le cas présent, il s'agit de la portion Québécoise du bassin versant du fleuve Saint-Jean qui
est, dans son ensemble, partagé avec le Nouveau-Brunswick et le Maine aux É.-U. Les membres de la table de
concertation de l'OBVFSJ, en provenance des secteurs économique, municipal, communautaire et
autochtone, travaillent à prioriser les enjeux de l'eau et des écosystèmes aquatiques, et mettre en oeuvre un
plan d'action visant à pallier aux problématiques soulevées. Le tout afin de veiller au maintien de la qualité de
l'eau et des écosystèmes aquatiques dans une perspective de développement durable.
Dans ce contexte, le tracé de l'oléoduc Énergie Est, dans les limites de notre bassin versant, sera analysé et
mis en relation avec les autres usages du territoire reliés à l'eau afin d'identifier les situations conflictuelles
possibles. L'Organisme centralise une somme d'informations sur les cours d'eau traversés, l'utilisation de
l'eau à proximité et dispose du savoir local de sa table de concertation afin d'avoir une vue élargie du projet
et de ses impacts sur le bassin versant et ainsi affiner les recommandations qu'il pourra faire.
Le document que l'Organisme préparera pour l'ONÉ contiendra ses recommandations précises concernant le
tracé de l'oléoduc dans le bassin versant, sur les aspects reliés à la protection de l'eau, des espèces fauniques
et des milieux naturels à proximité. Il mettra également le projet en relation avec les autres usages de l'eau et
pourra proposer des alternatives au tracé ou à la localisation de valves de sectionnement, ou tout autre
élément qui feront consensus auprès des membres de la table de concertation et qui seront reliées aux 2
questions sélectionnées dans la liste de questions.

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.
2.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the proposed project.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
4.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on Aboriginal interests.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
I am a landowner with a home and a camp that are both directly adjacent to waterways that will be
negatively impacted by a pipeline leak. In addition to the ecological damage done by a pipeline leak, the
value of my property will be adversely affected by not only an actual pipeline leak, but by the fact that my
property is located where it will always be under the threat of being affected by future pipeline leaks or spills.
Outside of my own personal concerns, I am also a naturalist, photographer, writer and the editor of a local
newspaper. I hike through the woods, fish the brooks and kayak on local waterways. I am extremely
concerned about the effects a pipeline leak will have on these waterways, the regional wildlife and the local
economy.
Our village on the St John River hosts several bass tournaments every year. As 6 of the more than 300
waterways in NB that the pipeline will cross in this province are major tributaries into the St John River, a spill
anywhere near those tributaries will despoil this river for sports fishing and all other recreational uses, and
thus drive away tourists and visitors for many, many years after the event.
Pipeline leaks and spills always negatively impact the health of local residents. The provincial health system is
stretched financially. The additional strain that will come from people suffering from many of the ills
associated with pipeline leaks will further devastate rural communities and their health care options.
A pipeline spill will cause irreversible environmental damage wherever it occurs, yet there will be no
significant benefit to any communities from the pipeline project in terms of jobs or economic development.
This pipeline is for export, and so will primarily feed corporate profits rather than provide benefits to the
people of New Brunswick.
A pipeline through this province is a disaster waiting to happen, and when it does the cascade of effects will
wreck the water, the health of humans, livestock and all animals, destroy tourism, ruin agricultural land and
poison the air with noxious fumes.
A sustainable and abundant human society is what we should be striving towards, and it is possible. But we
need to move away from our archaic dependence on fossil fuels. It is now the time to look to a world of the
future that is powered by clean, green and renewable energy and fuels.

 I am a Mom, an Aunt, and a life long citizen of Canada. I live in a city where water surrounds us everywhere.
I was the Executive Director of the Lake Winnipeg Foundation and I therefore very much understand the
movement of water and the definition of a watershed. I have been educated further on this issue by highly
educated Scientists and am aware that a spill or explosion could absolutely affect all of Winnipeg. My sister
works on a farm in St. Norbert and we get our food from there as much as possible throughout the year. My
parents live along the river in Fort Garry. We canoe, enjoy walks, and simply adore the water that surrounds
us. The following risks exist for all Winnipegers and absolutely make my family and I Directly Affected
persons.
1) risk of fire and explosion exacerbated by the nearby parallel natural gas lines
2) sulphur and hydrogen sulphide (H2S) in the line – hydrogen sulphide will corrode the line internally and eat
its way out. It is a deadly toxic gas.
3) the extensive failure history of TC lines in Canada
4) TC is relying solely on uncertain and infrequent inspection using “smart pigs” and ineffective pressure
monitoring from Edmonton to prevent failures
5) unappreciated risk to drinking water of many communities and of two major aquifers, the Assiniboine
Delta and the Sandilands Aquifer
6) extensive drainage into the LaSalle and Seine Rivers near Winnipeg that extend the spill reach far beyond
city boundaries and render ineffective shut-off valve protection
7) evacuation risk from toxic fumes from a dilbit spill
8) expense and extreme difficulty of cleaning up dilbit spills as experienced in the Kalamazoo spill – the
bitumen portion sinks
9) long term ecological damage and contamination of the food chain
10) liability issues relating in particular to compensation claims and the fact that bill C-46 extending liability
protection for pipeline spills is not yet passed and that the EE subsidiary bears the spill liability not TC
Also, The climate impacts of Energy East will affect nearly every issue on the list of issues:
If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit global warming to 2 degree Celsius there will be
no proven need for Energy East as tar sands expansion will need to be capped
The economic feasibility of the project is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble
and the low price of oil
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and on ways of life.
For these reasons the NEB needs to include climate change in its review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an
abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across Canada.

 The Energy East pipeline project will directly affect the City of Kenora, located in the Lake of the Woods
watershed in northwestern Ontario. The TransCanada Canadian Mainline traverses the City from west to
east, making several water crossings close to and within the City boundaries. Within the City environs there
are landowners and residents directly affected by the project, as the line passes through several residential
neighbourhoods. The pipeline is in close proximity to community schools and other community facilities.
Further, Municipal Councillors under the Safe Drinking Water Act 2002, section 19, can be held liable in the
event of a failure to protect source drinking water. A failure of the proposed oil pipeline in the Lake of the
Woods watershed would pose a major threat to those relying on the Lake of the Woods as a source for their
drinking water, including the City of Kenora.
Following discussions, City Council has stated its intention to undertake community consultation, facilitated
by an independent and neutral facilitator to ensure that the process will allow for the expression of
comments either pro or con. The City wishes to apply for status with the NEB to submit the comments
received.
The purpose of the consultation will be to provide residents the opportunity to comment on environmental
and health and safety risks associated with a spill anywhere within Kenora’s watershed (NEB Issues #7, 12, 13,
14), and impacts on neighbouring First nation communities (Issue #11). As the economy of our community
and surrounding area is dependent upon natural resources, comments will also likely include impacts to the
local economy (Issue #3) and the importance of the watershed to the City’s economy, tourism and recreation.
The City recognizes the agency of Aboriginal groups and landowners to pursue self-representation before the
NEB; it is our intent to share information. For those who may participate in the City consultation meetings,
we will ensure that their comments are submitted (Issue #12).
Because of the number of water crossings and the route of the pipe line through parts of the City, adequate
shutoff procedures, contingency plans and determination of financial responsibility in the event of spills,
accidents or malfunctions needs to be in place. The residents will be provided the opportunity to further
question/comment on these areas which are of importance to the Municipality. Namely, assurances from
NEB that Trans Canada will have detailed safety and emergency response plans; documented contingency
plans are in place and; that a financial plan is in place to address the costs associated with any spills,
accidents or malfunctions as a result of the project. The integrity of this project must be addressed to the
satisfaction of the City. (Issues #13, 14, 15)
It is the intent to work in conjunction with community, municipal governments, First Nations and Regional
Organizations in the sharing of information. This will be undertaken via the Environmental Advisory
committee of Council.

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental

12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
Forty years ago, encouraged by the City of Saint John, and assisted by CMHC, my neighbours and I came to
this community, and built our homes ourselves, some with hand tools, since there was no electricity to begin
with. We have lived and worked in this community, paid our property taxes, and our water and sewer rates
for the past 40 years, raised and educated our families, and expected to live here in our retirement and leave
our homes, our major investment, to our children and grandchildren.
Instead, our plans and dreams are being destroyed by someone else's plans for the Energy East pipeline and
terminal. Plans are being made that we feel will be detrimental to us and our community without our input or
consent.
At a meeting of the Red Head Community Association we learned from our neighbours that agents of
TransCanada Pipeline had been going to peoples' homes to speak to them, had refused to meet with more
than one homeowner at a time, had been telling different people different things, and had been acting in a
manner that made people feel threatened and intimidated.
We also learned that parts of our stable, well-maintained residential community were being rezoned heavy
industrial without our input or consent. One neighbour had applied to the city for a permit to build a house
for his daughter behind his own and his son's homes on residentially zoned land that had been in his family
for many years, but was denied a permit, and his appeal was denied, although others in other parts of the
city were accomodated.
Following the meeting,some of us wrote or called city councillors without satisfactory results, and some
attended a city council meeting and were surprised they were not allowed to speak about their concerns, and
were threatened with expulsion from the council meeting by the mayor.
Over the past year or so, I have been renovating my house so that my daughter can move here with her
children, where the air is better than East Saint John, and the children will have more room and a safer,
healthier community to play in. However, I have learned that emissions from the pipeline and terminal will be
harmful to my grandchildren.
We feel the TransCanada agents lurking around our community have already lowered our property values,
made happy neighbours sad and angry and affected our sleep, our stomachs, and our blood pressures.The
communities here are healthy stable safe communities in a beautiful seaside area, an asset any city would
want to protect. They should not be destroyed to prolong a dying industry.

 3.     The commercial, economic, supply and market impacts of the Project
As the economic development agency, Ignite Fredericton, represents the employment and commercial
impact potential of the Energy East Project. As one of the largest communities located within the general
service and logistics area for the pipeline our communities stand to benefit from design, construction, and
operational economic streams. Our intent is to be a commentor supporting this initiative and the economic
development impacts to our region and province.
Currently our community represents both business and academia interests that have natural resources as a
foundational component of our GDP. With more than 5000 employees sustained by direct and indirect work
in this sector it is critical to have mega-projects such as this proceed. As lead organization we have formed a
Natural Resources Task Force to ensure that we maximize opportunities with in this sector. Not only is the
project itself a direct opportunity but the legacy of experience and skills will give us an additional exportable
service globally.
Our comments and submissions will address these opportunities and the positive outcome to employment,
export, and our regional GDP.

 2.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the proposed project.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
7.     Safety and security during construction of the proposed project and operation of the project, including
       emergency response planning and third-party damage prevention.
8.     The ability to finance the proposed project
9.     The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue.
2 the land purposed for the new easement seems excessive. The first purposed route was totally
unacceptable and land wasteful. Further work can and needs to be done in this aspect.
3 concerns exist about soil disturbance and soil integrity on completion. Soil profiling needs to be done prior
to construction and soils removed and separated in three separate lifts. An agronomist needs to be present
to ensure these protocols are adhered to and given authority to stop work if these protocols are not adhered
to. It is impossible to unscramble an egg or restructure soil once destroyed. Google maps shows a distinct
outline showing the previous pipe restructuring dig.
Depth of cover, Modern ag practices shows a benefit to deeper tillage allowing more vertical water drainage
as well as fertility benefits. Pipe not buried deep enough is a risk to all and a determent to our ability to
achieve yield potential from our land.
6 At present drains on the north side of the pipeline do not function as they should since the last dig. This
needs to be rectified in this contract. In the case of a spill at any time per or post construction it is a concern
to me that these same tiles could be an express conduit for the migration of unwanted material from the
pipeline leak (or pump station adjacent) to impact a much bigger area in an accelerated rate. An agreed
contingency plan would benefit all concerned.
7 posting all emergency numbers on site with clear location directions as well as notification to fire police and
EMS at the start of each day would greatly help 911 challenged operators find or send help to remote off
road areas.
8 ability to finance a landowners worst nightmare would be the abandonment of a construction site
unfinished. Provisions should be made to avoid this download to any landowner.
9 it would be appreciated for the NEB to include in any terms recommendations and conditions to be in any
approval the Board may issue, including conditions and protocols for communication. There can be no quality
cooperation without timely communication.

11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
The Energy East pipeline runs through my community and if a spill occurs it could threaten waterways close
to areas where my child regularly plays, namely the home of his grandparents. I am concerned about spills in
the area and Trans Canada's safety record to date. I am also concerned about the ramifications of utilizing old
pipeline infrastructure that was not designed to pump bitumen. I am also concerned about the overall
climate impacts.
Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year - the
same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads and larger than the climate footprint of an Atlantic
province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE). Energy East’s impact is also larger than the Keystone XL pipeline which the
United States Environmental Protection Agency just determined to have a significant impact on climate
change. The National Energy Board needs to take the upstream climate impacts of Energy East into effect
because there is no other federal review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East impact nearly every issue already on the list of issues:
• If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit warming to 2 degree Celsius there is no proven
need for Energy East as tar sands expansion must be capped (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4 & http://bit.ly/SccvIZ)
• The economic feasibility is also linked to climate change, especially in relation to the carbon bubble & the
low price of oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
• To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
• There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly
affected landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on
traditional indigenous land use and ways of life and much more.
For these reasons and so many more related to climate change the NEB needs to include climate change in
it’s review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across
Canada.

9.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the Project
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use

       the Project
As a stakeholder for the Eastern Mainline Project, we are gravely concerned about the process that has been
followed by the Trans Canada Pipeline (TCP) people. Delay and stall tactics have been practiced and
compliance with the NEB Act as not been followed. This has not only affected us, but our neighbours as well.
(Evidence to be sent in)
The existing route would be literally cut our land in half. As landowners, we have future plans for our land
and cutting it in half would have a severe impact and consequences for our personal future. In trying to work
with the TCP we have offered several suggestions for a revised route and we have made numerous attempts
to obtain information about revised plans and maps but no new proposed route map has been sent to us yet
nor do we see any evidence of a route change for our property on the websites of either NEW or TCP. The
new route for the Eastern Mainline Project is necessary in order to convert the existing lines and will
adversely affect us. We are opposing the existing suggested route of the new line and want to be heard at a
Public Hearing. We have displayed to the TCP that there are alternatives that can be used but still do not
have any concrete route proposal changes.
If we do not have the opportunity to be included in the Public Hearings, we would be unheard and the TCP
would have another opportunity to move forward with the heavy handed techniques that they have used
and tactics that they have employed to operate other than in good faith. One unnecessary delay after
another, as well as lack of information, has left us with no other option but to ask to be included in the
hearing in order to voice our concerns.

 3.     Les effets du projet sur les échanges commerciaux, l’économie, l’approvisionnement et le marché
9.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet
12. L’incidence possible du projet sur les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement touchés et sur leur
       utilisation des terres
13. La sécurité et la sûreté associées à la construction et à l’exploitation du projet, y compris la planification
       de l’intervention d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés par des tiers

       travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
15. Les répercussions financières de la planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement,
       d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
16. Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office à l’égard du
       projet
Le Forum Énergie Est de la Vallée est épaulé par la Chambre de commerce de la Vallée et inclut également un
représentant de chacune des municipalités qu’elle dessert, soit Grand-Sault, Saint-André, Drummond Saint-
Léonard, et également des gens d’affaires de la région. Le forum a été créé l’an dernier pour offrir une voix à
nos membres ainsi qu’au public en général concernant le projet d’Énergie Est.
Nous desservons une population d’environ 15 000 personnes et nous sommes situé au long de la vallée de la
rivière Saint-Jean dans le nord-ouest du Nouveau-Brunswick. Nous y retrouvons plusieurs secteurs d’activités
commerciales et industrielles. Nous retrouvons également une forte présence d’agriculture dans nos régions.
Le tracé proposé par le Projet Énergie Est passe à proximité des communautés représentées par le Forum et
sur les frontières de la Communauté Rurale de Saint-André. Cette même municipalité a été identifiée parmi
l’une des destinations pour une station de pompage. De plus, la municipalité de Saint-Léonard va avoir un
camp de construction pour recevoir environ 2 000 travailleurs lors de la construction du projet.
Donc, comme vous pouvez bien le constater, les membres du Forum, ainsi que les gens qu’il représente ont
intérêt à plusieurs aspects énumérés par l’Office dans le processus de réglementation.
Nos membres ont intérêt au niveau de l’utilisation des propriétés foncières à l’égard de l’emplacement du
pipeline, station de pompage, camp de construction ainsi que les propriétés affectées lors de la construction
du pipeline.
Nos municipalités qui font partie du forum ont également un intérêt direct au niveau de la planification des
intervenants d’urgence, les coûts qui s’y rattachent et l’administration des services d’urgence déjà en place
par nos communautés qui assurent la sécurité de nos résidents.
La mission du forum est de fournir à nos membres l’information nécessaire pour qu’ils puissent se préparer
au niveau des impacts sociaux-économique, environnemental ainsi que l’aspect sécurité à l’égard du projet.
Nous agissons comme voix commune pour défendre l’intérêt de nos membres.
Le Forum reconnaît les bienfaits que ce projet vont apporter à nos membres aux niveaux de développement
et retombées économique dont notre région a besoin. Plusieurs facteurs font en sorte qu’il est difficile de
garder nos jeunes en région et de promouvoir le développement économique. Notre territoire comprend des
petites municipalités rurales qui seront grandement affectées par ce projet et c’est pour les raisons
énumérées ci-haut que nous croyons sincèrement que nous devons être entendus lors du processus de
réglementation par l’Office National de l’Énergie.

       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental

The proposed Energy East pipeline will run through my community at Stittsville and will cross the Rideau
River and other tributaries of the Rideau River watershed. There are serious risks to groundwater, aquatic
systems and farmland should a oil spill occur. Drinking water would be contaminated, crops ruined. Leaks
and ruptures are inevitable, but are even more likely in this case as the original pipeline was designed to carry
natural gas, not diluted bitumen. From examples of pipeline ruptures in Arkansas and Michigan, it is clear
that the destruction of ecological integrity and risk to human health are real and the cost of cleanup is
unacceptably high.
Climate change is the issue of our time, and Canada is not pulling its weight in addressing it. Thirty-two
million tonnes of CO2 emissions will be produced each year in relation to this project, resulting in an
increased climate footprint that Canada should be ashamed of. In fact, this is greater than the emissions
from the proposed Keystone XL pipeline recently rejected by President Obama. I call on The National Energy
Board to consider not only the bottom line of multinational corporations, but also the urgency of climate
change and its risk to humanity. We must limit global warming to 2 degrees C to ensure the survival of our
children and future generations and we must begin immediately to work towards this goal. As a start,
bitumen extraction needs to be reduced - indeed, recent economics suggest that this is already occurring. I
argue that this pipeline is not required. It has no benefit to the local communities it will pass through,
including mine. We bear the risk, largely foreign interests reap any benefits. This is not in the best interests
of Canada and Canadians. As a national institution, The National Energy Board needs to take the climate
impacts of Energy East into consideration, along with the environmental and health risks that are
unacceptable to my community and others. We need an energy policy that benefits us all. This project is a
bad idea.

L’Institut
       projetde développement durable des Premières Nations du Québec et du Labrador (IDDPNQL) est une
commission de l’Assemblée des Premières Nations du Québec et du Labrador (APNQL). Le mandat principal
de l’IDDPNQL est d’apporter son soutien technique et son expertise aux 43 communautés au Québec et au
Labrador dans l’harmonisation des quatre piliers de leur développement durable : protection et mise en
valeur des territoires; développement social; viabilité économique et reconnaissance des droits des
Premières Nations.
Le soutien de l’IDDPNQL est particulièrement sollicité lorsqu’un projet de développement est susceptible
d’affecter les droits et intérêts des Premières Nations relativement à leur territoire et aux ressources
naturelles. L’IDDPNQL doit régulièrement traiter des impacts potentiels d’un projet sur l’environnement et
sur le bien-être de la communauté et faire des recommandations aux parties prenantes afin que le projet
respecte les enjeux, droits et intérêts des Premières Nations. Ainsi, l’IDDPNQL est directement interpellé par
le projet Énergie Est de TransCanada puisqu’il implique de nouvelles infrastructures qui traversent ou qui
sont localisées à proximité des territoires des communautés des Premières Nations, que l’IDDPNQL a le
mandat de soutenir. L’IDDPNQL possède les renseignements pertinents et l’expertise appropriée pour
contribuer à l’examen de l’Office.
L’équipe de l’IDDPNQL est formée d’un coordonnateur et de 6 chargés de projet. Le coordonnateur est
membre de la Première Nation Innue d’Essipit. Il détient une maîtrise en sciences de l’environnement avec
spécialisation en ressources renouvelables. Avant d’être coordonnateur pour l’IDDPNQL, il a réalisé des
études sur l’utilisation et l’occupation du territoire pour sa communauté. Les 6 chargés de projet ont les
qualifications suivantes :
-Maîtrise en biogéosciences environnementales;
-Maîtrise en ingénierie environnementale;
-Baccalauréat en géographie;
-Maîtrise en sciences politiques avec spécialisation en gouvernance de l’environnement;
-Maîtrise en sciences de l’environnement avec spécialisation en anthropologie;
-Maîtrise en sciences de l’environnement avec spécialisation en gestion de l’eau.
En outre, l’équipe de l’IDDPNQL coordonne des réseaux d’experts des Premières Nations et organise
régulièrement des rencontres au cours desquelles les représentants des communautés et leurs
collaborateurs partagent leurs travaux et expériences sur des dossiers précis. Avec son réseau, l’IDDPNQL
intervient notamment sur ces thématiques :
-Consultation ;
-Planification territoriale;
-Énergie ;
-Foresterie;
-Mines;
-Espèces en péril et protection des habitats fauniques;
-Changements climatiques;
-Gestion de l’eau;
-Gestion des matières résiduelles;
-Etc.
L’IDDPNQL possède par le fait même des renseignements pertinents pour l’évaluation du projet Énergie Est.
En effet, l’IDDPNQL a organisé auprès de son réseau et auprès des Chefs des Premières Nations des ateliers
d’information et des ateliers de travail par rapport au projet Énergie Est et ses enjeux quant aux Premières
Nations. Enfin, l’IDDPNQL a effectué des travaux sur des dossiers qui ont des composantes communes avec
celui d’Énergie Est : stratégie maritime du gouvernement du Québec, politique énergétique du Québec,
évaluations environnementales stratégiques sur les hydrocarbures, etc. Ainsi, l’IDDPNQL est en mesure de

 contribuer à l’examen de l’Office, notamment en ce qui concerne les questions 7, 8, 11 et 16 de la liste.

                                       Connection to Project Issues
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
In reference to issue #12, I am a landowner that was notified by Transcanada Corporation about the Energy
East pipeline that will allow diluted bitumen to run through my property.
The Transcanada Corporation already stated publicly that they cannot 100% guarantee that spills will not
occur. This increases the risk of contamination since diluted bitumen seeps into the ground whereas natural
gas simply evaporates into the air. This project affects me in the following ways:
1) The resale value of my property decreases automatically due to the known risks of contamination that is a
concern for future buyers interested in my property.
2) My existing pipeline easement agreement with Transcanada Corporation is very outdated and will not be
renewed. Transcanada Corporation will never be required to pay compensation (rent) on an annual basis that
would offset the loss of value to my property and give incentive for future prospective buyers. A
representative from Transcanada Corporation who came to my home in 2013 made it very clear that they
would not be able to provide any ongoing compensation to the property owners as it would cost them too
much money.
3) There is no defined mechanism in place that ensures that I will receive fair compensation for the value of
my property if it is deemed unlivable due to contamination. I have my residence on the property that
depends on well water and farm land that would lose productivity.
4) After the pipeline has been decommissioned and the process of pipeline abandonment has been
completed a utility or facility company then takes over. Should the company cease to exist afterwards it then
becomes the responsibility of the land owner. Any remaining issues with the abandoned pipeline will be at
my expense.
5) Transcanada Corporation is not required to remove the abandoned pipeline from the easement on my
property. This will result in regulatory restrictions on crossing the pipeline with agricultural equipment and
limiting easement access.

As a long time resident of Falcon Lake MB and Winnipeg, I am directly affected by this project. My cottage is
the closest residence to the water outflow point at Falcon Lake. As a resident of Winnipeg I drink the water
that will potentially be contaminated if chemicals spill into Falcon Lake and then through the Falcon River
System into Shoal Lake, the source of Winnipeg's drinking water.
The TransCanada pipeline #4 that is proposed to be re-purposed for Dilbit is situated in very close proximity
to Falcon Lake. From what I understand the re-purposing of a 40 year old pipeline that is presently nearing
the end of its lifespan comes with great risk. The proposed technology to monitor the stress cracks in the
pipe does not have the abilities to access many sections of the pipe. The exterior coating on the pipeline is
old, brittle and failing. The interior of the pipe will be detrimentally affected by the 4% sulfur content of the
Dilbit. The sulfur will expedite the corrosion of the interior of the pipe. There will be leaks and if they happen
near my home in Winnipeg or at Falcon Lake there will be permanent damage done. Besides the concern for
the water, I am concerned for the surrounding area. I walk, cross-country ski and bike on the pipeline and on
trails that crisscross and run adjacent to the pipeline.
I am a past director and current member of the Whiteshell Trail Association and have been directly involved
in the site location and development of 100 km of hiking/biking/skiing trails in the south Whiteshell that cross
both pipelines at several locations. I am a member of the Whiteshell Cottagers Association.

10. The engineering design and integrity of the Project
The Association of Consulting Engineering Companies - Canada (ACEC) is a federation of twelve provincial and
territorial associations representing over 450 companies that provide professional engineering services to
both the public and the private sector. Its members' services include planning, designing and implementing
all types of engineering projects, and providing independent advice and expertise in a wide range of
engineering-related fields.
In 2013, ACEC adopted a position on energy infrastructure that supports pipelines as a responsible and
necessary means of transporting oil and energy resources to market. Increasing global and domestic demand
for energy means that the oil and gas sector will continue to be a necessary and important part of the
Canadian economy and energy security for the foreseeable future. The Canadian consulting engineering
sector has expertise to support the socially, environmentally and economically responsible extraction and
transport of energy resources.
If granted the opportunity, ACEC and the consulting engineering sector are committed to working with the
Canadian energy sector and all levels of government to ensure the responsible and safe extraction and
transportation of Canadian oil and gas resources.

 7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
L'association des biologistes du Québec est un organisme à but non lucratif qui représente 800 membres
biologistes. Un des objectifs de l'Association est d'exprimer la position des biologistes sur les enjeux sociaux,
économiques, politiques et environnementaux qui interpellent les membres. Le projet "énergie est" est un
projet d'envergure qui touchera plusieurs écosystèmes aquatiques et terrestres au Québec. Une majorité des
membres de l'ABQ sont spécialisés dans l'écologie et les évaluations d'impacts sur l'environnement. Plusieurs
d'entre eux ont déjà participé à des projets énergétiques et à des évaluations environnementales
stratégiques sur les ressources énergétiques. L'Association des biologistes du Québec fera appel à leur
expertise afin de produire la lettre de commentaires. Nous impliquerons des biologistes qui se retrouvent sur
le tracé du pipeline et en ont une bonne connaissance ou qui ont de l'expertise particulière sur les
évaluations se rapportant aux pipelines, au déversement de pétrole sur l'environnement ainsi qu'aux
analyses de risque et aux évaluations toxicologiques. Ces biologistes pourront faire des recommandations
pour réduire les impacts ou gérer les risques associés à la protection des écosystèmes aquatiques et
terrestres ainsi que sur les mesures compensatoires qui sont prévues dans l'étude d'impact de TransCanada
Oleoduc Energie Est. Nous sommes convaincus que l'expertise des membres de l'Association des biologistes
du Québec pourra être très utile à l'Office nationale de l'Énergie dans son évaluation du projet.

 9.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet
10. La conception technique et l’intégrité du projet
Depuis le début le tracé de l'oléoduc proposé n'est pas clair. Même après plusieurs changements de trajets,
rien ne fait du sens et la population du Nord-Ouest du Nouveau-Brunswick n'est pas bien informée.
Encore aujourd'hui, la documentation déposée du projet Énergie Est à l'ONÉ comporte des erreurs de
description du trajet qui ne correspond pas à la carte associée au trajet pour la région d'Edmundston. Une
grande inquiétude plane sur la région et de la sincérité de l'entreprise Transcanada est mise en doute.
Ma première rencontre avec un agent au travail pour la compagnie m'a laissé avec une grande déception. Ce
n'est qu'à son départ qu'il m'a laissé de la documentation me permettant de connaître mes droits. Mais il
avait déjà eu ma signature sur un document et en faisant la lecture, j'ai réalisé que c'était une erreur que
j'allais regretter.
Des dizaines de personnes ont étés approchés dans ma région et ont étés mal informés par la compagnie. La
stratégie des agents étant claire; ne pas présenter l'ampleur du projet, les engagements et les droits aux
propriétaires de façon que les propriétaires prennent une décision éclairée. Les signatures de permissions
étaient recueillies et un chèque remis comme remerciement, avant même que les gens reçoivent de la
documentation et compris leurs droits et ce que cette signature signifiait.
Étant un propriétaire ayant signé un document "Études préliminaires", je m’inquiète que le trajet définitif se
retrouve sur ma propriété.
Étant un résident d'Edmundston, je m’inquiète que le trajet de l'oléoduc se retrouve dans le bassin versant
qui approvisionne la municipalité en eau potable.
Étant un adepte de plein-air, de chasse, de pêche et de cueillette de petits fruits et plantes sauvages, je crains
que mes loisirs et source de nourriture me soient privés par l'arrivée de ce pipeline.
