 1.     The need for the Project
2.     The economic feasibility of the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year, the
same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads, and greater than the climate footprint of an Atlantic
province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE). This is also 10 million tonnes per year greater than the Keystone XL pipeline,
which the United States Environmental Protection Agency has determined to have a significant impact on
climate change. The National Energy Board needs to take the climate impacts of Energy East into
consideration as there is no other federal review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East will affect nearly every issue on the list of issues:
If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit global warming to 2 degree Celsius there will be
no proven need for Energy East as tar sands expansion will need to be capped (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
The economic feasibility of the project is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble
and the low price of oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and on ways of life.
For these reasons the NEB needs to include climate change in its review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an
abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across Canada.
I am living in Ottawa. The pipeline would cross through the City of Ottawa and through the Rideau River
which feeds into the Ottawa River - our major source of drinking water. Spills would have devastating
impacts, the pipeline would be a fundamental risk to drinking water sources for Ottawa.
I have the vision that Ottawa should be the greenest city in Canada, to make it the best place to raise our
families – and I have two kids to raise here -, to have vibrant communities and neighborhoods, to see viable
options for public transit, cyclists, and pedestrians, to have clean rivers, local food and to be safe from threats
of climate change. The pipeline fundamentally threatens this vision and a healthy way of life.

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.
2.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the proposed project.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
5.     The engineering design and integrity of the proposed project. The appropriateness of the proposed
       capacity of the proposed project (575 TJ/d) will be considered under Issue #5 of Energy East.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
7.     Safety and security during construction of the proposed project and operation of the project, including
       emergency response planning and third-party damage prevention.
9.     The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue.
The TransCanada Eastern Mainline natural gas pipelines, as currently established consists of two natural gas
pipelines within a single right-of-way (ROW). The expansion project proposes to add a third natural gas
pipeline. Within the Town of Whitby, the majority of the new pipeline installation will deviate northwards
from the existing TransCanada pipeline ROW, creating a new ROW across the northern portion of the
municipality.
In June 2014, Town of Whitby Council authorized staff to submit to the National Energy Board an Application
to Participate in the hearing to provide input into the proposed TransCanada Eastern Mainline natural gas
pipeline.
Our Letter of Comment will identify and provide insight into the following areas:
+ The impact of the proposed pipeline and ROW
+ The significance of the Environmentally Sensitive Areas along the pipeline route within the Town of Whitby
+ Community Safety during construction and operation of the pipeline
+ Environmental safety during construction and operation of the pipeline
+ Restoration and compensation due to the creation and expansion of the pipeline ROW
+ Adequate security to ensure that TransCanada is able to quickly and fully restore any negatively impacted
lands
Town of Whitby looks forward to providing input into the proposed TransCanada Eastern Mainline natural
gas pipeline. Should you have any questions or require additional information, please do not hesitate to
contact Robert Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer, 905-430-4300 x2211.

I live with a First Nations person and enjoy the privilege of visiting Indigenous lands during fishing season.
Each summer is an opportunity to leave the city for a necessary health break along the banks of the many
streams and rivers of Ontario that lie along the proposed pipeline's route. Without these breaks I would be
incapacitated. We camp on the shores of these rivers and streams and I am aware that there have been
landslides reported as a result of pipeline reconstruction and installations in those places. My roommate
works full-time and has not had adequate opportunity to consider the full impact this project will have on the
lives of his family.
I write to add my voice, and request a delay in the NEB [National Energy Board] approvals process [for the
proposed Eastern Mainline project] to allow for a true process of consultation and accommodation with First
Nations and other affected communities, including a series of in-person sessions by board staff and
TransCanada for communities along the route, and funding to those communities to ensure they have the
capacity to assess the proposal. The NEB has declined multiple requests for Chiefs of Ontario for in person
information sessions on the proposed project and the approvals process for First Nations in Ontario. Chief
Beardy highlights, "The Government of Canada must undertake robust consultation with First Nations on the
Energy East Pipeline, and this consultation must form the basis of the Government’s ultimate decision on the
proposed project.” Treaty 3 Grand Chief Warren White expressed similar concerns about the lack of
consultation.
I respect the right to free, prior and informed consent which is affirmed in the United Nations Declaration on
the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. I also acknowledge the duty to consult which the Supreme Court of Canada
has defined as a mandatory constitutional obligation. It does not mean simply informing Indigenous peoples
about a major project, but rather it requires appropriate accommodation and on 'very serious issues' their
full consent. Aboriginal title extends to the entire traditional territory of an Indigenous group and that
consent from First Nations.

spills is essential to guage the economic and ecological impact of the pipeline.

 Grand Lake and the adjoining watersheds will be devastated if there is an oil spill near the Salmon River
crossing. I am a waterfront landowner on Grand Lake and an oil spill will affect the economic value of my
property, as well as the use and enjoyment of my property. Many birds frequent the waters near my house;
gulls, great blue heron (a species at risk), kingfisher, mergansers, bald eagle, cormorants, river otter. Birds
and mammals are very sensitive to oil spills. I kayak, boat, sail and fish on Grand Lake and its tributaries, and
an oil spill will negatively impact all recreational activity, including bird watching. Any oil spill close to the
waters of Grand Lake and its tributaries would affect thousands of people and have a devastating affect on
New Brunswick tourism. Bitumen entering the these waters would be highly toxic and very damaging to
human, animal and plant health for a long period of time. This will negatively affect the health of local
recreational, tourism and other economies which thrive on clean water with plant and animal species.
 i have a Masters Degree in Recreation Administration from Florida State University and a Masters in Public
Administration from Dalhousie University and am well versed on the economic impacts of tourism and
outdoor recreation.
For further information I direct you to a study - http://www.grandlakemeadows.com/index.asp
The Grand Lake Meadows is a unique fresh water wetland that lies between the waters of Grand Lake and
the St. John River in central New Brunswick. It is one of the largest freshwater wetlands in Atlantic Canada
and is noted for its complex but inter-related ecosystems and for its biodiversity.
Made up of about 116,000 hectares the Meadows are an exceedingly productive and precious resource for all
living things. Several portions (almost 3000 hectares) of the Grand Lake Meadows are protected under the
New Brunswick Protected Natural Areas program and the Eastern Habitat Joint Venture program.
Wetlands are the cradle of life for a number of species. They serve as breeding, nesting and feeding grounds
for a wonderful variety of wildlife that includes fish, amphibians, insects, birds and mammals.
The waters of the Grand Lake Meadows act as a heat sink storing heat in summer and releasing it in autumn
resulting in a lengthened frost-free period, and generally moderating the local climate.
The wetlands of the Grand Lake Meadows help to reduce floods and ease drought by absorbing excess water
and slowly releasing it somewhat like a sponge.
Wetlands reduce pollution by filtering out pollutants and excess nutrients from nearby lakes, rivers and
streams.
Wetlands can serve to recharge valuable groundwater supplies.
In and near the Grand Lake Meadows a variety of recreational activities take place – birding, photography,
fishing, hunting, gathering, and boating. The Meadows are ours to enjoy, but always remember that human
activities must not be allowed to diminish the quality of this valuable natural environment. Our concern and
stewardship will help protect this unique part of our natural heritage.

My family and myself are directly affected by this project. The proposed pipeline will cross waterways, that
when there is a spill, will directly affect both the North Bay, Ont. city's source drinking water from Trout Lake
and also the land of which our family has farmed for over 100 years. A bitumen leak from this proposed
pipeline into Doran Creek, which flows into Trout Lake and crosses through our farmland, would adversely
affect the aquatic, insect and small mammals life that sustains the Permaculture of our farm.
We are unable to assess as to whether or not TransCanada Pipelines contingency plan is adequate to address
the negative impacts to the Trout Lake and Lake Nipissing watersheds as TransCanada has yet to file a
contingency plan for our area to the NEB.
North Bay's Natural Gas is serviced by the proposed Bitumen Pipeline at present and I have grave concerns as
to the reliability and cost to North Bay and Eastern Ontario residents for Natural Gas in the future if this line
is converted to carry Bitumen. It is also of concern that a 40 year old gas pipeline is being converted to carry a
completely different weight and pressure of product, in light of the many breaches in pipelines that have
occurred recently in pipelines designed specifically for bitumen across North America.
I have difficulty believing that there will be any long term financial benefit from jobs in our province if this
project goes forward. A bitumen spill will not only have a huge environmental impact in our area but it will
also negatively impact tourism in our area. This far exceeds any financial benefit from the few jobs that may
be created.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
16. The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue for
       the Project
The Ministry of Environment (ministry) has direct regulatory responsibilities related to the protection and
management of the environment within Saskatchewan. As such, the province has a vested interest in any
project that may result in environmental impacts or socio-economic impacts related to changes to the
environment.
The province is supportive of the Energy East Pipeline Project (the Project) and the National Energy Board
(Board) as the reviewing agency to reduce regulatory duplication. However, the Project has potential
implications to environmental components regulated under provincial legislation and therefore the province
wishes to provide advice and recommendations for consideration by the Board during the decision–making
process.
Specific issues of interest are centered on the activities required for retrofitting the existing natural gas
pipeline for use transporting oil, and performance of the pipeline during operation including, but not limited
to:
-Impacts of construction and operation activities on rare, sensitive, or endangered environmental features
such as native prairie and sensitive ecosystems (i.e. the Great Sand Hills).
-Potential for adverse environmental effects stemming from malfunction following the retrofit given the age
of the existing pipe and construction methods utilized during initial construction.
-Ensuring provincial legislative requirements are reflected in the Board’s terms and conditions for the Project
thereby avoiding regulatory duplication.

                Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
3.     Les effets du projet sur les échanges commerciaux, l’économie, l’approvisionnement et le marché
La Société du parc industriel et portuaire de Bécancour (SPIPB) est une société du gouvernement du Québec
ayant pour mission de favoriser le développement économique du Québec en développant et en exploitant,
dans un objectif d'autofinancement, un parc industriel et portuaire à Bécancour.
La principale préoccupation de la SPIPB dans le cadre du projet Énergie Est concerne ses effets sur
l'approvisionnement en gaz naturel du Québec.
Dans le contexte actuel d'une économie en redressement, Bécancour sort du lot avec plusieurs projets
d'investissements industriels majeurs annoncés au cours des dernières années. De ces projets, on peut
compter plusieurs industries pour lesquelles l'accessibilité au gaz naturel, en quantité et en coût, constitue un
facteur déterminant dans la décision finale concernant la construction de l'usine. Ces projets totalisent des
investissements privés potentiels à hauteur de 3,4 milliards de dollars canadiens et nécessitent
conjointement une quantité de gaz naturel plus élevée que l'approvisionnement complet du Québec en 2014.
L'incertitude sur l'approvisionnement en gaz naturel en raison de la cession d'actifs constitue une inquiétude
importante pour les promoteurs de ces projets et pour la SPIPB.
Étant convaincue que les enjeux d'approvisionnement en gaz naturel doivent faire l'objet d'une étude
détaillée en raison de l'impact potentiel sur l'économie Québécoise, la Société du parc industriel et portuaire
de Bécancour souhaite pouvoir déposer une lettre de commentaires dans le cadre du projet, suivant les
audiences de l'Office national de l'énergie.

I am directly affected by this pipeline because I live in the city of North Bay where all of our drinking water
comes from Trout Lake. The pipeline crosses the watershed and goes through the lake. When there is a leak,
it will be very difficult to clean up, and word of this will only cause our property values to drop. I am relying
on the value of my house as a portion of my old age security. Furthermore, by repurposing the natural gas
pipeline, I understand the cost of natural gas in this area will rise. In a cold climate such as we are in, this will
only add to our heating and other home-related costs.

7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets

Nous sommes un groupe de professeurs de l’Université de Moncton, Campus de Shippagan (UMCS)
possédant une expertise dans les domaines du développement durable, des sciences environnementales, de
l’économie et de la sociologie. Nos activités de recherche et d'enseignement portent sur des problématiques
complexes qui impliquent des modifications multiples sur les plans économiques, environnementaux et
sociologiques, comme le projet Énergie Est.
Nous croyons pouvoir fournir un point de vue unique sur le projet Énergie Est en démontrant comment les
conséquences du projet sur les sphères environnementales, économiques et sociologiques interagissent les
unes sur les autres et peuvent finir par avoir des conséquences inattendues sur la qualité de vie des individus
et le devenir des sociétés. Nous voulons montrer ici le sens que peut avoir ce projet sur le plan humain, pour
les générations présentes et celles de demain, en considérant plus particulièrement les régions de l'est du
Canada.

 3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
6.     Contingency planning for spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and operation of the
       proposed project.
7.     Safety and security during construction of the proposed project and operation of the project, including
       emergency response planning and third-party damage prevention.
9.     The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue.
The proposed project directly affects: (1) the landowner’s use of her land; (2) the safety and security of the
landowner or those permitted onto the property during construction and operation of the project; (3) the
landowner’s use of the land in the event of spills, accidents or malfunctions, during construction and
operation; and (4) the landowner’s use of her land in view of any terms and conditions to be included in any
recommendation or approval by the Board.
(1) The project directly affects the landowner’s use of her land. The landowner owns approximately 20 acres
of land which is both an active agricultural farm and rental residential property. The proposed pipeline is
routed to run through the westerly portion of the landowner’s farm and will have a major impact on the
farm, both the lands through which the pipe is proposed to run as well as the remaining land surrounding the
pipeline. Specifically, there will be a significant amount of disruption and reduced use due to the
construction of and access to maintain the pipeline. In addition, the right of way above the pipeline and 30
metre safety zone around the pipeline, will significantly limit and impact agricultural use. There is also the
potential for the pipeline to designate a restricted area extending beyond the safety zone which further
restricts the landowner’s land use. Given that the landowner has only 20 acres of land the right of way,
safety zone and restricted area will significantly reduce the usable portion of the landowner’s property. Such
reduction in use and value of the landowner’s property will be a direct result of the installation of the
pipeline and the restrictions that come with it. The landowner is retired and the close proximity to the
pipeline will affect the landowners ability to rent the residential portion of the property or rent/use the
agricultural property thereby affecting her income.
(2) The safety and security of the landowner and others permitted on her property will be directly affected
during construction and operation of the project. Specifically, the landowner is directly affected by
limitations on the type of activity and farm equipment which may be safely used on the property and the
types of crops which may be grown. In fact, in many, if not all cases, landowners must seek permission from
the pipeline company for any activity on their property.
(3) The landowner’s use of the land will be directly affected and seriously impacted in the event of spills,
accidents or malfunctions. The impacts of such spills and malfunctions have the ability to render the entire
property unusable and reduce the value of the property to the landowner.
(4) The land owner is directly affected by any terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or
approval the Board may issue. Such terms are directly relevant to the pipeline's use and impact on the
landowner and landowner's property, including any approvals for additional construction.

    As a Trout Lake lakeside resident of North Bay I will be extremely negatively effected by any leak of
diluted bitumen along the route of the proposed Energy East Pipeline through the Trout Lake watershed. My
drinking water is drawn directly from Four Mile Bay, part of Trout Lake, into my home as is all of the water
used within and around my home. My recreation in, on and around my lakeside property and crown land
along the pipeline route contributes to and maintains my physical and mental well-being. The possibility of a
leak/incident along the pipeline route, if approval is given to this present proposal, is terribly upsetting. The
potential risk of this proposal to Trout Lake water quality is not acceptable.
    When a leak occurs (and it will at some point in time) in this proposed pipeline, values of lakeshore
properties will significantly plummet. I have worked hard to purchase this property, and this investment is
part of my retirement planning. Who will purchase property on a lake polluted with diluted bitumen; unsafe
to drink, swim and recreate in or on? Trans Canada would not be able to clean up the damage; the lake and
land could never be returned to its pre-spill state.Trans Canada would never be able to compensate people
for their resulting losses.
    Two natural gas pipelines run side by side through the Trout Lake watershed, one proposed to be
converted to transport diluted bitumen, the other to continue transporting natural gas. Co-location of these
two lines is dangerous and ludicrous. There have been explosions in gas pipelines in Northern Ontario in the
past, and this will continue to occur in the future.
    This pipeline route is not easily accessible due to the terrain, lack of access, and winter conditions. In
many stretches, once a leak is discovered, it would be days before emergency response teams are in place,
resulting in the spread of irrecoverable diluted bitumen. Rigorous and diligent evaluation of the emergency
response plan needs to be conducted with utmost integrity and transparency by an unbiased and adept third
party.
    At a minimum, approval of this proposal must include the condition of building a new stretch of pipeline
outside of the Trout Lake watershed. The entire proposed project should have to undergo thorough
environmental assessment reviews along the whole route. All stretches of this proposed pipeline should be
built to the highest standards of the industry.

9.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet
La MRC de Témiscouata est située dans l’Est du Québec, dans la région administrative du Bas-Saint-Laurent.
Frontalière du Nouveau-Brunswick et de l’État américain du Maine, elle est bordée du côté du Québec par les
MRC de Rimouski-Neigette, des Basques, de Rivière-du-Loup et de Kamouraska. La MRC de Témiscouata
couvre une superficie de 3 921 km2 et compte 20 440 citoyens . Dix-neuf municipalités composent le
territoire de la MRC de Témiscouata. Traversé par la route Transcanadienne, le territoire est la principale voie
d’accès vers les provinces de l’Est du Canada.
La MRC de Témiscouata compte de nombreux cours d’eau sur lesquels elle a compétence exclusive, 867 plans
d’eau dont 14 de plus de 100 hectares et plus de 30 rivières d'importance. Ces cours d’eau et lacs contribuent
à créer des paysages très diversifiés et d’une grande qualité et revêtent une grande importance au niveau
environnemental, tant en milieu rural qu’en milieu urbain.

Seuil de détection des fuites inadéquat
Plusieurs municipalités s'opposent au projet d'oléoduc EnergieEst. La MRC d’Autray repose sa décision sur
une étude indépendante menée par les firmes J. Harvey Consultants et Écogestionsolutions. Leur rapport
souligne une faille majeure du système de détection des fuites de TransCanada.
www.lapresse.ca/actualites/environnement/201501/28/01-4839343-energie-est-une-etude-independante-
montre-des-failles-de-securite.php Le seuil de détection des fuites serait de 1,5% du débit total de l’oléoduc.
 Il pourrait s’écouler plusieurs semaines avant de détecter une fuite dont le débit serait inférieur à 1,5%.
À première vue, un seuil de détection de 1,5% peut sembler convenable, il est pourtant inacceptable. Quelle
quantité de pétrole pourrait s’échapper à leur surveillance? 1,5% du débit total de 1,1 millions de barils par
jour c’est immense. Ça représente 16500 barils par jour ou un peu plus de 2,6 millions de litres. C’est
l’équivalent de 82 camions citernes ou 23 wagons de train par jour qui pourrait se répandre sur nos terres et
dans nos cours d’eau avant qu’il s’en aperçoive, et ce pendant plusieurs semaines. C’est plutôt inquiétant.
J’irai même plus loin, parce que j’ai l’ambition de sortir le monde de la torpeur. Lorsqu’une plateforme
pétrolière prend feu et coule au fond des mers, ces des quantités phénoménales de pétrole qui se répand
dans l’environnement. Vous vous rappelez sans doute de la catastrophe qui a eu lieu dans le golfe du
Mexique en 2010. La plateforme « DeepWater Horizon » a déversé 680 000 tonnes de pétrole dans la mer,
pendant 111 jours. C’est en moyenne 6 126 tonnes de bitume par jour. En 1979, la plateforme « Ixtoc 1 »
sombra aussi dans les eaux du golfe du Mexique et répandit entre 470 000 et 1,5 million de tonnes de
pétrole. Au début, elle a déchargé entre 4 200 et 4 300 tonnes par jour puis entre 1 400 et 1 500 tonnes
après le colmatage partiel de la fuite.
1,5% du débit de l’oléoduc ÉnergieEst correspond à 2 000 – 2 300 tonnes de pétrole par jour, dépendamment
de la densité du bitume. Ainsi, la quantité de pétrole perdue toléré par le seuil de détection de TransCanada
est comparable aux plus grands déversements de plateformes pétrolières. Pendant qu’il y a état d’urgence
sur une plateforme pétrolière le pipeline de TransCanada coulerait autant et ce serait tout à fait acceptable?
C’est ce qui me tourmente le plus.
Avec ces chiffres alarmants qui a l’audace de prétendre que leur technologie permettra de détecter
rapidement les fuites et de réagir à temps pour empêcher une catastrophe éventuelle? Le constat est
dangereusement menaçant, il faut absolument que nos gouvernements se réveillent. On a droit de jouir d’un
environnement sain. Notre eau potable, nos terres fertiles et nos habitats naturels sont plus précieux que
votre or noir bitumineuse.

 We are a Citizens Group in the Village of Gagetown, N.B., and surrounding area, located on the St. John
River, near the outflow from Grand Lake - the largest freshwater body in N.B. Some of our members have
homes on the shores of Grand Lake.
We are very concerned that the proposed pipeline route crosses many watersheds that flow into the St. John
River, including in Southern N.B., our own Grand Lake, Canaan-Washademoak, Belleisle, Kennebecasis and
the Hampton Marsh. We are also concerned about the Bay of Fundy, which has a very fragile ecosystem and
many unique features, including the world's highest tides, superb beaches, and the Right Whale, a
threatened species. The bay and all it has to offer is one of our greatest tourist attractions.
We think that the proposed route threatens, rather than enhances our economy. We think the potential for
accidents poses severe implications for our property values and the tourism industry, to say nothing of the
threat to the actual waterways and our important fish and wildlife which bring in revenue from hunters and
sports fishers. The possibilities are too great to enumerate.
We sincerely hope that the NEB will consider from all its angles, the application to build this pipeline, not just
as a way to bring oil from west to east.
Background
Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year, the
same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads, and greater than the climate footprint of an Atlantic
province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE). This is also 10 million tonnes per year greater than the Keystone XL pipeline,
which the United States Environmental Protection Agency has determined to have a significant impact on
climate change. The National Energy Board needs to take the climate impacts of Energy East into
consideration as there is no other federal review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East will affect nearly every issue on the list of issues:
If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit global warming to 2 degree Celsius there will be
no proven need for Energy East as tar sands expansion will need to be capped (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
The economic feasibility of the project is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble
and the low price of oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and on ways of life.
For these reasons the NEB needs to include climate change in its review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an
abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across Canada.

The Green Party of Manitoba is a political party that seeks to serve the interests of all Manitobans. We have
numerous members and supporters who have contacted us regarding concerns about the proposed pipeline
conversion (some who live near or adjacent to the proposed pipeline). Our members and supporters are
particularly concerned, inter alia, about the potential environmental impacts from a spill and/or explosion,
how the costs and liabilities in the event of a spill and/or explosion will be apportioned, the need for the
project in general, and the amount of Manitoban produced electricity the pipeline will use to facilitate
pumping. We wish to participate in the process as a commentator to raise the concerns of our members and
supporters.

The Pembina Institute (Pembina) is Canada’s leading think-tank on the impacts of energy development and
associated infrastructure projects. Pembina staff has decades of experience in academia, government, civil
society and industry. Since 1982, Pembina has been involved in national and provincial regulatory processes
regarding energy development and infrastructure projects across Canada. Pembina has critical information
and expertise pertaining to the List of Issues numbers one, two, three, seven and 16.
Oilsands extraction and refining requires a significant amount of energy. Because of this, oilsands
development results in larger amounts of greenhouse gases (GHGs) than most global oil reserves. As
governments legislate to ensure the negative externality associated with carbon pollution are not born by
society, oilsands projects – and their associated infrastructure – become less economically viable. It is
essential the Board includes the longer-term economic feasibility of the Energy East Pipeline Project (the
Project) – not only the short and medium-term benefits as outlined by the proponent. To this end, Pembina
can provide expert evidence on a wide variety of potential carbon policies and the impact each would have
on the viability of the Project.
Sumas Energy 2 Inc. v. Canada (National Energy Board) describes the jurisdiction of the Board to reject
applications where the coincident environmental effects are counter to the public interest. Given oilsands
bitumen will make up the majority product in the pipeline — and oilsands mining projects have been
determined by Canada’s Governor in Council to generate significant, adverse environmental impacts, as
defined by the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, 2012 — the Board must consider whether the
cumulative environmental effects in connection with the Project are justified. Pembina is the only group in
Canada positioned to articulate the cumulative environmental impacts that would be coincident to the
approval of the Project.
Further to the Sumas Energy 2 Inc. decision, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency found another
oilsands pipeline — the Keystone XL project — could have a significant impact on GHG emissions if oil prices
fell below US$65-75 per barrel. Moreover, the International Energy Agency predicted crude prices will
average US$55 per barrel in 2015, and will rise to US$73 per barrel by 2020. In this low-price environment,
the difference shipping via pipeline versus other modes (rail, barge, etc.) is significant enough to influence an
oilsands company's decision to proceed with a project, and therefore reduces demand for and economic
viability of the Project. Unlike previous occasions when the Board considered this argument, the sustained
low price of oil has shifted oilsands economics: infrastructure decisions now impact the viability of future
oilsands development. Numerous projects were delayed or cancelled in 2014, citing lack of access to export
pipelines that would increase the value of Western Canada Select crude oil. Accordingly, the Board’s decision
to approve the Project would result in additional oilsands production, and its associated environmental
effects. These effects must be fully considered in advance of a Board decision to determine whether they are
justified and in the public interest.

As an artist and a life-long resident of northeastern Ontario, I have an interest in the Energy East project and
its potential effects on our region. I was born and raised in Temiskaming District and have lived in the North
Bay area for most of the last thirty years. The TransCanada pipeline has been a scar across our landscape
since the 1970s and the possibility of that “scar” becoming the source of additional damage as a result of oil
spills when the pipeline fails – again – is of concern to all of us who live here.
I am a visual artist. I paint, draw and sketch landscapes in our region, as well as working as a visual designer.
On both a professional and personal level, nature and the visual beauty of our region are necessities of life.
I rely on the healthy water of our region for physical life, but the water is also part of our social life, and
spiritual well-being. I am also a cancer survivor, and know too well the numbers games of risk and risk
calculation. When “risk” becomes reality, the calculations are set aside and the issues of liability and who
pays become more than just financial arguments.
So what are MY issues with Energy East? And how do they match with the NEB “list of issues”?
I could have checked “all of the above”, although noteably absent from the list of NEB issues is the issue that
is of global consequence, that being climate change and the carbon footprint of this project.
The first issue, the “need” for the project must be first and foremost. And the “business need” of
TransCanada does not suffice. The “need” is the need for a safe and healthy environment, for clean water
and air, for beauty and well-being. Will this project help us at a national or regional level meet these needs?
The other two issues I intend to address in my letter are the potential for environmental effects (issue #7) and
contingency planning (#14). When the pipeline fails, what will it affect? How will TransCanada respond? What
will we be left with? How will the aftermath affect our daily lives?

I live on the north shore of the Lake of the Woods, Ontario, a fresh water lake which has had the oversight
and review of an International Joint Commission since the turn of the last century to maintain the quality of
the water and to research and intervene with pollutants like phosphorous, invasive species and the like as
this is a basin of water into which other rivers and water systems drain. Water from this lake flows into the
Winnipeg River and eventually to the Hudson's Bay. It is a source of drinking water and a source of economic
livelihood for a large tourist industry of fishing, boating, sailing, camping and numerous recreational
activities. It is the summer home for thousands of cottagers who have been coming for generations. The
possibility of a ruptured pipeline with a 20 minutes turn off time frame is a risk far too dangerous and costly
and outweighs the reward. There are no mitigating factors in the application which would convince me that
all technical and engineering safeguards have been installed. Leave the crude in the ground! We are in a
period of history where alternative energies are already being used and critical mass is at hand.
At the OEB consultation in Kenora, the Trans Canada Pipeline had not completed the environment and social
impact section of the application to the satisfaction of the OEB experts. How do we know that that was ever
completed to the OEB expert satisfaction. In the 68 binder application, it was evident that environmental
concerns and social impact in the building of the pipeline were of little to no importance.

I would like to speak to this project both as an individual directly affected by the proposed project and as an
individual having expertise in environmental planning and assessment and energy policy. This expertise
would be relevant under both (3) and (7) above.
Firstly, I am a resident of Winnipeg, MB and living alongside the Assiniboine River. The proposed routing
could potentially disrupt the watershed upstream from my home. Past oil spills, such as that in Kalamazoo
Michigan resulted in spills up to 56 km long. If a similar spill were to occur along the Assiniboine in would flow
just meters from my home. All residents alongside the proposed project have a legitimate right to concern
and to be heard.
Regarding my specific areas of expertise, I am researcher and environmental advocate with over ten years of
experience representing environmental non-governmental organizations, including Green Action Centre,
Canadian Environmental Network and Manitoba Eco-Network. In 2011, I was selected as an ENGO delegate
to provide evidence to the NEB for the Environmental and Socio-economic Assessment (ESA) Section Update
to the NEB's Filing Manual. I have provided numerous workshops and presentations on environmental
assessment processes and best practices. In my testimony I will provide evidence about the potential for
environmental and socio-economic impacts from the project, including harm to local ecosytems and also the
cumulative impacts of project in relation to existing energy infrastructure development in Manitoba.
A third concern I would like to raise relates to the economic impact of the project as a result of its energy
consumption in Manitoba. I have expertise in electricity rates and their social and environmental impacts. As
a member of the Green Action Centre policy committee, I have been involved as an intervenor in Manitoba
Hydro rate review hearings through the Public Utilities Board. I will present evidence that the Energy East
Pipeline will have a negative economic impact on Manitoba energy consumers, and will mitigate many of the
otherwise positive environmental benefits of Manitoba's energy plan.
Across North America, more and more communities are turning to ecological and sustainable alternatives to
fossil fuels. I will also dispute the need for the Energy East pipeline on this basis.

As a grandmother, I am deeply concerned about accelerating levels of carbon dioxide emissions and dire
consequences that will affect the health and safety of my grandchildren and future generations. The National
Energy Board needs to include the impacts on the environment in the review of the largest proposed pipeline
in North America, Energy East, and the resulting risk factors determining a healthy and safe future.
 My family and I live near and shop in Harbour Landing where the forty five year old gas pipeline is located
that will carry sluggish diluted bitumen. This conversion from the original purpose creates a greater risk of
injury and/or death from major ruptures, spills, explosions and fires. We, and the citizens of Regina, will bear
the risks and the costs for upgrading emergency responders, providing specific medical treatment and toxic
clean up.
The Energy East Pipeline would allow an increase in tar sands production of up to 750,000 barrels of oil every
day equivalent to the emissions of adding over 7,000,000 cars to Canada’s highways each year. People living
downstream would experience more toxic exposure. There has been increasing concern about how the rapid
pouring of carbon monoxide into the atmosphere is already altering earthly existence in every region of the
earth, including Canada.
The Energy East pipeline will cross or run near Canada’s most precious drinking water sources to valued
recreation and fishing waters. It would pose threats to local water supplies, communities and coastal waters.
Diluted bitumen sinks in water and is almost impossible and extremely expensive to clean up as witnessed in
the Kalamazoo River in Michigan.
According to the Leader Post, February 23, 2015, the most recent calculation by scientists is that two-thirds of
known reserves of oil and gas and coal must stay in the ground to slow and stop the warming trend. The
Energy East Pipeline would allow an increase in tar sands production that would generate up to 32 million
tones of carbon emissions each year. Canada would not be able to meet its emissions agreement, made with
the international community, to keep the global average temperature below two degrees Celsius.
To consider the environmental, social and economical effects of this gigantic project without considering the
environment and climate change impacts is not logical. Not including climate change in the Energy East
Pipeline review would be irresponsible and a failure to protect our grandchildren and future generations
from dire environmental consequences.

I am a citizen of Winnipeg who lives approximately 100 m. from the Assiniboine River. In the event of a DilBit
spill from the 40 year old existing natural gas pipeline that already has leaks and explosions, DilBit traveling
up the river, as in the case of the Kalamazoo spill, would require that I evacuate my house. It would also
decrease my property value because Dibit spills can only be cleaned up to 25% at very best. It would also
render the two public green riverside spaces near my house unusable. I would be directly affected by clean-
up costs as Energy East actually holds no assets so I, as well as other taxpayers, would be required to foot this
huge bill to "clean up" the mess. I would be directly affected in the event of a natural gas explosion whose
risk is high because the proposed DilBit line runs 7 m. from and parallel to the natural gas line. DilBit is very
flammable so would catch on fire and I (and the rest of Winnipeg) would have to be evacuated to avoid the
burning hydrogen sulfide. This gas reaches very high levels as it runs down the pipeline due to friction and
bacteria. Should I breath in any of this toxic hydrogen sulfide plume, I would be dead before I hit the ground.
I call on you to say no to the Energy East pipeline. It is not worth the risk.

15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
We oppose the Energy East Pipeline proposal nationally for many reasons. The
likelihood of a spill that would permanently harm our environment is too great
to chance. There have been many pipeline spills here and the USA, and some of
them have been catastrophic.
One study shows that in Alberta, less than one percent of environmental
infractions have been enforced. (http://globalnews.ca/news/734227/albertaenforcing-
fewer-than-one-per-cent-of-oilsands-environmental-violationsreport/
1)
Other studies confirm bitumen spills are impossible to clean up. This type of
pollution is known to have carcinogenic consequences.
Diluents will be shipped back to Alberta, increasing the chances of more
spillage, meanwhile reducing railway capacity for shipping more important
commodities.
Thus far, the industry and government regulations and oversight have
not properly addressed these problems. TransCanada’s intransigence on
addressing issues has been frustrating to many of us.
We believe the economic benefits are grossly exaggerated and the jobs they will
create will be negligible after the construction process.
On a local level, we oppose the proposal for numerous reasons. The threat to
the Madawaska River as Arnprior’s source for drinking water is too great and
the damage caused by leaked or spilled dilbit would be irreversible or, at best,
take many years to remediate.
There is the threat to area aquifers and pollution of our waterways in the
event of a spill - costly for the environment, residents, tourism, land values.
Moreover, considering Kalamazoo costs so far, we see the one billion dollar
insurance figure for cleanup as inadequate.
Also, our natural gas costs will likely go up: Enbridge has just informed
Arnprior Council of this directly. This issue is fraught with so many
inconsistencies and opposing views from different factions we just don’t know
whom or what to believe. There is too much spin, too little transparency.
We have asked TransCanada many questions on these and other issues and
although some have been answered, many more have not.
Therefore, we believe there is not enough information or credible assurance
from TransCanada to go ahead with the project.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental

 RE: 7 & 12, with two TransCanada pipelines crossing my farm and as an Intervenor in the NEB Hearing for the
first one built in 1982 I am aware of the discrepancies between what TCPL says it will do to protect the
environment and farmland and it's actual field performance. This is particularly true regarding compaction
which is highly detrimental to crop yields. Commitments made by TCPL at a Hearing are useless unless
followed through on, both during construction and afterwards. Compaction resulting from mismanagement
of wet soil can significantly reduce crop yields for years after the original damage, which I know because of
my experience as a farmer and as a researcher at Agriculture Canada's Land Resource Research Institute and
supported by the study TCPL eventually carried out on our farm after repeated demands. And in spite of
what they claim they did not do any follow-up in subsequent years. Their disregard for their commitment to
protect cropland productivity (which they made at the NEB hearing) and their lack of timely response to
complaints is symptomatic of a company that lacks the integrity to keep commitments made both to
landowners and to the NEB, which raises the question 'what else are they not doing that they claim that they
will do?' If they fail to address damage to agricultural land, which is easily noticed by a farmer, what faith can
one have that they will undertake remedial action for environmental damage done either from construction
or malfunction of the project, which in many cases will be out of sight (eg. fish spawning habitat in the Rideau
river)?
Regarding # 16 there is a definite need for major financial penalties for every breach of conditions set by the
NEB and every instance of non-compliance with both the NEB Act, that is supposed to govern TCPL, and with
any and all land-owner agreements. This is a necessity because I know that they have repeatedly ignored
both the requirement set out in our Landowner Easement Agreement and included in the National Energy
Board Act Bill C-60 (passed in 1982) to update the land values every 5 years. This legislated requirement to
update the land value every 5 years, on which the Easement Agreement rent is based for those who chose a
rental payment, has been disregarded by TCPL every 5 years for 28 years since the first update was due. To
date they are still paying rent based on the 1982 land value. Additionally payment can be sporadic, once
taking three years. If "how you do anything is how you do everything" there is no guarantee that any terms
and conditions set by the NEB will be adhered to so therefore in order to protect the environment, farmland
and landowners the NEB must not only ensure compliance but ensure that failure to comply by TCPL carries
with it a very large financial penalty, as well as all costs incurred by landowners and organizations working to
protect farmland and the environment.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
The City of Brandon is concerned about oils spills that impact our source of raw water, a loss of natural gas
supply and the impact of smoke from an oil fire.
The City of Brandon’s main source of raw water for potable water is the Assiniboine River. There are two
concerns related to spills that may enter the Assiniboine River upstream of Brandon. The first deals with
pipelines crossing the Assiniboine River at Miniota and at the Rivers Reservoir, which is part of the Little
Saskatchewan River that empties into the Assiniboine River. Our experience in flood response is that river
water takes approximately 96 hours to reach Brandon from Miniota and 24 hours to arrive from the Rivers
Reservoir.
The second concern related to spills is the impact on the system of interconnected aquifers that provide
Brandon with less than a 30 day emergency supply of water. The Brandon wells draw from the Assiniboine
River Valley Aquifer which touches the Brandon Channel Aquifer directly and the recharge of the Brandon
Channel Aquifer is effected by the Assiniboine River Valley Aquifer. It is our understanding that the
Hydrogeologists in Manitoba have not reached a consensus as to how they are interconnected but there is a
relationship since they are in the same watershed.
Contamination of raw water puts all 46,061 residents of Brandon in harm’s way and seriously impacts
industries in Brandon who are dependent on potable water, including Maple Leaf Foods who process
thousands of hogs on a daily basis. Other large industrial users including, Koch Fertilizer and Canexus
Chemicals, draw water from the Brandon Channel Aquifer. We understand that cleaning up contaminated
river water takes an extended period of time that is beyond what our emergency aquifer supply can provide.
Our emergency planning for a loss of water treatment relies on portable water treatment facilities that would
use river water and/or aquifer water as a supply. An extended river clean up or aquifer contamination would
make this unavailable.
A second type of impact is an explosion similar to the Rapid City (1995) event where two pipes were damaged
from one explosion. In the event of an explosion where several of the natural gas/oil pipelines are impacted
Brandon may suffer a loss of natural gas. The severity of the impact is dictated by the length of outage and
season in which it occurs. An event similar to Otterburne (2014) could seriously cripple Brandon. Our
emergency planning shows that in sub-zero temperatures buildings cool to the point of being uninhabitable
within 48 hours. Brandon’s sudden conversion to electric space heaters will cause a spike in electrical
demand and likely necessitate rolling blackouts. Our emergency response planning shows that once the gas
has been returned to the system several days are needed to inspect all gas appliances as they are brought
back on line.
The smoke plume from such a fire/explosion may require the activation of our shelter-in-place program and
thereby shut the city down for that time period.

                Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
3.     Les effets du projet sur les échanges commerciaux, l’économie, l’approvisionnement et le marché
7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
8.     Les effets environnementaux et socio-économiques pouvant découler d’un accroissement des activités
       de transport maritime
La Chambre de commerce de l’Est de Montréal (CCEM) a pour mission de défendre et de promouvoir les
intérêts économiques et sociaux des 32 000 entreprises qui composent son territoire. Avec ses quelque 1 200
membres, la Chambre est le plus important regroupement de gens d’affaires de l’est de la métropole et
exerce son leadership afin de susciter la participation active des intervenants socioéconomiques de son
milieu. La Chambre de commerce de l’Est de Montréal couvre un vaste territoire s'étendant de l'est du
boulevard Saint-Laurent jusqu'à la pointe de l'Ile, de la rivière des Prairies jusqu'au fleuve Saint-Laurent.
La CCEM est très enthousiaste face au projet Énergie Est qui engendrera, à première vue, des retombées
pour l’emploi et l’économie, en plus de stimuler la vigueur de l’industrie pétrolière et pétrochimique
montréalaise. Elle tient cependant à ce que trois conditions soient respectées avant de donner son aval entier
:
1- le pipeline doit approvisionner directement les entreprises pétrolières situées dans l’est de Montréal
2- il doit respecter la règlementation en vigueur dans l’industrie, tant au niveau de la sécurité et de
l’environnement
3- il ne doit pas engendrer d’autres enjeux d’approvisionnement et de surcharge pour les entreprises qui
consomment notamment le gaz naturel.

 Hydro-Québec produit, transporte et distribue de l’électricité. Son unique actionnaire est le gouvernement
du Québec. L’entreprise compte quatre divisions, dont Hydro-Québec TransÉnergie qui exploite le réseau de
transport d’électricité le plus vaste d’Amérique du Nord au bénéfice de clients au Québec et hors Québec. Le
réseau de HQT comprend 33 639 km de lignes de transport et 516 postes électriques, y compris des
interconnexions qui permettent des échanges d'électricité avec les provinces atlantiques, l'Ontario et le nord-
est des États-Unis. Les tarifs et les conditions de service de HQT, approuvés par la Régie de l'énergie, assurent
un accès non discriminatoire à son réseau, conformément à la réglementation nord-américaine applicable.
Pour répondre à l'évolution des besoins de la clientèle et garantir la qualité du service de transport, HQT
veille au développement, à la fiabilité et à la pérennité du réseau.
TransÉnergie a un intérêt certain à intervenir au présent dossier et à obtenir l’autorisation de l’ONÉ à y
participer notamment en fonction des questions nos 7, 9, 10,12, 13,14, 15 et 16. HQT détient, à titre de
bénéficiaire de droits de servitude sur les terrains visés par l’emprise projetée du projet, un intérêt dans le
présent dossier et peut faire valoir ses prétentions conformément à l’article 34(4) de la Loi sur l’Office
national de l’énergie.
Le tracé préliminaire proposé au Québec pour le projet de Trans Canada PipeLines Limited (« TCP »), a un
impact important sur les installations actuelles et futures d’HQT. Sur une distance de 710 km, le tracé longe
les lignes électriques d’HQT (principalement des lignes à 735 et 315 kV) et créer de nombreux croisements
(63) dans ses emprises de lignes. En certaines occasions, les équipements d’HQT devront cohabiter avec ceux
de TCP et ce, dans une même emprise.
À l’emprise projetée du pipeline, s’ajoute la zone de sécurité de 30 mètres en vertu de la législation et
réglementation applicable qui constitue une contrainte additionnelle pour l’exploitation des installations de
transport d’HQT et ses opérations.
HQT estime que ce projet pourrait ainsi limiter et affecter l’exploitabilité, la maintenance et la croissance de
son réseau électrique. HQT a des préoccupations particulières en raison de la proximité du pipeline projeté,
particulièrement en ce qui concerne le développement de son réseau électrique et des coûts des mesures de
protection des installations en place et de ceux à venir.
Par ailleurs, quant à sécurité et la sûreté associé à l’exploitation du projet, la présence des lignes d’électricité
de haute tension à proximité d’un pipeline, peut engendrer, le cas échéant, des phénomènes d’induction, de
corrosion et de champs magnétiques sur les installations pipelinières.
Enfin, en cas de bris de l’oléoduc, les installations d’HQT seront vraisemblablement touchées et des
interruptions de service pourront survenir avec toutes les conséquences qui en résultent, incluant la perte
d’alimentation électrique.
En conséquence, HQT est d’avis que son intervention sera utile et pertinente à l’Office et lui permettra de
rendre une décision éclairé dans le présent dossier.

 As a concerned Canadian, not just for our present society, but for Canadians in the generations to come, I feel
our real need is to quickly diversify our sources of energy, not to ever-more aggressively extract this one
resource for the benefit of the present list of oil companies.
The aim of oil companies is to get their product to tidewater and to overseas markets where the oil would
command higher prices than present circumstances allow. The companies are doing this for themselves and
their investors, as companies all do and should, but not for Canada. Most of the big companies aren’t
Canadian. If they wanted to build this for Canadians why did they first propose to pipe out their dilbit by
way of Keystone? And if they don’t get approval for this EE proposal, why are they saying they will next try to
get it out through Alaska? Our resources are precious and should be available to Canadians first to ensure our
long term energy security.
The environmental risks of spills along the route are significant when considered over the course of the
decades ahead. Much of the pipe is already 40 years old. Under pressure at 1000 psi, the chance that
ruptures at points along the route will occur in the next 40 years is certain. Slight drops in pressure and slow
leaks won’t easily be detected back in Calgary, and major damage can occur before detection. A break in the
line by the Rideau River near my home in Ottawa would have devastating and long-lasting consequences to
my city. Seepage into the Oxford-Mills aquifer at our south end of Ottawa would destroy drinking water
sources for thousands of people.
The Ottawa River Watershed is held sacred by the Algonquins. It is their land which I and my neighbours in
Ottawa occupy. We must respect our First Peoples and the land and waters that they hold sacred. It is not
right to risk our shared land and water.
I feel that all Canadians are directly affected by this proposed pipeline expansion because of the climate
impact. We can’t divide the environment into different parts and consider them in isolation. There’s been
an effort to say that isolated economic benefits for people along the route mean a benefit for all Canadians,
but that negative impacts can only be considered by local stakeholders even if everyone’s taxes help pay the
expenses incurred when problems occur.
Climate change directly affects us all and should be a part of this discussion. Our elected leaders are acting
irresponsibly and we should not condone their behaviour. Science has shown that we are alarmingly close to
destabilizing our climate and contributing further to the ongoing mass extinction by releasing more
greenhouse gases. The last time I remember a similar situation in Canada was when scientists warned of the
fishery collapse on the east coast. As a concerned citizen, I don't want my country to push global climate
change further.
Thank you for considering these perspectives.

The Central Lake Ontario Conservation Authority (CLOCA) is a non-profit organization that works with local
communities/municipalities and regional government to conserve and protect natural resources within
south-central Ontario. CLOCA's jurisdiction covers portions of Durham Region and includes portions of
Scugog Township, City of Pickering, Town of Whitby, City of Oshawa and the Municipality of Clarington where
proposed sections of the TransCanada Eastern Mainline Project are located. CLOCA acts a regulator and
commenting agency. In addition, CLOCA is a landowner with land holdings (i.e. Conservation Areas) directly
affected by the proposed Eastern Mainline route selection (Stephen's Gulch Conservation Area). CLOCA has
interest in the specific location of the proposed pipeline route across CLOCA lands as well as natural valleys,
features and natural hazard areas regulated by CLOCA pursuant to Ontario Regulation 42/06 (Development,
Interference with Wetlands and Alteration to Shorelines and Watercourses) under the Conservation
Authorities Act. CLOCA regulates field investigation and pipeline construction activities near watercourses
and wetlands and other "Regulated Areas". CLOCA acts as a watershed manager with staff expertise relating
to Natural Heritage and Natural Hazards protection (protection of natural areas, stream & river valleys, flora
& fauna) as well as Natural Hazards such as floodplains, wetlands, unstable soils, steep slopes, storm water
management, groundwater, fisheries (fisheries impacts) sediment and erosion controls. CLOCA wishes to
share relevant data and staff expertise with the National Energy Board (NEB) and TransCanada Pipelines Ltd.
CLOCA staff have professional expertise in biology, ecology, engineering, groundwater, planning and related
disciplines. CLOCA also has relevant data related to erosion, flooding hazards, wetlands, fisheries, unstable
soils, steep slopes, groundwater (hydrogeology), hydrology, ecology, wetlands, woodlands, water resources
(source protection/drinking water resources) in the vicinity of the project. CLOCA has engaged in meetings
and data sharing since May 2014.

I am directly affected in a number of ways in this project:
-My drinking water (Montreal) is under direct threat because of the route of the pipeline.
-In the case of a massive spill, the taxpayers (myself included) will have to pay for the clean up (if there is a

infrastructure is a threat to the future of humanity. My interests in having a family and living on this planet
are directly affected by this project.
-Canada will, once there is a reasonable price on carbon, have to abandon export projects like this and the
lost time and resources of going ahead with this project will directly hinder my ability to live in a thriving
society.

Although I have not yet been directly contacted by TransCanada Pipeline concerning the routing of the
Eastern Mainline project, neighbours have indicated to me that there is a proposal to move a spur line
further north from the presently indicated route and onto my land. The portion of my property in question
was planted with trees 35 years ago. It now provides an undisturbed habitat for much wildlife including deer,
wild turkeys and a variety of amphibians in a natural swamp. This would be destroyed by pipeline
construction and operation.
If the separation requirements on the present pipeline easement were modified, based upon the significant
improvements in construction techniques and improved monitoring and safety technology developed since
the original pipelines were built, the proposed additional pipeline could be placed within the present
easement, significantly reducing the environmental impact of the construction and the long-term impact on
present landowners.

                Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
1.     Les éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques du projet proposé, notamment ceux qui
       sont décrits dans la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation environnementale.
9.     Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office.
La Chambre de commerce de l’Est de Montréal (CCEM) a pour mission de défendre et de promouvoir les
intérêts économiques et sociaux des 32 000 entreprises qui composent son territoire. Avec ses quelque 1 200
membres, la Chambre est le plus important regroupement de gens d’affaires de l’est de la métropole et
exerce son leadership afin de susciter la participation active des intervenants socioéconomiques de son
milieu. La Chambre de commerce de l’Est de Montréal couvre un vaste territoire s'étendant de l'est du
boulevard Saint-Laurent jusqu'à la pointe de l'Ile, de la rivière des Prairies jusqu'au fleuve Saint-Laurent.
La CCEM est très enthousiaste face au projet Énergie Est qui engendrera, à première vue, des retombées
pour l’emploi et l’économie, en plus de stimuler la vigueur de l’industrie pétrolière et pétrochimique
montréalaise. Elle tient cependant à ce que trois conditions soient respectées avant de donner son aval entier
:
1- le pipeline doit approvisionner directement les entreprises pétrolières situées dans l’est de Montréal
2- il doit respecter la règlementation en vigueur dans l’industrie, tant au niveau de la sécurité et de
l’environnement
3- il ne doit pas engendrer d’autres enjeux d’approvisionnement et de surcharge pour les entreprises qui
consomment notamment le gaz naturel.

 1.     The need for the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Jody Williams, Chair of the Nobel Women’s Initiative based in Ottawa, led a fact-
finding mission to the Alberta tar sands and along the proposed Northern Gateway pipeline in October 2012.
During the mission, the delegation met with over 200 women from 13 communities. The findings of the
mission are summarized here: http://nobelwomensinitiative.org/2013/12/breaking-ground-women-oil-and-
climate-change-in-alberta-and-british-columbia/.
 Women, children and communities directly affected by the tar sands development are dealing with a range
of economic, health and social impacts, including homelessness, spiraling inflation, respiratory diseases,
contaminated water, high levels of cancer rates and increased domestic violence. Affordable housing and
shelter spaces are scarce in the area, while many communities report high levels of domestic violence. In Fort
MacKay, has seen a surge in cancer rates. Women we met along the proposed Northern Gateway pipeline
fear oil spills. In Alberta alone, an average of three hundred oil pipeline spills happen every year and the
tragedy in Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, is just one example of many where communities were put at risk due to
crude oil shipping.
Upon the announcement of the proposed Energy East pipeline, Jody Williams came to Ottawa to hear from
women. First and foremost, women are concerned about the safety of the existing pipeline doubting its
ability to carry bitumen safely. Ottawa women lack trust in TransCanada’s capacity to respond to an oil spill
and are not confident in TransCanada’s commitment to pipeline safety. The women are concerned about the
impacts a pipeline spill would have on their water supply, given that Energy East would run under the Rideau
River—Ottawa residents’ water supply. Women are further concerned about TransCanada’s marketing
campaigns that often contain false information contributing to their mistrust of the company. This brief video
provides a brief glimpse into Jody Williams trip to Ottawa: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NTBfCPrACns
Women we met realize that Energy East is not an isolated project, but that new pipelines mean further
reckless expansion of the tar sands. They know the Alberta tar sands are already the most carbon intensive
project on the planet. They know that climate change brings more natural disasters, more famine and
drought, more resource scarcity and ultimately more human displacement and conflict, which again
disproportionately impacts women as they bear the brunt of poverty. They know that the impacts are
already being felt in Canada and will only increase, yet it is the world’s most vulnerable who are already
paying with their lives and livelihoods. We know that it is impossible for Canada to do its fair share to fight
climate change and allow the tar sands to expand as projected.
We urge Canada to say no to the proposed Energy East pipeline and instead invest in renewable energy
infrastructure, to be on the right side of history in moving beyond dirty oil.

Temiskaming Environmental Action Committee (TEAC) is a voluntary group of residents in Timiskaming
District who are concerned with environmental issues in their district in particular and northern Ontario more
generally. TEAC formed in 1980 around concerns with pesticide spraying, and has been active over the last
thirty five years on numerous issues in the District, including pesticide use, forest management, energy
concerns, waste management and waste import projects, and nuclear waste burial proposals.
TEAC’s interest are with respect to the environmental quality of life in Timiskaming District, and the health of
then forests, waters and land upon which Timiskaming residents – and TEAC members – rely for their health,
livelihood and recreation. The Energy East project threatens the air, land and water of the District, with risks
increased over those posed by the current natural gas. With a membership that is resident in Timiskaming
District and the majority of the population of the District living in relatively close proximity to the pipeline
corridor, TEAC has a direct local interest as people who live, own property and / or recreate or gain their
livelihoods in or near the project area, aka the pipeline. With decades of experience in environmental
research and awareness raising in Timiskaming District, TEAC offers abundant local community insights and
knowledge about a region that can be impacted by the proposed project. TEAC also intends to bring expert
evidence to the review, including evidence related to the potential for adverse impacts on the rich
agricultural area of Timiskaming known as “the little claybelt”.
The issues TEAC is primarily interested in are those realted to the potential for environmental and socio-
economic effects on Temiskaming District. These include the route and it’s proximity to features that are of
high social and environmental value, the pipeline design and integrity and the risk of pipeline failure resulting
in nnegative impacts on the environment, the plans for responding to emergencies, spills, ruptures, failures,
and accidents. These issues match with issues 7, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14 and 15 on the NEB’s List of Issues.
TEAC intends to retain an expert to evaluate the potential impact of a line failure in the agricultural region
known as the “little claybelt”. The study will evaluate impacts of pipeline in other areas and postulate what
the ecological consequences might be for the agricultural areas of southern Timiskaming District. The expert
will assess potential impacts of a line failure and subsequent release of crude oil in the little claybelt,
including an evaluation of the ecology of the area and on the agricultural values and economy in the region.
Her evaluation will include review of related sections of the TCPL application and EAS, reviewing, preparing
and responding to Information Requests as appropriate, and providing a written summary of expert findings.

By virtue of the fact that I live in a city which is on the Energy East route, I am directly affected. There could
be a spill running through the city, and surely surrounding water and food sources would be contaminated.
As an engineer, I value proper consideration of all potential problems, as well as associated contingency
plans. One idea that rarely seems to be discussed is that of double-walled pipelines. It is my understanding
that, in the nuclear industry, hazardous waste has multiple levels of containment in the case of a spill. If
similar measures were taken in the pipeline industry, actual spills into the natural environment would be a lot
less frequent. If the inner pipe burst, then the spill would be sensed and contained in the outer pipe, and
then appropriate measures can be taken to temporarily shut down the line and clean up the mess, without
having toxic oil or bitumen spilling into the natural environment.

The National Farmers Union Local 362 question the need for the Energy East project based upon negative
economic impacts for its farmer members. The project will disrupt the current economic stability and supply
of natural gas. Increasing oil exports from outside North America will increase fuel costs for farmers and for
those who supply fertilizer to farmers. Nitrogen costs, especially, will increase as they are tied directly to the
cost of petroleum.
As caretakers of the environment in the Ottawa River Valley, we are concerned about the negative impact
the project may have when a spill occurs. Using old pipe not designed for the service being asked of it is not
logical. Being underground, the pipe is not easily inspected especially for exterior corrosion. Minor leaks
could go undetected for a long enough period to contaminate the Ottawa River and underlying aquifer.
Finally, we question the incentive of private industry to adequately protect the environment as corporations
are adept at internalizing profits and externalizing costs.

 16. The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue for
       the Project
The Council of Canadians is a non-governmental organization that strongly supports the Human Right to
Water and Sanitation, which was ratified into international law by the United Nations in 2010. As such, the
Toronto Chapter of the Council of Canadians is very concerned with the threat posed by an Energy East
pipeline spill to the drinking water quality of thousands who live along the pipeline route.
In Ontario, the Energy East pipeline route crosses two primary watersheds: the Nelson River and the Great
Lakes/St. Lawrence watershed. TransCanada states it also crosses 41 “named” river crossings in Ontario. A
pipeline spill could pollute many important waterways and drinking water sources.
Energy East is proposed to carry diluted bitumen (or “dilbit”), which is composed of benzene, polycyclic
aromatic hydrocarbons, and n-hexane; toxins that can affect the human central nervous systems. The
capacity of drinking water treatment plants to safely eliminate these compounds is unknown, therefore a
dilbit spill contaminating residents source water could effectively result in their loss of potable water.
Our Council of Canadians supporters are strong advocates of our public local municipal water system - they
all drink tap water. There are thousands of Council of Canadians supporters who live along or downstream of
the proposed Energy East pipeline. The high potential of a dilbit spill posed by Energy East and the resulting
contamination of communities drinking water sources would effectively violate their Right to Water.
The Kalamazoo river, Michigan spill of Enbridge's Line 6b pipeline in 2010 showed that dilbit is heavier than
water and is far more difficult to clean up than a conventional oil spill. Dilbit, the mix of raw bitumen diluted
with condensate is unlike conventional light or heavy crude oils. The raw bitumen must be diluted with large
volumes of a natural gas condensate, or a light distillate component of gas condensate such as naptha and
heated as well to make it pumpable. Condensate diluent contains a significant amount of carcinogenic
benzene and other toxic compounds as well as hydrocarbon components such as natural gasoline, light and
heavy naphtha, kerosene, diesel and gas oil.
Upon accidental release, the volatile diluent immediately begins to flash off leaving behind an increasingly
heavy bitumen/diluent mix — a process known as “weathering” that is accelerated by
temperature, and wave action if spilled into water. The remaining residue, the original raw bitumen when
combined with organic matter forms a sludge-like material that makes clean-up very difficult, if not
impossible.
A dilbit spill in any one of the many waterways along Energy East's route could contaminate drinking water
sources, pollute fishing waters, and put an end to recreational activities – all of which would have related
negative economic impacts. Therefore, the Toronto Chapter of the Council of Canadians strongly urges the
National Energy Board to deny TransCanada's Energy East pipeline project application.
