3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
This group of farmers work on a small clay belt north of Lansdowne Ont. This area is about 6 miles long (west
to east) and about 2 miles (north to south). This is a very fragile area with 5 to 7 inches of heavy clay topsoil
and is underlaid with a heavier layer of white and blue clay. It is very hard to tile drain and must be farmed
very carefully and only tilled when it is dry. Lansdowne clay is a recognized soil type on the Ontario Soil
Maps.
In order to continue to farm our land we have a 3 point program to protect it and to continue normal farm
practices.
1. The depth of the soil cover over the pipeline must be a minimum of 1.3 metres or 50 in. In our heavy soils
this should be sufficient but in lighter soils this may require more depth.
2. Most of the land affected is systematically tile drained. Therefore, there will be lateral tile drains and some
6 in. headers to be moved or replaced. If the length of tile is more than 50-100 ft this must be done using a
lazer tile drain plow and not equipment that is already on site for the pipeline project (ie. Hy-hoe or back-hoe)
3. If the right-of-way is not tiled, but could be, this should be considered as part of the agreement. If excess
water is removed from over and around the pipe it will allow crossing of large equipment with much less
damage and risk to the pipe and the soil. Wetter soil is more succeptible to compaction and rutting. Not only
does this compaction prevent drainage of water but it also puts more down pressure on the pipe as well.
Note: Tile drains work in both winter and summer.
When the first pipelines came through our farms we were told we would be able to continue normal farm
practices over the righ-of-way. In order to continue farming, all of the above 3 points will have to be
addressed. As equipment is getting bigger, heavier and faster this will all become more critical.
These three issues were addressed but not necessarily implemented in previous pipeline installations. We
want reassurance that these will actually be completed in this project.
Richard Davis would be willing to comment and further discuss these points if called on for the hearing.

I believe I have expertise relevant, and of value, to the Board. I have a PhD in hardwood tree ecology (McGill,
1994) and extensive knowledge in the fields of forest ecology, Acadian forest history, and general ecology. I
have taught a number of courses at UNB (Faculty of Forestry and Environmental Management and
Department of Biology) covering all of these topics. I have a broad background in environmental issues
(which I have taught at St. Thomas University). I have conducted research on rare and endangered plants
(including trees and shrubs) in New Brunswick and contributed to the Department of Natural Resources' "Our
Landscape Heritage" document. I have researched different forest types in New Brunswick, including rare and
declining forest types and their importance to rare and endangered animal species. I also have expertise in
the issues surrounding invasive species (plants, insects, disease organisms, etc.), which are likely to invade
anytime new roads and pathways are cut through intact landscapes (such as New Brunswick forests) and to
which our waterways are also vulnerable.
To examine the potential impacts of the Energy East pipeline, a deep understanding of New Brunswick's
ecosystems, their major components, rare species, and overall responses to perturbation and various types
of stress (such as invasive species) is required.
I believe I can contribute to the discussion.

the province's strengths and weaknesses when it comes to managing and enforcing the protection of
waterways and wetlands - of which this pipeline will cross many times and that the province will be
responsible for long term oversight.
My masters degree thesis research focused on the Canaan-Washademoak watershed, where the pipeline is
proposed to cross a number of times. I have a good understanding of the ecological and social conditions of
the area and access to water quality and ecological data for the Canaan River and downstream
Washademoak Lake.

 1.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the proposed project, including those to be
       considered under the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act.
2.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the proposed project.
3.     Potential impacts of the proposed project on landowners and their land use.
Transport Canada (TC) is directly affected by the proposed Eastern Mainline Project (EMP). TC owns and
manages federal land, known as the Pickering Lands Site (PLS), and the proposed EMP project (Line 3) is
planned to traverse the PLS along an approximate 11 km east/west route. The PLS was acquired by the
Government of Canada in 1972 for a future airport. TC is responsible for the day-to-day management and
long-term planning of the PLS including its protection for future aviation. In the interim, the PLS has been
and is currently leased to various tenants for agricultural, residential, commercial and other uses.
Regarding Issue #1
As summarized above, TC is the federal land owner and administrator of the PLS. To date, the TransCanada
ESA has some information gaps about species at risk, if any, for the 11 km east/west route that the EMP is
planned to take across the PLS. TC will not be able to exercise any power or perform any duty or function
related to the EMP until the NEB decision statement is issued indicating that the designated project is not
likely to cause significant adverse environmental effects.
Regarding Issue #2
On June 11, 2013, the Government of Canada announced its plans for the future use and development of the
federal PLS, which included new regulations pursuant to the Aeronautics Act to protect for a smaller airport
site. The routing of the proposed EMP could interfere with planning for the protection of future aviation. TC
has had communications with TransCanada about its concerns and suggested routing changes. TransCanada
will require a right-of-way (ROW) easement from TC as well as a temporary access agreement for extra lands
that are temporarily required for the construction of EMP. TransCanada and TC have initiated discussions
about the federal legal instruments which govern occupancy of federal land (i.e. ROW/easement, temporary
access agreements, temporary work areas, and the like).
Regarding Issue #3
As summarized above, TC is the federal land owner and administrator of the PLS, and these lands are
currently leased to various tenants for agricultural, residential, commercial and other uses. The EMP will
directly affect the tenants along the 11 km pipeline route that is planned to traverse the PLS. TC and
TransCanada have initiated communications about the mitigations, reimbursement, etc. that TransCanada
plans to make for affected tenants.
Regarding “relevant information or expertise”
TC has a Civil Aviation Directorate which promotes and advances the safety of the national air transportation
system through its regulatory framework, oversight activities, and by developing policies, guidelines,
regulations, standards and educational materials. TC administers the Aeronautics Act.

11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
I do not believe that First Nations have been consulted with properly. Individual communities have been
consulted and treated as individual nations. I also do not feel I am being properly represented by advocacy
groups such as Assembly of First Nations Chiefs of New Brunswick. Chiefs of Indigenous Communities do not
have the authority outside of the jurisdiction of the perimeter of individual communities as set aside by the
Government with the Indian Act. My collective rights as a Wolastoqewiyik are being ignored. I will not have
freedom of movement to gather medicines, or utilize my ancestral land in the same way it has been used for
generations. Already ancestral hunting territory has been negatively impacted over the years evident by laws
and regulations of hunting abilities due to city limits. My ancestors USED to hunt within the now city limits of
Fredericton NB. My ability to provide food for myself and my family, such as muskrat, deer, moose, bird etc
is quickly moving further and further away from us. My ability to gather medicines and fruits will not be
freely accessible nor will they be safe to eat especially if there is a spill or incident that negatively impacts the
environment that I am trying to survive from. In the case of a spill and water is affected, this not only affects
the water way, drinking water and animals that inhabit those water ways, but wood animals, plants and
people will be affected. We can drink bottled water, however moose, deer, mice and all other animals
cannot.

I am of Alqonquin descent and I live in unceded Algonquin territory where land has been taken up without a

through land where my Nation holds underlying title.

Aboriginal rights.
 I have not been consulted by the proponents of this project which will run through my traditional territory. I
rely on a vulnerable and fragile aquifer for my drinking water and I am concerned about the impact of this
project on my water supply.

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
8.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of increased marine shipping
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
I own a house and property on Darling's Island, NB, where I've lived for over a decade. My property extends
to Darling's Lake (also known as Kennebecasis Lake), part of the Kennebecasis River system. I live in this part
of the country and province because it offers a lifestyle which includes a landscape and natural environment
relatively untouched by the direct impacts of the industrial operations of the city, Saint John, where many of
its inhabitants work. The multiple potential points of pipeline failure situated near, and passing
through/under the Kennebecasis River near Hampton, are of grave concern to me--in particular with respect
to the volume and density/composition of material to be transported. Like numerous other residents and
tourists, I canoe every year on the Kennebacasis, putting in at the bridge in Hampton. A large part of the
value of being on and near the waterway is being close to the Great Blue Herons and other birds, trout,
numerous amphibians, reptiles, and other human beings who depend on the waterway for existence and
pleasure. I have seen no evidence that provisions exist (let alone have been proposed by the project
proponent) which would with any reliability protect the waterway from the potentially catastrophic impact of
even a 10-minute spill of the proposed 1.1 million barrel a day bitumen pipeline.

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency

I was a candidate for the Green Party for Saint John Harbour in the last New Brunswick Provincial Election. I
live in the proposed terminal of the pipeline; Saint John. I have invested 56 years in New Brunswick.
I have two concerns. Having attended the information sessions and reviewed the data available to me, I
believe that the economic benefits to New Brunswick have been highly exaggerated. The safety record of
Transcanada Pipeline and its ability to respond to a catastrophic event have also been over-estimated.
Primarily, I would argue that the continued investment in a fossil fuel economy is bad for New Brunswick
because it discourages investment in other energy technologies that have less effect on the environment.
Anyone who manages a household or business knows that money spent on one thing means it is not
available for something else.
In theory, New Brunswick has chosen to develop green technologies. The New Brunswick government has
already accepted that reducing its CO2 emissions is a good thing and has set a target to reduce its outputs. It
is unlikely that it will meet these goals. The industry associated with the pipeline development will further
jeopardize the provinces ability to meet its own standards. This project runs contrary to a stated priority of
New Brunswick.
These greenhouse gas emission concerns may become insignificant in the event of a pipeline failure and spill.
Reports of spills in other centres indicate the devastation and associated financial costs. Given the shear
volume of bitumen being transported, I have been unimpressed with the company's claims of a good safety
record and its ability to sense remotely and resolve any problems within minutes.
 There are other and better energy options available

1.     Les éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques du projet proposé, notamment ceux qui
       sont décrits dans la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation environnementale.
La MRC de Témiscouata est située dans l’Est du Québec, dans la région administrative du Bas-Saint-Laurent.
Frontalière du Nouveau-Brunswick et de l’État américain du Maine, elle est bordée du côté du Québec par les
MRC de Rimouski-Neigette, des Basques, de Rivière-du-Loup et de Kamouraska. La MRC de Témiscouata
couvre une superficie de 3 921 km2 et compte 20 440 citoyens . Dix-neuf municipalités composent le
territoire de la MRC de Témiscouata. Traversé par la route Transcanadienne, le territoire est la principale voie
d’accès vers les provinces de l’Est du Canada.
La MRC de Témiscouata compte de nombreux cours d’eau sur lesquels elle a compétence exclusive, 867 plans
d’eau dont 14 de plus de 100 hectares et plus de 30 rivières d'importance. Ces cours d’eau et lacs contribuent
à créer des paysages très diversifiés et d’une grande qualité et revêtent une grande importance au niveau
environnemental, tant en milieu rural qu’en milieu urbain.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
8.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of increased marine shipping
9.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the Project
Island Quest Marine is a whale watching company that has been providing world-class whale and wildlife
tours for the past 18 years on the New Brunswick side of the Bay of Fundy. The Bay attracts thousands of
people a year to its shores and waters due to its pristine and unaltered state. We rely on a reputation of vast
amounts of wildlife, including one of the rarest animals in the world - the North Atlantic Right whale, clean
air, low boat traffic and unperturbed natural marine habitat to draw people to our area. An increase in the
amount of shipping traffic through the Bay has huge implications for marine mammals, not only through an
increase in noise pollution (which marine mammals have been shown to be very sensitive to) but also an
increase in direct ship strikes. North Atlantic Right Whales spend a lot of their time at the surface of the water
in what we call SAG’s (i.e. Surface Active Groups); they swim very slowly and can easily become a casualty of
ship strike. With a total population hovering around 500 individuals, one loss could spell ruin for an entire
species.
If a spill were to occur, the devastation to the marine life, sea birds, crustaceans and fisheries just to name a
few would be immeasurable. The Bay of Fundy is unlike anywhere else in the world, with the largest tidal
range on our planet causing mixing, a factor that makes it ideal for wildlife – also a reason why a spill would
make the Bay lethal for any and all species. Not only do we whale watch, we also Sport Fish. Our company
relies on a healthy bay to support fish populations for our guests. An unhealthy Bay (from increased boat
traffic or possible spills) would damage the reputation of our pristine Bay and decimate tourism and fishing
activity.
Our family has been fishing in the Bay of Fundy for over 5 generations. Our livelihood has transformed from
fishing into ecotourism. We have learned how to survive changing times but we would not be able to survive
a marine disaster. The Bay of Fundy is our home, it is where we raise our children and spend our lives. Oil
tanker activity that would come with the Energy East Pipeline will change the way we live our lives, operate
our business and how we make our livelihood. We are opposed to the completion of the Energy East Pipeline.

 I am presently the MP for Thunder Bay-Superior North. I have a constitutional obligation to represent my
constituents, the people of Thunder Bay - Superior North. I have spent years and months consulting with
people across the region on energy issues such as proposed pipelines, and have accumulated information and
perpectives that I feel need to be shared, and might otherwise go unheard.
I am not necessarily opposed to a West to East pipeline, but do have concerns about
some aspects of the present proposal.
As an MP, it is my job to ensure that any and all development in Canada and especially in my riding is
conducted in a way that is:
• Safe
• Sustainable
• Meets Canadian needs and interests
I am a terrestrial ecologist, biologist, and hold a Masters in Forestry and Wildlife Biology
.
Some of my former professional experience includes:
• Land use planner
• Regulator for the State of Connecticut for water and air pollution, and pesticides registration (Title: Senior
Environmental Analyst)
• Consultant on biology, forestry, wildlife, parks and protected areas
• Adjudicator, Ontario Environmental Appeal Board
Bruce Hyer

 Nous sommes des propriétaires qui avons en commun d’avoir choisi de nous établir à Saint-Antoine-de-Tilly
ou juste à la limite de cette municipalité patrimoniale sise sur le Saint-Laurent, membre de l’Association des
plus beaux villages du Québec. Nos propriétés sont toutes riveraines ou voisines du Saint-Laurent, avec une
vue directe sur ses eaux. En raison de leur cadre naturel et patrimonial exceptionnel, nos propriétés ont une
valeur élevée et représentent une part importante de nos actifs financiers respectifs. Auparavant, nous
résidions respectivement à Gatineau, Montréal, Lévis, Québec et en Suisse. Vivre en contact étroit avec le
fleuve a été un choix conscient et important pour chacun de nous et fréquenter le fleuve est au coeur de
notre quotidien. La plupart d’entre nous sommes membres des Amis du marais de Saint-Antoine-de-Tilly, un
organisme de protection du marais intertidal du Saint-Laurent. Notre mode de vie est construit autour de la
conservation et de la mise en valeur de notre patrimoine paysager, culturel, naturel et agricole.
Selon le tracé proposé, l’oléoduc franchirait le Saint-Laurent et aboutirait sur la rive sud à Saint-Nicolas, à des
distances d’environ 3 à 12 km de nos propriétés. En raison des marées, tout déversement ou toute fuite du
pipeline sous le Saint-Laurent ou à son arrivée rejoindrait immanquablement nos rives. Le tracé nuirait donc
directement à nos terrains : qu’il s’agisse de dégradation du paysage, de souillure du fleuve et de ses rives, de
dommages à l’écosystème, de privation de jouissance du fleuve ou de perte de réputation de notre village,
une telle occurrence aurait un impact substantiel voire, potentiellement, catastrophique, sur la valeur de nos
propriétés. Cela entraînerait également une détresse psychologique importante chez chacun de nous.
Nous devons également craindre les effets cumulatifs liés au fait que les risques inhérents à ce projet
s’ajouteraient aux risques de déversements liés au passage de pétroliers et superpétroliers au large de nos
rives.
Tous les membres du groupe ont une connaissance directe du dossier et des risques auxquels il expose nos
propriétés. Certains d’entre nous possédons une expertise particulière. Béatrice Riché détient un
baccalauréat en agronomie de l’Université McGill et une maîtrise en environnement de l’Université d’Oxford
(Angleterre). Elle a acquis une solide expérience internationale, notamment au sein de programmes de
protection des baleines déployés par des pétrolières. Pierre Marchildon, retraité, était haut fonctionnaire à la
Commission canadienne de sûreté nucléaire (Secrétaire général de la Commission et directeur général du
Secrétariat, et autres postes). Il est en mesure de jeter un regard éclairé sur les pratiques de gestion de
risques du projet Énergie Est, de la conception au démantèlement, de commenter les exigences
réglementaires qui s’y attachent et de faire le lien avec les risques auxquels les membres de notre groupe
sont exposés. Carole Dupuis, consultante en planification stratégique, a réalisé des analyses sectorielles pour
d’importantes institutions financières canadiennes; elle a effectué une étude qui lui permet entre autres de
répondre à la première question de l’ONE (La nécessité du projet).

   Je souhaite participer de la façon suivante :
            { Auteur d’une lettre de commentaires
            ~ Intervenant
                                             Intérêt ou expertise
            ; Je suis directement touché par le projet proposé.
               Je possède des renseignements pertinents ou une expertise appropriée.
               Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
1.     Les éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques du projet proposé, notamment ceux qui
       sont décrits dans la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation environnementale.
3.     Les répercussions possibles du projet proposé sur les propriétaires fonciers et leur utilisation des terres.
6.     La planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement, d’accident ou de défaillance durant les
       étapes de construction et d’exploitation du projet proposé.
Les déversements inévitables causés par ce pipeline ainsi que l'absence de plan d'urgence adéquat menace
grandement nos ressources d'eau potable. Les besoins du marché du pétrole ne justifient pas le risque de
contaminer irrémédiablement nos réserves d'eau potable. Si vous allez à la station service présentement, le
prix de l'essence oscille de 1$ à 1,30$ le litre. À la même station service, une bouteille d'un litre d'eau potable
se vend plus de 2$ le litre. L'or bleu est en voie de remplacer le pétrole comme moteur économique des
nations qui prospère et nous possédons l'avenir. Il est inconcevable d'échanger cet avenir contre des profits à
court terme qui n'iront aucunement dans l'amélioration de notre qualité de vie.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
9.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the Project
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention

       Project
15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
Sustainable North Grenville (SNG) was created to help raise awareness about sustainability issues in North
Grenville, and to share information with those who would like to see our community become more
sustainable. Members of SNG live along the pipeline route and are directly affected. Many of us also depend
on a water source that would be at risk of serious contamination in the event of a small, or large scale
pipeline spill in our area.
In the municipality of North Grenville, 70 per cent of its 15,000 residents have private wells that draw their
drinking water from the shallow Oxford Aquifer. This aquifer lies directly beneath the proposed pipeline
route and was classified as "highly vulnerable to pollution" (the worst rating) by the Ontario government in
the wake of the Walkerton water crisis. This is because the soil is very thin and cannot absorb much. The rock
underneath the soil is also riddled with holes and fractures, meaning liquids on the surface - like spilled crude
oil or dilbit - can leach into this important drinking water source.
The pipeline route also crosses a significant groundwater recharge area in North Grenville. These areas are
naturally formed; they allow rain and melted snow to flow down into the aquifer easily. A spill in this area
would be devastating to this highly vulnerable aquifer.
Sustainable North Grenville has worked in our community to raise awareness about this project, including
collecting 316 signatures on a petition stating: We, citizens of North Grenville, are deeply concerned about
the proposed TransCanada Energy-East pipeline to transport tar sands oil across the country and through our
community. We urge our Municipal Council to oppose the proposed pipeline until a full assessment has been
made of the potential impacts on our drinking water, air, and land, and associated risks to the Rideau River
system.

 *This application is to replace the earlier submitted application - authorized users were removed from earlier
draft*
Manitoba Energy Justice Coalition (MEJC) is a citizen's group made up of Manitobans with expertise in
sustainability, the energy sector, conservation and ecology, Aboriginal politics, and political economy. Our
group are experts in ethical energy development and have a determined stake in the economic, social, and
ecological feasibility of the project.
Our group, since it represents citizens who are property owners all along the pipeline route, especially in the
Whiteshell, St Anne, and Winnipeg Manitoba has numerous pieces of evidence regarding pipeline safety and
spill mitigation as well as insurance liability issues to bring to the board's attention.
In all communities along the pipeline route we have alternative routes and requests for pump station and
safety valve placement. We have expert knowledge in the re-purposing that must take place to make the
pipeline safe.
We wish to speak to how the project pump stations will be powered and the type of product permitted to
flow through the pipe as central questions as to the viability of the asset transfer. Our group has Aboriginal
interest issue concerns to bring to the boards attention for the question of power.
Our organization has a former public servants of Conservation, a retired biophysicist
specializing in the transportation of hazardous fuels from Pinawa nuclear facility, sustainability professionals,
an Account, a trained conservation Program and Policy Analyst, a scholar of Indigenous Governance, and a
trained wildlife biologist for fisheries, and more combining their efforts to assess the environmental impacts
of the project. Who will all be submitting their comments jointly as MEJC.
Our organization is deeply committed to climate justice and therefore believes the review of the pipeline
must be done in the context of all other energy developments in Canada. Our group aims to intervene to
discuss climate change and the economic costs of this project in the context of the tar sands as well as the
global carbon market.
As a group of Manitobans, we will be directly affected by increased water vapour in the hydrological cycle in
Manitoba which will drastically change the climate of Manitoba and have irreversible effects on the provinces
ecological and economic health. We would like to present evidence on this using our expert witnesses.

The Montreal Chapter of the Council of Canadians is very concerned about Energy East. We feel it is an
unnecessary project that will cause great harm to our environment, trample the rights of First Nations and
landowners and leave future generations with a toxic legacy.
We will submit evidence that this is the wrong project, the wrong technology and the wrong company.
Building tar sands pipelines at this point in time, knowing that we must stop burning fossil fuels as quickly as
possible to avoid catastrophic climate change, is beyond foolish. Energy East shows a malevolent disdain for
our climate as the project will allow for rapid expansion of the tar sands-some of the dirtiest oil on the planet.
Our very survival depends on immediately reducing climate change gas emissions and the NEB must play a
lead role in refusing infrastructure projects that work counter to that goal. We will submit evidence to show
that Energy East will increase Canada's green house gas emissions significantly.
TransCanada's plans to convert an old natural gas pipeline system to carry diluted bitumen is extremely
reckless. That portion of the pipeline would violate many aspects of the relevant codes if it were considered
as newly built. It was never intended to carry oil. There have been 13 ruptures on the Mainline system since
1992. Any rupture of a converted Energy East pipeline filled with diluted bitumen will cause one of the worst
environmental disasters in Canadian history. We will submit evidence concerning the history of ruptures on
the pipeline slated for conversion and the causes of the ruptures.
Since 1992, TransCanada has had as many pipeline ruptures as all other companies in Canada combined. In
the last sixteen months they have had five major pipeline ruptures. We will introduce evidence that
TransCanada is not operating in a responsible and safe manner and therefore must not be allowed to build
and operate Energy East.
We will submit evidence that shows that Energy East Pipelines will not have the financial wherewithal to pay
for a major rupture or maritime shipping leak of crude oil and that the increased amount of shipping will
cause undue risk to Canada’s maritime environment.

 Our group consists of community residents of the Taymouth area, which straddles the Nashwaak River below
a number of tributaries that will be crossed by the pipeline (Cross Creek, Arnold Creek, McGivney Creek and
more). Our members include organic vegetable farmers and grass-fed cattle farmers whose property lies
directly on the river. Any oil spill or degradation of water quality may be a direct threat to those economic
interests.
The Nashwaak River is also a salmon bearing river, and as such provides economic value to local residents
through salmon fishing tourism and threaten research being done to increase the salmon population. This
would be threatened by any degradation of water quality, as would the enjoyment of the river by local
residents who have long cultural and historic ties to the river.
Recent years have seen the growth of a ‘river tubing’ tourist business consisting of half a dozen businesses
running tube trips as well as supporting local vendors of various types. These businesses run thousands of
trips each summer and would be severely damaged by any threat to water quality, and especially an oil spill.
We are particularly concerned over the possible negative interactions between the oil pipeline and the
planned Sisson Brook Mine to be built in the same area. This mine would be the largest open-pit tungsten
mine with a vast earthen tailings pond that would be a permanent part of the landscape. The potential of
accidents at this mine to cause subsequent failures of the pipeline are of extreme concern to us.
In the larger picture, as New Brunswick residents we are very concerned about the potential for accidents in
the Bay of Fundy from the increased marine shipping of bitumen and/or finished products. The Fundy is the
heart of New Brunswick's history, culture and the very important tourist and fishing industries. Because of
the extreme tidal nature of the Fundy, a spill would be devastation on a vast scale.
It is a risk that doesn't seem to be justified by economics. As the price of oil drops, not only does bitumen
become less economical to produce, but it produces the incentive to cut costs, particularly in the areas of
maintenance and safety. This happens everywhere and often and is attested to by the many pipeline
accidents whose causes often involve lapses in these areas.
Contingency plans and emergency response appear to have stopped very few of the major spills in this
industry, and efforts of compensation are always long delayed and inadequate.
The proposed route crosses many watercourses, which no longer require an environmental impact
statement. Not only is this an absurd situation, but it makes one suspicious of the nature of adequate
planning for a project crossing thousands of kilometres, using not only new pipe, but refurbished and re-
purposed old pipe.

Brunswick. Because of the nature of my work I have a broad and deep understanding of the environmental
conditions, policy framework, enforcement capacity and history of issues in New Brunswick, especially as
they pertain to waterways and wetlands of the province.
I have an good understanding of the federal environmental review process and was recently involved in the
Canadian Environmental Assessment Agency's review of the Sisson Brook tungsten and molybdenum mine in
New Brunswick, reviewing the sections related to stream and wetland impacts.
I sit on the province's "Long Term Wetland Management" stakeholder committee and am very familiar with
the province's strengths and weaknesses when it comes to managing and enforcing the protection of
waterways and wetlands - of which this pipeline will cross many times and that the province will be
responsible for long term oversight.
My masters degree thesis research focused on the Canaan-Washademoak watershed, where the pipeline is
proposed to cross a number of times. I have a good understanding of the ecological and social conditions of
the area and access to water quality and ecological data for the Canaan River and downstream
Washademoak Lake.

I live several kilometres downstream from where the Energy East pipeline would cross the Rideau River in
Ottawa. I am concerned that a pipeline spill would impact on the river (a 5-minute walking distance from my
home), the park and the recreational opportunities offered by the river and park (such as canoeing,
swimming and nature-watching). I am also concerned by the climate change impacts of the pipeline which
directly impact all of us. There is no separating the carbon emissions required to fill the pipeline from climate
change and its impacts on all of us now and in the future.

 1.     The need for the Project

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
The Green Party of Ontario (GPO) has an obligation to speak out on issues that concern our members and the
233,269 Ontarians who voted for the party in the 2014 provincial election.
The GPO’s members and supporters have serious concerns about how this project will affect the health and
well-being of the people of Ontario and our natural environment.
Our members hold a plethora of qualifications on this issue— professional economists, experts in the energy
field & clean-tech sector, teachers, health care professionals, community activists, politicians, citizens,
organizers, lawyers, etc.
Many of our supporters are concerned by the increasing number of pipeline spills and the effect these spills
have on our environment and health. The GPO has an obligation to ensure that the health and safety of
Ontarians and the province’s natural heritage and environmental services, especially our drinking water, are
protected.
The externalized costs of run-away climate change caused by projects such as these must be considered.
Every person in Ontario will be negatively affected by climate change. At a time when the provincial
government is seeking public input on a comprehensive strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 15%
below 1990 levels by 2020 and 80% below 1990 levels by 2050, it is critically important for Ontario’s economy
and environment that energy infrastructure projects not increase GHG pollution.
We also need to consider the economic risks of stranded assets if we continue to sink capital into new fossil
fuel infrastructure. Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, has warned of the financial risks of
stranded fossil fuel assets that could undermine the stability of our economy.
The GPO has a unique and relevant perspective on this project. We look forward to sharing and representing
the views of our members and supporters on this important issue.

                Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
8.     Les effets environnementaux et socio-économiques pouvant découler d’un accroissement des activités
       de transport maritime
9.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet
12. L’incidence possible du projet sur les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement touchés et sur leur
       utilisation des terres
13. La sécurité et la sûreté associées à la construction et à l’exploitation du projet, y compris la planification
       de l’intervention d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés par des tiers
14. La planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement, d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les
       travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
15. Les répercussions financières de la planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement,
       d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
16. Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office à l’égard du
       projet
Depuis avril 2011, j’occupe la fonction le 4e vice président du Conseil central des syndicats nationaux des
Laurentides et j’ai, sous ma responsabilité, le dossier de l’environnement. C’est à ce titre que je demande à
l’Office de déposer une lettre de commentaires au sujet des inquiétudes de près des 15 000 membres que
nous représentons dans les Laurentides.
Un nombre important de nos membres a démontré des préoccupations concernant le projet proposé par
Oléoduc Énergie Est Ltée. Le Comité Exécutif du CCSNL (CSN) a recensé ces préoccupations et a établi des
recommandations, selon la volonté des membres, afin d'être entendu devant les autorités compétentes, en
l'occurrence l'Office National de l'énergie.
Je tenterai d’expliquer à l’Office les préoccupations des membres au sujet des effets environnementaux, du
tracé dans les Basses Laurentides, des mesures de sécurité ainsi que de la solvabilité de TransCanada en cas
de déversement. Je m’efforcerai d’émettre des recommandations et des solutions afin que l’Office National
de l’Énergie prenne une décision à l’égard des membres-citoyens des Basses Laurentides.

1.     The need for the Project
2.     The economic feasibility of the Project
3.     The commercial, economic, supply and market impacts of the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
1 - As the project will primarily serve oil shippers moving the product to foreign buyers, I do not see the need
for this project. I am not convinced of the projected increase in energy requirements due to the current
financial climate, or that, even if these increases were to occur, that this project would meet the growing
energy needs of Quebec over other possible energy projects and investments.
2 - Eastern Canadian refineries cannot refine bitumen without considerable investment to retrofit their
facilities. I am concerned that these costs will be passed on indirectly to the tax-payer in an already difficult
economic climate without any guarantee of reduced prices on energy or royalties to the people of the
province of Quebec.
3 - Some of Rigaud's primary economic activities include agriculture and eco-tourism. Although the
construction of the pipeline might create temporary jobs, the construction process, which will include a large
increase in noise pollution, increased traffic, wear on our roads, the disturbance of natural habitat, as well as
the potential for spills, leaks and/or explosions will reduce tourist dollars and lower the values of our
properties.
7 - I am concerned that the ability to detect leaks and clean-up after spills in a timely manner has not been
thoroughly planned and prepared for (not to mention sorting out who will pay for such occurrences), and
such events can lead to the contamination of our drinking water and soil, as well as compromise our abilities
to fish and use our water for recreational activities.
12 - Without a rigorous environmental assessment process, without owners’ consent and without a polluter-
pays principle, landowners are at-risk.

I am affected as a resident of South Winnipeg, living within several miles of the pipeline. As a father and
grandfather of a family all located in Winnipeg, I do not want to be exposed to the risk of a rupture that could
release poisonous sulphur gas into our atmosphere.
 I am also concerned about the possible spill of bitumen finding its way into the Red River which comes within
100 yards of our house, and which then empties into Lake Winnipeg, where our cottage is located.
Further, the pipeline goes near to the lake that Winnipeg gets its drinking water from.
Finally, (and unfortunately beyond your scope), I do not want to accept any environmental or human risk for
the development of an energy source which will contribute to climate change.

       Project
As a landowner living beside the Saint John River, I am very concerned by the large number of water crossings
of tributaries into the Saint John River for the proposed Energy East pipeline. The nature of the Alberta Tar
Sands bitumen will make it impossible for spills to be thoroughly cleaned up in waterways. The Kalamazoo
River in Michigan still has 600,000 litres of bitumen at the bottom of the riverbed from the spill in 2010.
What would this do to the Saint John River and the many landowners like myself that depend on well water
for drinking and for growing food gardens?
Sea-level rise affecting the height of the Saint John River, as well as catastrophic storms, are two of my many
concerns about climate change. This pipeline should not be allowed to be built since it will directly allow for
the expansion of the Alberta Tar Sands and greatly increased greenhouse gas pollution. We can't commit to
this type of fossil fuel infrastructure for the next 40 years when the United Nations IPCC 5th Report states
that we must immediately transition to building efficiency and clean energy if we hope to keep global
temperatures below a 2 degrees Celsius rise.

 Ottawa Riverkeeper (ORK) is a licensed member of Waterkeeper Alliance, a coalition of over 200 groups
worldwide working for clean and accessible water. Led by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Waterkeeper Alliance is a
global movement of on-the-water advocates who patrol and protect over 160,000 kilometres of rivers,
streams, and coastlines. Waterkeepers are authoritative voices on issues affecting swimming, drinking,
water, and fish/fish habitat in our watersheds.
Founded in 2001, ORK is a grassroots charity formed to protect, promote, and improve the health of the
Ottawa River watershed. ORK works to inspire others to take action, to encourage responsible decision
making, to hold polluters accountable and to recommend alternative practices and policies to safeguard our
local waterways. We are first responders on the river to investigate spills and harmful pollution that may
impact aquatic life and public health.
ORK works with communities to facilitate the use of environmental laws to protect their rights to swim, drink,
and fish. We participate in legal processes to improve environmental decisions by including independent
research and evidence and advocating on behalf of the public’s interest in clean and healthy waters. ORK has
participated in consultations under the Species at Risk Act, the Navigable Waters Protection Act, and the
Fisheries Act, in decisions by the Ontario Ministry of the Environment under the Environmental Bill of Rights,
as well as in hearings before the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission. We have substantial experience
facilitating expert research, providing recommendations on terms and conditions, evaluating risks to
watersheds and/or community values, and understanding grassroots impacts of project proposals.
ORK has regional knowledge gained through research, investigations, and experience that would be
invaluable to the Board. We have specialist knowledge and experience related to impacts on water quality,
navigation, fish biology, swimming, boating, and fishing in our watershed. The information we will provide to
the Board is within the project scope and related to the list of issues. Our comment will add significant value
to the Board’s decision or recommendations.
For Issue #7, we will provide information on potential impacts of the project on water quality, aquatic
habitat, and navigation. This will include information on the potential impacts of fuel spills or leaks and
cumulative impacts on creeks, rivers, and lakes in our watershed.
For Issue #10, we will provide information relevant to the integrity of the pipeline as it relates to capacity to
carry heavy crude without impacting the environment, specifically water quality.
For Issues #13 and #14, we will provide information relating to spill prevention and response, specifically
focussing on the regional challenges responding to spills, impacts of potential spills on watercourses, and
mitigation of impacts on habitat and water quality.
For Issue #16, for the Board’s consideration, we will include suggested terms and conditions, where
appropriate, to address or mitigate the effects on water quality, habitat, and navigation described above.

Whereas Ms. Tremblay-Deveau owns acreage on Whale Cove of Grand Manan Island in the Bay of Fundy, and
whereas said property is adjacent to the shipping lane where bitumen will be transported from the proposed
marine terminal on the Bay of Fundy, her concerns include but are not limited to the following: increased
marine traffic, environmental effects of accidents, and cumulative impacts resulting from another major oil
and gas project in this area. This is especially relevant since the property in question is encumbered by a
conservation easement registered with Environment Canada as ecologically sensitive land. Ms. Tremblay-
Deveau (along with her spouse JL Deveau) are also stewards of the Meredith Houseworth Memorial Seashore
(MHMS) which is also registered federally with Environment Canada as an ecologically sensitive land and
provincially as an Environmentally Significant Area. The MHMS abuts the aforementioned property.

 7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
9.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the Project
10. The engineering design and integrity of the Project
We are a member based environmental organization. Our Manitoba office is located in Winnipeg. We have
thousands of members and supporters in Winnipeg. The pipeline crosses within a few kilometers of the city,
and crosses the Red, Assinaboine, and La Salle River just upstream from the city. Any leak or spill will affect us
and our members and supporters directly.
We are an independent environmental watchdog organization. We routinely audit the environmental
assessments and Environment Act applications for industrial projects across the province. We are one of the
only organizations to do so. From mining to logging to commercial building, we examine the documents filed
which describe the impacts of a given project on the lands and waters and species, and then publicize our
analysis, so an informed decision can be made by the general public. As such, our expertise in analyzing the
impacts of this project in relation to other industrial operations in the province is a valuable addition to a
robust NEB hearing process.
We are a voice for provincial park protection in Manitoba. This project is proposed to cross Whiteshell
Provincial Park. We have worked in Whiteshell Provincial Park since 1999, investigating the impacts of
development and industrial activity, publicizing the risks to the integrity of a natural park, leading groups to
witness the wilderness first hand, and providing recommendations to the provincial government on added
protection for the park. Thousands of hectares of land in Whiteshell has been protected due to our work. We
have relevant expertise on plans for development in Whiteshell Provincial Park.

J’ai plusieurs inquiétudes au sujet du projet proposé par Oléoduc Énergie Est Ltée, pour lequel cette
compagnie souhaite obtenir les autorisations afin de construire et exploiter un réseau de pipeline de 4 500
km et dont une partie passerait sur le territoire de ma municipalité.
L’approbation du projet envisagé par TransCanada, soumis à l’ONÉ, peut avoir des effets directs sur la qualité
de vie de tous les Anneplainois, sur nos ressources en eau potable ainsi que sur la valeur de nos demeures
dans la probabilité d’un déversement pétrolifère.
Je tenterai d’expliquer à l’office mes préoccupations au sujet des effets environnementaux, du tracé sur le
territoire de Sainte-Anne-des-Plaines, des mesures de sécurité ainsi que de la solvabilité de TransCanada en
cas de déversement. Je m’efforcerai d’émettre des recommandations et des solutions afin que l’Office
National de l’Énergie prenne une décision à l’égard des citoyens inquiets à Ste-Anne-des-Plaines.

My wife and I live on Falcon Lake within one mile of the pipeline close to the city of Winnipeg drinking water
aqueduct at Shoal Lake.
Simply
1. I am not convinced that it is safe or sustainable to repurpose a new or used pipeline designed and built for
natural gas to be used for Dilbit.
2. I am not convinced that the criteria used for the environmental scrutiny of a natural gas pipeline is the
same for Dilbit.
3. I am not convinced that it is safe to operate multiple gas pipelines in the same proximity of a Dilbit pipeline.
In my mind these questions are major concerns to the safety and feasibility of this initiative.

 1.     The need for the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
8.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of increased marine shipping
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
16. The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue for
       the Project
I am a Registered Nurse and in my training and work have learned that the physical environment is an
important determinant of health.
Saint John has a large share of industry that already poses risks to its citizens. Many of our citizens suffer
from asthma and lung cancer. These risks will be increased by bringing bitumen and other substances mixed
with it. The plan to build large storage tanks that will contain these chemicals and will release toxic
substances into the air, will only contribute to the increased risk to the people in this city.
The risk of pipelines rupturing and spilling these chemicals into many of the waterways that will cross in this
province, is also a grave concern to me. Our family, as many of our citizens, boats and swims in these waters.
I know from reading and listening to experts, that the proposed pipeline and the amount of bitumen that is
planned to carry, will significantly contribute to tar sands expansion and therefore will contribute to our
country’s greenhouse emissions. As a citizen, I have an obligation to address climate change. And to demand
that the government that represents me, also does.
My children and grandchildren live in this city and any project that plans to increase the risk to their health,
forces me to get involved and say no to this project.
I have friends and know people who own property on the proposed path of the pipeline and who are already
suffering a great deal of psychological stress from the potential that a pipeline spill may wipe out their life
support. We need to promote energy projects that protect our environment and therefore our health.
Our country, province, planet, do not need a project that will jeopardize water, people and the environment
instead of benefiting us.

13. La sécurité et la sûreté associées à la construction et à l’exploitation du projet, y compris la planification
       de l’intervention d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés par des tiers
14. La planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement, d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les
       travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
15. Les répercussions financières de la planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement,
       d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
16. Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office à l’égard du
       projet
J’ai plusieurs inquiétudes au sujet du projet proposé par Oléoduc Énergie Est Ltée, pour lequel cette
compagnie souhaite obtenir les autorisations afin de construire et exploiter un réseau de pipeline de 4 500
km et dont une partie passerait sur le territoire de ma municipalité.
L’approbation du projet envisagé par TransCanada, soumis à l’ONÉ, peut avoir des effets directs sur la qualité
de vie de tous les Anneplainois, sur nos ressources en eau potable ainsi que sur la valeur de nos demeures
dans la probabilité d’un déversement pétrolifère.
Je tenterai d’expliquer à l’office mes préoccupations au sujet des effets environnementaux, du tracé sur le
territoire de Sainte-Anne-des-Plaines, des mesures de sécurité ainsi que de la solvabilité de TransCanada en
cas de déversement. Je m’efforcerai d’émettre des recommandations et des solutions afin que l’Office
National de l’Énergie prenne une décision à l’égard des citoyens inquiets à Ste-Anne-des-Plaines.

Les déversements inévitables causés par ce pipeline ainsi que l'absence de plan d'urgence adéquat menace
grandement nos ressources d'eau potable. Les besoins du marché du pétrole ne justifient pas le risque de
contaminer irrémédiablement nos réserves d'eau potable. Si vous allez à la station service présentement, le
prix de l'essence oscille de 1$ à 1,30$ le litre. À la même station service, une bouteille d'un litre d'eau potable
se vend plus de 2$ le litre. L'or bleu est en voie de remplacer le pétrole comme moteur économique des
nations qui prospère et nous possédons l'avenir. Il est inconcevable d'échanger cet avenir contre des profits à
court terme qui n'iront aucunement dans l'amélioration de notre qualité de vie.

 I am a Mother of a young family that lives in a city where water surrounds us everywhere, it is integrated into
our daily lives. It is critical that we continue to ensure a clean and reliable water supply which allows us to
continue pursuing regular recreational activities such as walking, wildlife viewing, canoeing and fishing with
my family and my children. Living in the South end of the City of Winnipeg any failures of the proposed
pipeline would have devastating effects on our daily lives as our children attend school, daycare, participate
in recreational activities and my family are employed in the area.
Having engaged with subject matter experts on the issue I have been educated on the risks and potential
adverse effects that a spill or explosion could have on the very fabric of my society in the city I call home,
Winnipeg. Friends we know work off the land in St. Norbert which is a major supplier to the City of Winnipeg
for farm fresh local produce.
The following risks exist for all for my community within the City of Winnipeg which make my family and I
Directly Affected persons.
1. Repurposing an existing natural gas line and the increased risk of fire and explosion due to close proximity
to nearby parallel natural gas lines
2. High failure rate of TC lines Canada based off historical track record
3. TC’s sole reliance on “smart pigs” which have been proven to be ineffective compared to manual
inspection in line error detection combined with ineffective pressure monitoring from Edmonton to prevent
failures
4. Potential risk to many communities drinking water if the key aquifers Assiniboine Delta and the Sandilands
Aquifer are ever affected
5. Extensive drainage into the LaSalle and Seine Rivers near Winnipeg which would extend the spill reach far
beyond city boundaries rendering ineffective shut-off valve protection
6. Dilbit spill issues include both risk from toxic fumes causing evacuation and extreme difficulty to clean the
environment effectively as seen in the Kalamazoo spill
7. Contamination to the food chain and associated long term ecological damage
8. Bill C-46 extending liability protection for pipeline spills is not yet passed and that the EE subsidiary bears
the spill liability not TC,
9. The use of corrosive Sulphur and hydrogen sulphide (H2S) to assist in moving bitumen which will corrode
the line internally potentially leading to the release of a deadly toxic gas.
10. Potential impacts to traditional Aboriginal land use and way of life.
Climate impacts of Energy East affects the majority of the listed issues
The economic feasibility of this project is tightly connected to the world markets as seen with the low price of
oil
For these reasons mentioned above NEB is obligated to include climate change in its review of Energy East. As
a regulator the NEB has a responsibility to people of Canada to include all relevant information in its review
process.

 2.     The economic feasibility of the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
Regarding #2 - The economic feasibility: as a graduate student (now holding a MA in Native Studies from U of
Manitoba), I had the opportunity to partake in and publish through a SSHRC-funded research project out of
the U of Saskatchewan's Centre for the Study of Cooperatives, called Linking, Leveraging and Learning. My
research enabled me to interview members of 2 first nations in the Manitoban region known as Waabanong
Nakaygum, or 'east side,' comprising the east side of Lake Winnipeg. My writings focused on social economy
- also known as the 'third sector' economy - that is underdeveloped in Canada in comparison to much of the
OECD, though it is strongest in Quebec. The social economy is an underutilized policy tool for First Nations
development and I believe that further private sector development on native lands will undermine its
potential both through creating environmental threats but also further an already fractured land use
tradition among First Nations communities that could serve as the foundation for this development.
#7 - The potential environmental and socio-economic effects: I have 15 years of research experience within
the ecological movement and have been studying systems-level design in terms of both bioregional planning
(according to watershed) and cutting edge thought on 'systems as organisms.' I believe the hydrology of
much of the country and especially within the Lake Winnipeg basin has been so heavily damaged and is
verging on being if not already beyond human control, as evidenced by continued algal blooms due to
eutrophication in Lake Winnipeg; by shoreline erosion due to hydroelectric-caused fluctuating water levels;
and by repeated floods such as those recently displacing members of multiple First Nations and other
communities, i.e. the Lake St. Martin and Lake Manitoba floods. I do not believe the watershed can sustain
increased industrial pressure or face further possible pollution. I include mercury issues unresolved in the
watershed, east of Manitoba along the English-Wabigoon river system and mercury released from large
hydroelectric dams.
#11 - Potential impacts on Aboriginal interests: While I have already mentioned First Nations' lands and
economies in the above, this point speaks generally to the diverse positions of various First Nations in
Manitoba and Ontario directly affected by the route of the pipeline and also more broadly affected by the
threat of a possible spill. My thesis dealt with the cultural and economic impacts of the construction of all-
weather roads, primarily on the east side of Lake Winnipeg, in the boreal ecosystem that this pipeline will
traverse. Among clearcut logging, road-construction, cottage-construction, over-fishing, poaching, hydro line
construction, mining, and now pipelines traversing their lands, many of the First Nations community
members with whom I spoke have expressed a sense of being under attack, their lands being fragmented
further, and their cultural geographic memories and practices being threatened. These feelings, for a
community still reeling from the intergenerational impacts of residential schools, cannot be underestimated
in their overall further oppression of First Nations' interests as equal partners under Treaty in Canada.

I am the proprietor of the Tranquil Acres Inc., a therapeutic equestrian centre in Kars Ontario. It is a centre
for people in the Ottawa area with varying social, emotional and mental health needs who want to
experience the transformative powers of horses as teachers and healers. We offer Equine Assisted Learning
(EAL) sessions and workshops aimed at promoting personal and professional growth and development as
well as Equine Assisted Psychotherapy (EAP) sessions.
My property is adjunct to a wetland that TransCanada's proposed Energy East pipeline traverses. The natural
gas pipeline proposed for conversion is ten to twenty feet from my property line.
Tranquil Acres Inc. property is on a lower plain than the area the pipeline traverses. Were there a pipeline
rupture, small or large, it would present a serious risk to our ability to use the land that sustains our business
and provides an important service to people in need. It would also pose a contamination risk to our water
source.

 1.     Les éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques du projet proposé, notamment ceux qui
       sont décrits dans la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation environnementale.

       étapes de construction et d’exploitation du projet proposé.
7.     La sécurité et la sûreté durant les étapes de construction et d’exploitation du projet proposé,
       notamment la planification des interventions en cas d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés
       par des tiers
9.     Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office.
L'Association francophone des municipalités du Nouveau-Brunswick (AFMNB) regroupe 53 municipalités
francophones et bilingues, réparties dans cinq grandes régions qui s’étendent du Nord-Ouest au Sud-Est de la
province. Nos municipalités membres représentent plus de 280 000 personnes, soit plus du tiers de la
population du Nouveau-Brunswick.
Notre intérêt réside dans l'impact potentiel de ce projet sur nos municipalités, dont plusieurs sont situées aux
abords du tracé proposé, principalement dans le Nord-Ouest de la province (Edmundston, Grand-Sault, St-
Léonard, St-François, St-Anne, Lac Baker, Baker Brook, Clair, St-Hilaire, Rivière-Verte, St-André, Drummond).
Pertinence du tracé et planification des mesures d'urgence
Une grande partie de la responsabilité de la planification des mesures d'urgences au niveau local (municipal)
et régional (Commissions de services régionaux) revient aux municipalités, et celles-ci sont directement
responsables des services de sécurité et incendie qui seraient les premiers répondants en cas de
déversement, d'accident ou de défaillance, que ce soit pendant la construction ou l'exploitation du projet
proposé. Ainsi, nous serons directement affectés par toute décision relative au tracé proposé, et à la
planification de l'intervention et des mesures d'urgence. Le projet pourrait d'ailleurs entraîner des coûts
financiers additionnels pour nos municipalités au niveau de la planification des mesures d'urgences et de la
formation des premiers répondants.
Éventuels effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques
Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques qui résulteraient de la construction du projet proposé ou
encore de potentiels déversements, accidents ou défaillances lors de l'exploitation ont de plus le potentiel
d'affecter les sources d'eau potables des municipalités et la qualité de vie des citoyens des municipalités de la
région.
Conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation
Nous ferons également des recommandations à propos des mesures permettant d’éviter ou de contrôler les
problèmes cités ci-dessus. Nous ferons aussi des recommandations à propos des modalités et conditions qui
devraient être prises en considération dans le cas où l’ONE en viendrait à recommander l’approbation du
projet.

As a citizen of North Bay, I would be directly affected by the proposed pipeline. I live near the pipeline route.
The pipeline actually crosses part of Trout Lake, the source of the City's water supply. Pipelines do leak, and
even a small amount of toxic diluted bitumen in our drinking water would contaminate it forever. The lake
would also no longer be safe for swimming. My property value would plummet. Local scientists and engineers
have proven that Trans Canada's safety claims are based on false statements. Trans Canada does not fully
understand local water currents, topography or water systems. Shut downs after a leak detection should be
immediate. Even then the drain down leakage would be massive and even small amounts in the water supply
would be disastrous. Is Trans Canada willing to supply a city the size of North Bay with an alternate source of
water in perpetuity? Does it have the financial capability to take on such remedial action? Is it willing to and
financially capable of removing the entire length of pipeline once it has outlived its usefulness, or will it allow
residue to corrode the pipeline and pollute the ground?
Emergency response plans MUST be part of the application and be highly scrutinized BEFORE approval of the
project.
The Mowat Centre concluded that the economic benefits of the pipeline would be minimal, especially in
Northern Ontario.
I therefore plan to address economic, financial, safety and environmental issues in my comments.

Issues #1 & 4: WDFN’s submissions will describe: (i) our Aboriginal title and rights; (ii) the location of our
traditional territory; and (iii) the spatial and temporal extent of our use of land, water, and resources for
traditional purposes therein. As stated above, the “1857 Arrowsmith map” outlines the areas that we have
used for centuries.
The Project is located adjacent to the South Saskatchewan River, which is a large source of freshwater for all
of Saskatchewan. It also has historical value to the Dakota people. The South Saskatchewan, Qu’Appelle,
Assiniboine, and Souris Rivers were and remain a major transportation route for our people. The South
Saskatchewan River continues to provide subsistence for us. It is one of our major fishing sites. Thus, WDFN
would like to provide further information on the traditional use of these areas as part of the NEB Hearing
process, as well and receive information in order to understand the potential impacts of the Project.
The proposed Project has the potential to cause adverse environmental effects in WDFN’s traditional
territory and therefore has the potential to adversely impact WDFN’s territory, as well as our Aboriginal title
and rights. In particular, an oil spill from the Project has the potential to harm our natural resources and
traditional territory, including the South Saskatchewan River and the water bodies in the vicinity of, and
downstream, of the Project. An oil spill would negatively impact WDFN’s use of land, water, and resources in
our traditional territory.
Project construction and operation also have the potential to adversely impact our Aboriginal title, rights, and
interests. Aboriginal title has an economic component. WDFN’s economic interest in our title lands will
therefore need to be accommodated.
WDFN’s evidence and submissions will describe potential environmental effects resulting from the Project
and corresponding impacts to our Aboriginal title and rights. They will also discuss cultural sustainability and
economic participation in the Project, including employment, procurement and contracting opportunities
provided by TransCanada.
Issue #6 & 7: WDFN will make submissions about contingency planning and emergency response for oil spills
during construction and operation of the Project. In particular, the traditional knowledge and traditional land
and water use information we will share with TransCanada and the NEB will help inform contingency
planning and emergency response for oil spills. For example, our traditional land use information could be
included in TransCanada's emergency response plans and maps as high consequence areas. Use and
occupancy sites could also be included in TransCanada’s Intelligent Valve Placement (IVP) modeling.

 As land/property co-owners of 404 Pipeline Road, Grafton which is situated directly accross Pipeline Road
from Station 136-Cobourg, our interests are immensely impacted by this application to further develop the
site as part of the Eastern Mainline Application.
Our chief concerns are the impact on our property value and enjoyment of our home/property due to this
proposed increased intensification of development of the site. Discussions have been ongoing with Matthew
Tully, Project Manager Compression Projects at TransCanada as to our concerns regarding additional sound,
light and visual impacts of the proposed development. From a property value impact, our property value
stands to suffer the most negative direct impact of any property in the area if the above concerns are not
addressed in both the planning and execution of this project at Station 136. To date we have been given
verbal confirmation that these concerns will be addressed fully in the execution of the project. It would be
most helpful if your panel would include provisions in its final terms and conditions which would address
these impacts on property owners most directly impacted by this development. As our property at 404
Pipeline Road does not include lands which the pipeline will need to pass through for development, we are
not included in the automatic negotiation process which could be employed to address our concerns. We are
instead reliant on the terms and conditions of the NEB ruling and the goodwill gestures of TransCanada to
ensure that this development does not have a massive negative impact to the future saleability and value of
our property.
Our assumption is that due to the nature of the construction involved at Station 136 and the length of time
that this project will require, the terms and conditions that your panel includes in its ruling will be extremely
rigorous when it addresses safety issues as outlined in List of Issues #5 and #6 above. This is of utmost
concern to us due to our property being situated directly accross the road from the northern property line of
Station 136. Note that the location of the full concentration of both exisiting and proposed development on
this site is situated extremely near to the Pipeline Road property border.
Thanking you in advance for your consideration of our Commentor submission to your panel regarding the
Eastern Mainline Proposal.
Daredra Beswick & Jeffrey Hunt

Grafton, Ontario K0K 1G0

Green Timiskaming is developing affordable housing which will be using water from Lake Timiskaming that is
supplied by the Blanch River. The Blanch River is crossed by the pipe line in a large drop crossing where the
pipe line drops over 150 feet to the crossing. This type of crossing could result in substantial contamination
to down stream water supplies. Our direct concerns arises with the potential long term loss of a single
source water supply for the community which we are investing in.
With such an extensive length and the potential for many leaks we are concerned that there would be
inadequate financial resources to fully clean up or compensate for damages that are created.
We are concerned that the separation of assets from Trans Canada will limit the liability available for
compensation from those that are benefiting from the project leading to lackadaisical operations. This will
lead to additional damages and losses to people and organization in the province.
As a experienced corrosion engineer on the Trans Canada pipe line I fear that the pipeline is being pushed
well passed its capacity as a gas pipeline.
We are concerned that an adequate breadth of recommendations needs to be developed that would ensure
the monitored safe operation of the pipeline as well as an adequate level of secured financial resources to
ensure that damages and environmental degradation are not downloaded to those who are receiving no
benefits.

517 Tenth Avenue SW                                                                          Telephone/Téléphone : (403) 292-4800
Calgary, Alberta T2R 0A8                                                                      Facsimile/Télécopieur : (403) 292-5503
