 13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
16. The terms and conditions to be included in any recommendation or approval the Board may issue for
       the Project
Council of Canadians is a national organization that is active in the research of environmental hazards
resulting from a dilbit spill. Among many other issues related to environmental protection, it focuses on the
integrity of the pipelines operated by the proponent. It’s York University chapter is part of this research
effort. Members of York University chapter comprise of scholars and faculty members from the Faculty of
Environment Studies and Osgoode Law School. They have both graduate and postgraduate degree standings
that include expertise in political science, environmental science and law. The various experts in this
organization will provide detailed analysis of the issues to which we will address. Our objective is to prepare a
comprehensive report focusing on the cumulative effects of this pipeline.
An oil spill from this pipeline will adversely affect the health of individuals living in close proximity of this
pipeline. A spill will contaminate the water reservoirs and air with toxins. This in turn will jeopardize the
health of individuals who intake the polluted water and air. The various health issues amongst individuals will
incapacitate them from performing daily operations. This effect inevitably affects the economic function of
the societies living along the line. The evidence of this underlining condition is already observed in the
Kalamazoo oil spill disaster. Council of Canadians - York University chapter will bring forth this evidence to
illustrate the scope of a potential spill disaster along the entire pipeline.
We will also illustrate the spatial extent of a spill scenario. We argue that an oil spill from this pipeline will
adversely affect the health of individuals living elsewhere, irrespective of their proximity to the pipeline. The
argument is based on the understanding of nature of things. We recognize water and air to be a medium of
transport and therefore generate a hypothesis that the contaminated water and air has a potential to
transcend into communities beyond the visions of this hearing. This argument will be supported by empirical
evidence and scientific journals. The complex interconnections between both biophysical and human
environment extends globally and thus not confined to a defined boundary. The environment in this context
has no boundaries.
We are concerned that an approval of this application will incubate a disaster (Financial, Social and
Environmental) for which EEPL Ltd. and the Government of Canada have no emergency response plan in
place. If given the opportunity we will investigate the scope of a potential disaster along the pipeline. This
pipeline gives the illusion of an economic growth. However, we think that our nation’s resources should be
invested in renewable technologies. The infamous Kalamazoo disaster was a result of cumulative negligence
which had cumulative and cascading effects to the well being of the entire nation. We want to ensure that
NEB does its due diligence by being an integral part of this application process.

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative

I am directly affected by the proposed Energy East pipeline because I am a citizen of this country and an
occupier of this land. The Energy Easy pipeline route is completely inappropriate, because it passes through
many rivers and waterways which I enjoy as a Canadian citizen. Because the pipeline crosses the Red River
and the Assiniboine River in Winnipeg, MB (my hometown), any spills or leaks that will inevitably come as a
result of the pipeline will flow upstream into the city of Winnipeg, contaminating the water for the entire city
and all the townships along the river. Spills and leaks would also affect the Seine River, the most beautiful
river we have in the city. I personally use the rivers as I spend my summers canoeing both on the Red River
and on the Seine river. The Red River runs right down the centre of the city and would affect millions of
people along only that river alone. This proposed pipeline affects me directly because I want my children to
grow up in a world that is clean and protected. I want my children to grow up in a world that is not dictated
by selfish corporate interests who are only interested in profit and care nothing for human health and human
lives, which are inextricably linked with the environment. I use these rivers every single week in the summers,
and often walk across, ski across or skate across them in the winter. I engage in recreational fishing, and any
spills and leaks from the pipeline will wipe out all the living creatures living in the rivers. I cannot see any
sense in polluting our rivers for ever for presumed economic benefits, which are false to begin with because
the energy output does not outweigh the input.

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency

I am a landowner on James Lake with a tourism business, which depends on maintaining clean wilderness
values. Simply put, the pipeline is bad for business. But my concern extends beyond my personal use and
dependence on a livelihood.
Temagami depends on its tourism industry. The pipeline through Temagami (and elsewhere) is a disaster
waiting to happen.
My concerns are that the pipeline was designed for natural gas. And this pipeline is old. Converting this
pipeline to transport bitumen is not acceptable. Bitumen is corrosive and the experts say will erode the
existing pipe. Corrosion will be accelerated at bends in the pipeline such as at each water crossing,
exacerbating the potential damage for a spill into waterways.
Baseline data has been collected by biologists at each pipeline-water crossing. Geomapping has been
produced illustrating the rate of contamination spilling into the watershed. The pipline into North Bay occurs
at a severe elevation, putting the city’s drinking water from Trout Lake at risk of irreparable contamination.
There have been dozens and dozens of pipeline failures in Ontario since the early 90s, much of it kept out of
the media, demonstrating non-disclosure business practices. Therefore how can you expect the public to
trust your measures for trust and our safety?
If a spill would occur it is physically impossible for a response team to get to the site in time to mitigate
disaster. In the meanwhile, pollution will have tainted a very important pristine and accessible watershed.
You can count on me to fight Energy East.

 Issues #7 & 11: WDFN’s submissions will describe: (i) our Aboriginal title and rights; (ii) the location of our
traditional territory; and (iii) the spatial and temporal extent of our use of land, water, and resources for
traditional purposes therein. As stated above, the “1857 Arrowsmith map” outlines the areas that we have
used for centuries.
The Project is located adjacent to the South Saskatchewan River, which is a large source of freshwater for all
of Saskatchewan. It also has historical value to the Dakota people. The South Saskatchewan, Qu’Appelle,
Assiniboine, and Souris Rivers were and remain a major transportation route for our people. The South
Saskatchewan River continues to provide subsistence for us. It is one of our major fishing sites. Thus, WDFN
would like to provide further information on the traditional use of these areas as part of the NEB Hearing
process, as well and receive information in order to understand the potential impacts of the Project.
The proposed Project has the potential to cause adverse environmental effects in WDFN’s traditional
territory and therefore has the potential to adversely impact WDFN’s territory, as well as our Aboriginal title
and rights. In particular, an oil spill from the Project has the potential to harm our natural resources and
traditional territory, including the South Saskatchewan River and the water bodies in the vicinity of, and
downstream, of the Project. An oil spill would negatively impact WDFN’s use of land, water, and resources in
our traditional territory.
Project construction and operation also have the potential to adversely impact our Aboriginal title, rights, and
interests. Aboriginal title has an economic component. WDFN’s economic interest in our title lands will
therefore need to be accommodated.
WDFN’s evidence and submissions will describe potential environmental effects resulting from the Project
and corresponding impacts to our Aboriginal title and rights. They will also discuss cultural sustainability and
economic participation in the Project, including employment, procurement and contracting opportunities
provided by TransCanada.
Issue #13 & 14: WDFN will make submissions about contingency planning and emergency response for oil
spills during construction and operation of the Project. In particular, the traditional knowledge and
traditional land and water use information we will share with TransCanada and the NEB will help inform
contingency planning and emergency response for oil spills. For example, our traditional land use information
could be included in TransCanada's emergency response plans and maps as high consequence areas. Use and
occupancy sites could also be included in TransCanada’s Intelligent Valve Placement (IVP) modeling.
Issue #16: Material provided to date by TransCanada does not satisfy WDFN. We believe additional
mitigation measures are needed to avoid potentially significant, negative impacts on our Aboriginal title and
rights.

This pipeline runs directly through my area and very close to homes, schools,business, farms as well as water
ways in the area.
The current pipeline was designed for natural gas, which the event of a rupture would not pool and create a
disaster that takes years to clean up like the one on the Kalamzoo river.
On Sunday, July 25, 2010, a 40-foot pipe segment in Line ruptured. The rupture in the Enbridge Energy
pipeline caused a 1,100,000 US gallons spill of diluted bitumen or heavy crude oil originating from Canada
into Talmadge Creek which flows into the Kalamazoo River.
Though alarms sounded in Enbridge's Edmonton headquarters at the time of the rupture, it was eighteen
hours before a Michigan utilities employee reported oil spilling and the pipeline company learned of the spill.
Meanwhile, pipeline operators had thought the alarms were maybe caused by a bubble in the pipeline and,
while for some time it was shut down, they also increased pressure for periods of hours to try to clear the
possible blockage, spilling more oil. This would surely see my entire area and thousands of people evacuated
from their homes and possible deaths.
The oil was "contained" to a 40 km stretch of the Kalamazoo River as several hundred workers took part in
the cleanup.The EPA estimated that it would take weeks to remove the bulk of the oil from the river, several
months to clear oil from the flood plains, and several more months to clean the oil out of the marsh where
the spill originated. However, a year later, a 40 Km stretch of the river remained closed. Originally estimated
at $5 million,by September 2011, cleanup costs passed $585 million and were expected to rise by 20 percent
more. The cleanup expense by summer 2012 had totaled $765 million.
Lac-Mégantic rail disaster occurred July 6, 2013, when 74-car freight train carrying Bakken formation crude oil
ran away and derailed, resulting in the fire and explosion of multiple tank cars. Forty-two people were
confirmed dead, with five more missing and presumed dead. More than 30 buildings in the town's centre,
roughly half of the downtown area, were destroyed all but three of the thirty-nine remaining downtown
buildings are to be demolished due to petroleum contamination of the townsite.
The other factor that has to be included is that Dilbit is a highly explosive substance like we saw in Lac
Magantic and this pipeline currently runs through residential neighborhoods in my area.
My goal is not to stop the line, but to ensure that the line is re routed further away from schools, homes and
people to mitigate the possibility of death and sickness.

Step 1 - I am applying as:
                                             An Individual
The following describes the categories under which you may apply . If you want to apply as a
group or authorized representative, please contact the Board and request a form for that category.
An Individual is one person or landowner who may or may not have a lawyer or person
speaking on their behalf and who will represent their own personal interests. Apply as an
Individual if you plan to bring forward issues regarding personal impacts or property-specific
issues, and you are not represented by a Group. Use the Individual ATP Form if you have a
lawyer or representative but are filling in the ATP Form yourself. If your lawyer or
representative is filling in a form for you , you do not need to complete a separate ATP Form.
An Authorized Representative on Behalf of an Individual is someone who speaks or submits
documents on behalf of an Individual. This may be a lawyer or other person. An Authorized
Representative will present the views and personal interests of the Individual they are
representing.
A Group is:
    •   an organization with its own interests (for example, a company, NGO, special interest
        group, Aboriginal group, government agency), or
    •   a collaboration of two or more people that represents the common interests of those
        people.
The Group will have a Main Contact Person(s) and may also have an Authorized Representative
such as a lawyer. The Main Contact Person will usually fill out the ATP Form on the Group's
behalf and will respond to questions in the hearing on behalf of the Group if participation is
granted. A Group representing an Individual should select the ATP Form for Authorized
Representative on Behalf of an Individual.
Since participating in an NEB hearing can require considerable time and resources, we
encourage people with similar interests or views to apply to participate as a Group.

 Step 2 - Hearing Information
The Energy East Project is defined as an approximate 4,500 km pipeline system designed to
transport crude oil from receipt points in Alberta and Saskatchewan to delivery points in Quebec
and New Brunswick. The proposed Project would include:
    •  The acquisition of natural gas facilities by Energy East Pipeline Ltd. from TransCanada
       PipeLines Limited and the conversion of those facilities to oil service;
    •  New pipeline constmction in Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Eastem Ontario, Quebec
       and New Brunswick to line up with the converted pipe;
    •  Constructing the associated facilities, pump stations and tank terminals required to move
       crude oil, including marine facilities that enable access to other markets by ship.

Step 4 - Privacy Agreement
The Board is authorized to collect, use and disclose personal information in the context of any
Board proceeding. Except where confidentiality is granted, all information and documents filed
with the Board as an Individual or on behalf of other Individuals will be made public.
Additionally, any contact information provided may be used to contact you or serve documents
on you.
Under the federal Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act, the
Regulations Specifying Publicly Available Information state that personal information in a record
of a quasijudicial body (like the Board) is publicly available without consent, provided that the
collection, use and disclosure of that information relates directly to the purpose for which the
infon:nation appears in the record.

 Step 7 - Method or Level of Participation
Tell us how you want to participate:
A Commenter:
    •   may provide written views on the proposed project in a single Letter of Comment;
    •   may include information supporting the views such as maps or photographs;
    •   may comment on proposed terms or conditions that the Board should recommend be
        added if the project is approved;
    •   may observe and monitor the hearing through the Board's public registry and heating
        broadcasts; and
    •   is not considered a Party (Intervenor or Company) to the hearing, cannot ask information
        requests or cross-examine other Parties, and cannot provide final m·gument.
An Intervenor:
    •   may file evidence stating their views on the project or providing information;
    •   may ask wiitten questions to clarify the evidence that others have filed;
    •   must answer written questions from others, if asked, about the evidence that they have
        filed;
    •   may be permitted to speak at an oral portion of the hearing; and
    •   may prepare and submit a final argument at the end of the process.
Intervening requires a time commitment to the healing process. In addition to the points above,
you will be responsible to read documents, respect procedural steps, and meet all deadlines.
If you wish to express a personal opinion and do not plan to file evidence or ask or answer
questions, select Commenter as your method of participation.
All timely submissions from patticipants, including letters of comment, are read and considered
by the Board.
The NEB will review your ATP Form and decide whether you are allowed to participate as well
as your method of participation. You may be permitted to patticipate at a level that differs from
what you requested.
Additional information about the role of commenters and intervenors may be found in the
Hearing Process Handbook (insert C in your package).

 Step 8 - Interest or Expertise
The NEB will only use the information provided in this ATP Form to decide if you will be
allowed to participate in this hearing. No other information will be considered. When completing
the ATP Form, you should consider the Hearing Description in Step 2 above and the List of

Facilities Hearing (insert Bin your package)
You are "directly affected" if you have a specific and detailed interest in the proposed Project
that may be affected by the Board's decision. You have "relevant information or expertise" if
you have knowledge that will assist the Board.
If you are applying as being directly affected you must not only describe how you have a
specific, individual and detailed interest related to the List of Issues but must also show exactly
how that interest is likely to be impacted by the Project. If you demonstrate to the satisfaction of
the Board that you are directly affected by the proposed Project, you will be allowed to
participate.
If you are applying as someone having relevant information you will need to explain where this
information originated, why this information is unique, and how this specific information will
assist the Board.
If you are applying as having relevant expertise you must identify the topics for which you wish
to be recognized as an expert and explain how you obtained your expertise. (If applicable, you
may wish to include a summary of your academic qualifications and work history, as well as any
publications or other explanation of why you are an expert). You must also demonstrate to the
Board how the expertise you will provide is relevant to the List of Issues, how this expertise is
beyond what the Board already possesses and how your expert information will add value to the
Board's decision making process.
If the Board determines· that your relevant information or expertise is required and will assist the
Board, it may allow you to participate.

 Trans Canada right of way - two gas lines existing since the early 60's - Keystone Oil Pipe - Keystone
XL Pipe. This is all fenced, and splits my ranch down the middle, and is next to my yard. "Now the
Energy East Pipe is going in, and it is on the edge of my yard." The right of way will be increased, and
less use of my home ranch!
I raise rare Alberta Block Horses, trying to preserve a history of this area, and Alberta. I used to raise
Morgan Horses, and extremely rare Suffolk Punch Draft Horses. Because of this disruption, I
concentrated on the Block Horses, and other breeders will carry on with the other two breeds. This is a
unique issue, and needs to be negotiated accordingly.
The right of way has taken at least one third of my foaling pasture, and the same in some breeding
pastures. Water on one side - none on the other. Every day trying to operate there is a problem
because of this right of way.
Some day, if the grass ever comes back, the fences will be taken down. At this time, we are still living
beside these pipes. There will still be disruptions because of maintenance, and safety checks. On top
of this, think what it is like to sleep beside these pipes, and know that someday one will probably
rupture or blow up!
This is more than a nuisance. This is disruption of my life long livelihood, and my home. This is a
high risk situation, and I did not invite them on my ranch to do this to me. It had better be determined
of destroying the natural native prairie, and the function of a ranch business. An agreement with
whoever is causing this needs to be discussed, and settled.

Bitumen from the oil sands is heavy and requires toxic chemicals to dilute it. In 2010, a pipeline carrying
bitumen ruptured, flooding the Kalamazoo River in Michigan with 3.8 million litres of diluted bitumen.
Conventional clean-up methods have not worked and, despite almost $1 billion in clean-up costs, the River is
still polluted.
There is evidence to suggest that it is not sufficient to leave environmental care in the hands of National
Energy Board. Prior to the NEB's approval of Enbridge's Line9b reversal, CTV's W5 program found that the
NEB only knew of seven spills along this pipeline, while Enbridge admitted to 13. In fact, W5 discovered that
the pipeline had a total of 35 spills, five times as much as the NEB indicated and more than three times as
much as Enbridge admitted.
If we weigh the need to protect watersheds such as Trout Lake against the reality that the bitumen that
would flow through the Energy East Pipeline would most likely be shipped, unrefined, to places like India,
Europe or possibly the United States, it becomes clear that this pipeline is not about needs in Canada but
profit. The value of protecting sole sources of drinking water far outweighs the value of profit-making.

As a landowner who has pipelines crossing her land, I am very uneasy as to the outcome of new projects. The
history of the pipeline companies has certainly not improved as we hear about accident after accident after
accident. The bottom line with the companies seems to be how to lose the least amount of money. The
companies employ PR techniques to calm anyone who is sceptical about pipelines and potential for disaster.
They downplay possible destruction of water sources and the impacts from same. They say that their
pipelines are almost completely foolproof, even in the light of accidents and spills. The bottom line is that we
should not be putting more pipelines in.

 15. Les répercussions financières de la planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement,

L'Association francophone des municipalités du Nouveau-Brunswick (AFMNB) regroupe 53 municipalités
francophones et bilingues, réparties dans cinq grandes régions qui s’étendent du Nord-Ouest au Sud-Est de la
province. Nos municipalités membres représentent plus de 280 000 personnes, soit plus du tiers de la
population du Nouveau-Brunswick.
Notre intérêt réside dans l'impact potentiel de ce projet sur nos municipalités, dont plusieurs sont situées aux
abords du tracé proposé, principalement dans le Nord-Ouest de la province (Edmundston, Grand-Sault, St-
Léonard, St-François, St-Anne, Lac Baker, Baker Brook, Clair, St-Hilaire, Rivière-Verte, St-André, Drummond).
Éventuels effets environnementaux et socio-économiques (re. via un accidents ou défaillances) :
Les effets environnementaux et socio-économiques qui résulteraient de la construction du projet proposé ou
encore de potentiels déversements, accidents ou défaillances lors de l'exploitation ont de plus le potentiel
d'affecter les sources d'eau potables des municipalités et la qualité de vie des citoyens des municipalités de la
région.
Pertinence du tracé, planification des mesures d'urgence et leurs répercussions financières en cas de
déversement, d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation
du projet :
Une grande partie de la responsabilité de la planification des mesures d'urgences au niveau local (municipal)
et régional (Commissions de services régionaux) revient aux municipalités, et celles-ci sont directement
responsables des services de sécurité et incendie qui seraient les premiers répondants en cas de
déversement, d'accident ou de défaillance, que ce soit pendant la construction ou l'exploitation du projet
proposé. Ainsi, nos membres seront directement affectés par toute décision relative au tracé proposé, et à la
planification de l'intervention et des mesures d'urgence. Le projet pourrait d'ailleurs entraîner des coûts
financiers additionnels pour nos municipalités au niveau de la planification des mesures d'urgences et de la
formation des premiers répondants.
Conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation :
Nous ferons également des recommandations à propos des mesures permettant d’éviter ou de contrôler les
problèmes cités ci-dessus. Nous ferons aussi des recommandations à propos des modalités et conditions qui
devraient être prises en considération dans le cas où l’ONE en viendrait à recommander l’approbation du
projet.

I am a retired computer analyst and programmer with a university degree i mathematics and physics. I have
spent the past four years studying the tar sands products(bitumen, diluted bitumen, synthetic crude,
petroleum coke, sulphur), crude oil, natural gas, hydraulic fracturing, pipelines, and rail transportation.
I am particularly concerned about the water crossings in New Brunswick as shown in the TransCanada
documentation.
See:
https://docs.neb-one.gc.ca/lleng/
llisapi.dll/fetch/2000/90464/90552/2432218/2540913/2543426/2543059/Vol_12
L_Detailed_Route_Maps-Append_Vol_12-85_to_12-93%2C_NB_and_Lateral_Segment_-_A4E0Z1.pdf?
nodeid=2543828&vernum=-2
My comments will be limited to the crossings of the Southwest Miramichi river and it's tributaries, the
tributaries of the Nashwaak river and the river itself as well as the Saint John River of which the Nashwaak is
a tributary. These crossings are shown in the Plaster Rock and Napadogan sections of the above document.
I am familiar with much of the Southwest Miramichi from Juniper to Boiestown as I have fished many pools
for Atlantic Salmon and Speckled Trout both of which migrate from the rivers to the Atlantic ocean.
I am also familiar with the Nashwaak river and some of the brooks and streams that flow into it and have
fished them as well.
For example: The S Br SW Miramichi River, Taxis River its tributaries and Lake Brook flow into the Southwest
Miramichi River. McGivney Brook and Arnold Brook flow into the Cross Creek stream which flows into the
Nashwaak River and on into the Saint John River.
The Miramichi River as well as attracting New Brunswick fishers also attracts fishers from many countries in
the world. It is world famous.
Both the Saint John and Miramichi river systems deserve nothing less than the best possible protection. If the
developer considers the best possible protection uneconomical then the project should not proceed.

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012

I work in a school that is directly beside the proposed pipeline route. I use the land involved for teaching. If a
spill occurs at this location I will be affected. Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide
emissions being produced each year - the same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads and larger
than the climate footprint of an Atlantic province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE).
Energy East’s impact is also larger than the Keystone XL pipeline which the United States Environmental
Protection Agency just determined to have a significant impact on climate change. The National Energy Board
needs to take the upstream climate impacts of Energy East into effect because there is no other federal
review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East impact nearly every issue already on the list of issues:
• If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit warming to 2 degree Celsius there is no proven
need for Energy East as tar sands expansion must be capped (http://bit.ly/ 14wgVB4 & http://bit.ly/SccvIZ)
• The economic feasibility is also linked to climate change, especially in relation to the carbon bubble & the
low price of oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
• To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
• There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly
affected landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on
traditional indigenous land use and ways of life and much more.
For these reasons and so many more related to climate change the NEB needs to include climate change in
it’s review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across
Canada.

As a grandmother, I am deeply concerned about accelerating levels of carbon dioxide emissions and dire
consequences that will affect the health and safety of my grandchildren and future generations. The National
Energy Board needs to include the impacts on the environment in the review of the largest proposed pipeline
in North America, Energy East, and the resulting risk factors determining a healthy and safe future.
My family and I live near and shop in Harbour Landing where the forty five year old gas pipeline is located
that will carry sluggish diluted bitumen. This conversion from the original purpose creates a greater risk of
injury and/or death from major ruptures, spills, explosions and fires. We, and the citizens of Regina, will bear
the risks and the costs for upgrading emergency responders, providing specific medical treatment and toxic
clean up.
The Energy East Pipeline would allow an increase in tar sands production of up to 750,000 barrels of oil every
day equivalent to the emissions of adding over 7,000,000 cars to Canada’s highways each year. People living
downstream would experience more toxic exposure. There has been increasing concern about how the rapid
pouring of carbon monoxide into the atmosphere is already altering earthly existence in every region of the
earth, including Canada.
The Energy East pipeline will cross or run near Canada’s most precious drinking water sources to valued
recreation and fishing waters. It would pose threats to local water supplies, communities and coastal waters.
Diluted bitumen sinks in water and is almost impossible and extremely expensive to clean up as witnessed in
the Kalamazoo River in Michigan.
According to the Leader Post, February 23, 2015, the most recent calculation by scientists is that two-thirds of
known reserves of oil and gas and coal must stay in the ground to slow and stop the warming trend. The
Energy East Pipeline would allow an increase in tar sands production that would generate up to 32 million
tones of carbon emissions each year. Canada would not be able to meet its emissions agreement, made with
the international community, to keep the global average temperature below two degrees Celsius.
To consider the environmental, social and economical effects of this gigantic project without considering the
environment and climate change impacts is not logical. Not including climate change in the Energy East
Pipeline review would be irresponsible and a failure to protect our grandchildren and future generations
from dire environmental consequences.

 1.     The need for the Project
7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
9.     The appropriateness of the general route and land requirements for the Project
11. Potential impacts of the Project on Aboriginal interests
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
14. Contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction and operations of the
       Project
Energy East would facilitate 32 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions being produced each year, the
same as adding over 7 million cars to Canada’s roads, and greater than the climate footprint of an Atlantic
province (http://bit.ly/1eB0LaE). This is also 10 million tonnes per year greater than the Keystone XL pipeline,
which the United States Environmental Protection Agency has determined to have a significant impact on
climate change. The National Energy Board needs to take the climate impacts of Energy East into
consideration as there is no other federal review for climate change and fossil fuel projects.
The climate impacts of Energy East will affect nearly every issue on the list of issues:
If Canada joins the world in taking meaningful action to limit global warming to 2 degree Celsius there will be
no proven need for Energy East as tar sands expansion will need to be capped (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
The economic feasibility of the project is also linked to climate, especially in relation to the carbon bubble
and the low price of oil (http://bit.ly/14wgVB4)
To consider “the potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project” without considering
climate change as a cumulative impact simply makes no sense in a world grappling with climate change.
There are also significant impacts related to climate in relation to “aboriginal impacts” and “directly affected
landowners and their land use” given the significant impact of climate change on farmers, on traditional
indigenous land use and on ways of life.
For these reasons the NEB needs to include climate change in its review of Energy East. Failing to do so is an
abdication of the regulator’s responsibility to people across Canada.
I live in Gatineau, and am concerned about the pipeline spilling and contaminating the Rideau River, and then
the Ottawa River. This will have a negative affect on my health, as tar sands dillbit is quite toxic and should
not be transported through an old pipeline.
 I also question the need for this pipeline, as there are reneable energy alternatives available that our
government should be moving towards. Finally, as a young student, my generation will feel directly the
impacts of climate change, which the oil transmitted through this pipeline will exacerbate significantly.
As pipelines always spill, there is no good route for a pipeline.

7.     The potential environmental and socio-economic effects of the Project, including the environmental
       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012
12. Potential impacts of the Project on directly affected landowners and their land use
13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency

I have 2 urgent concerns:
First, I live on a family farm at the mouth of Belleisle Bay and the proposed pipeline is detailed to cross at the
head of this important recreational tidal waterway, approximately 5 miles away. Even without an accident I
believe our property value will significantly decrease if this Project proceeds as currently planned. More
importantly, should an accident or spill occur our large farm waterfront property would be rendered
uninhabitable because of our immediate downstream proximity. I believe the environmental risks associated
with the pipeline would be born disporportinately by my family and community, and these risks have not
been adequately considered in the Project's business plan. Further the Belleisle Bay area is a vibrant
recreational area that has good potential for future economic development. The proposed pipeline would
threaten this. In addition our local access to emergency health service has always been a concern, as such I
would question the Project's emergency response plan.
Secondly, I am a recently retired professor of nursing, an expert in mental health, with over 30 years
experience. I am internationally recognized as an expert in woman abuse, with several peer reviewed
publications, with completed and on-going nationally funded research. I believe there are health impacts,
specifically mental health impacts associated with the pipeline project that have not been adequately
considered. To date the pipeline in NB has been presented as a'goldmine' economic opportunity. Details
concerning the reality of mid and longterm employment opportunities suggest that false expectations have
been harmfully seeded among NB citizens. This style of 'Boom-Bust' economic development has shown to
negatively affect longer term community cohesiveness and patterns of mental health and social well-being.
This is particularly important to consider in NB where we have one of the highest rates of male suicide in
Canada and one of highest rates of intimate partner violence and domestic femicide. This issue I believe
should be considered as part of the potential socio-economic effects of the Project.

In the 1920's, my Swedish grandparents homesteaded in Benoit Twp. This is on the east side of Hwy 11N at
the Temiskaming-Cochrane district line, a few miles north of the Arctic watershed. As landowners, we have

inclusion.
My current home in North Bay ON is a mile or so from the pipeline. My city is intervening, and our drinking
water comes from from Trout Lake . That's another reason I should be included.

I question the need and the viability of this project. The economic feasibility of this project is not going to
affect Saint John enough to warrant it. I need to know the potential environmental effect that wil affect the
beaches surrounding my home. The route and land requirements of this project are going to affect our
waterways, tributaries, and wildlife in a negative way. There has been very little information supplied to me
by Transcanada regarding any of my issues, being a property owner in Red Head. I have seen no contingency
plans for any spill or accident or how that will affect my land and drinking water. I'm also concerned with
answers not being readily available with regard to the health issues of myself and children.

 1.     La nécessité du projet

                    ƕ du calcul des droits qui seraient exigés par la société Energy East Ltd.
7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
12. L’incidence possible du projet sur les propriétaires fonciers qui sont directement touchés et sur leur
       utilisation des terres
13. La sécurité et la sûreté associées à la construction et à l’exploitation du projet, y compris la planification
       de l’intervention d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés par des tiers
14. La planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement, d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les
       travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
15. Les répercussions financières de la planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement,
       d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
16. Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office à l’égard du
       projet
Je suis propriétaire des lots 3692677,3692681,3691632,4345148,4345149 à ST Raphael,Bellechasse.
Le pipeline projetté traverse ma terre dans une zone inondable et la Rivière du Sud qui longe ma terre.
Avez vous prévu d'arrêter l'écoulement par des vannes à proximité de la Rivière en cas de d'accident ou
déversement?
Quant est t'il des risques à moyen terme quand le pipeline vieillira et comment vous prévoyez son entretion
et les compensations des dommages et remise à niveau de l'environnement?
Ma propriété perdra beaucoup de valeur d'autant plus qu'une rue est déjà prévue par la municipalité et un
développement éventuel potentiel à proximité du parcours du pipeline en plus de projets futurs au niveau
récréatif à proximité de la Rivère du Sud .
Mes préoccupations sont d'ordre économiques et environnementales à court et à plus long terme.
C'est pourquoi je désire me faire entendre (ou mon représentant) sur ces préoccupations ,sur la pertinence
de ce projet et de son tracé.J'aimerais avoir davantage de précisions techniques concernant la traversée de la
Rivière,les mesures de sécurité prises par le promoteur et la municipalité en cas de déversement ou
d'accidents.
Par ailleurs,la servitude de passage devrait comprendre une indemnité initiale selon la perte encourue par le
propriétaire ainsi qu'une indemnité annuelle pour le risque lié au pipeline ainsi que prévoir des
compensations supplémentaires en cas d'accident avec obligation de remettre le site en bon état.
Camille Cadrin

7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
10. La conception technique et l’intégrité du projet
13. La sécurité et la sûreté associées à la construction et à l’exploitation du projet, y compris la planification
       de l’intervention d’urgence et la prévention des dommages causés par des tiers
15. Les répercussions financières de la planification des mesures d’urgence en cas de déversement,
       d’accident ou de défaillance pendant les travaux de construction et les activités d’exploitation du projet
16. Les conditions devant être rattachées à toute recommandation ou approbation de l’Office à l’égard du
       projet
a) Je réside à environ 300m du tracé proposé et à proximité de la rivière des Outaouais. Il est donc à prévoir
qu'il y aura une valve d'urgence près de ma résidence. Il est normalement reconnu qu'il y a plus de
probabilité d'avoir un bris près d'un point de discontinuité. De plus comme il doit y avoir des interventions
d'entretien sur ce point de coupure, il y a donc plus de probabilité qu'il y ai un déversement à cet endroit que
sur l'ensemble du pipeline. Finalement, à défaut d,information précise, je peux anticiper qu'il peut y avoir des
fuites le long des arbres de transmission qui actionnent le mouvement des valves.
b) Mon habitation est alimentée en eau potable par un puits artésien, toute fuite mineure ou majeure aura
une incidence sur la qualité de mon eau potable. Il faut comprendre qu'une contamination de la nappe
phréatique peut persister pendant des générations. De plus mon terrain est parsemé d'arbres et juxtaposé à
la zone inondable de la rivière des Outaouais. J'ai peine à m'imaginer comment il est possible de
décontaminer un secteur boisé sans raser la forêt. En plus de mes intérêts personnels, il ne faut pas négliger
les répercussions d'un déversement dans la rivière des Outaouais.

                Votre rapport entre vous et les questions soulevées par le projet
1.     La nécessité du projet
2.     La faisabilité économique du projet
3.     Les effets du projet sur les échanges commerciaux, l’économie, l’approvisionnement et le marché
5.     Les effets de la cession d’actifs sur le commerce, l’économie, l’approvisionnement et le marché,
       notamment la nécessité du projet du réseau principal Est, sa faisabilité économique et ses incidences
       commerciales, y compris le caractère approprié de la capacité proposée de 575 TJ/j pour le réseau
       principal Est
6.     Cession d’actifs :
          1. les tests à utiliser pour évaluer la vente et l’achat d’éléments d’actif
          2. les actifs à céder et les conditions à lier à la cession
          3. la valeur des installations aux fins :
                    ƕ du retrait des installations de la base tarifaire du réseau principal de gazoducs de
                        TransCanada PipeLines Limited
                    ƕ du calcul des droits qui seraient exigés par la société Energy East Ltd.
7.     Les effets environnementaux et socioéconomiques potentiels du projet, y compris les effets
       environnementaux des accidents ou défaillances pouvant survenir en lien avec le projet et tous les
       effets cumulatifs susceptibles de découler du projet, comme le prévoit la Loi canadienne sur l’évaluation
       environnementale (2012)
9.     La pertinence du tracé général et des besoins en terrains pour le projet
Nous sommes une municipalité de 352 personnes dont le tracé proposé traverse le territoire. Nous
considérons comme important de vous faire part de notre préoccupation face à ce projet concernant :
La proximité de l’oléoduc par rapport à la principale agglomération de notre municipalité et de la prise d’eau
du réseau d’aqueduc.
Les répercussions, en cas d’accident ou non, sur les principales richesses de notre milieu; qui font de nous un
milieu naturel convoité.
L’impact sur le dynamisme économique et environnemental, tant par la dépréciation de la valeur de l’oléoduc
lui-même, que part la crainte suscité par la proximité d’une telle structure.
Le préjudice à notre politique de développement qui prône la qualité de l’environnement dans le but d’attirer
de nouveaux arrivants.
La préoccupation d’une baisse d’évaluation pour les maisons de notre localité.
L’inquiétude d’un déversement sur la qualité de notre richesse naturelle puisque l’oléoduc traverse la plus
grande tourbière naturelle de notre municipalité et MRC de Témiscouata , un milieu riche en biodiversité
servant de filtre à la pollution et de recharge des nappes d’eau souterraines.
Notre situation à la tête d’un immense bassin versant et qu’un incident majeur pourrait apporter des
complications sur une grande partie de notre territoire.
La portée de l’impact, dans le cas d’un incident majeur, qui demeure méconnue puisqu’aucun oléoduc de
cette ampleur n’existe au Canada et que les eaux souterraines de notre localité n’ont jamais été répertoriées.
La priorité de la municipalité de cheminer vers un développement durable et de diminuer notre empreinte
écologique.

       effects of accidents or malfunctions that may occur in connection with the project, and any cumulative
       effects that are likely to result from the Project, as considered under the Canadian Environmental
       Assessment Act, 2012

13. Safety and security associated with the construction and operation of the Project, including emergency
       response planning and third-party damage prevention

       Project
15. Financial implications of contingency planning for spills, accidents, or malfunctions during construction
       and operations of the Project
I am a landowner with a home and a camp that are both directly adjacent to waterways that will be
negatively impacted by a pipeline leak. In addition to the ecological damage done by a pipeline leak, the
value of my property will be adversely affected by not only an actual pipeline leak, but by the fact that my
property is located where it will always be under the threat of being affected by future pipeline leaks or spills.
Outside of my own personal concerns, I am also a naturalist, photographer, writer and the editor of a local
newspaper. I hike through the woods, fish the brooks and kayak on local waterways. I am extremely
concerned about the effects a pipeline leak will have on these waterways, the regional wildlife and the local
economy.
Our village on the St John River hosts several bass tournaments every year. As 6 of the more than 300
waterways in NB that the pipeline will cross in this province are major tributaries into the St John River, a spill
anywhere near those tributaries will despoil this river for sports fishing and all other recreational uses, and
thus drive away tourists and visitors for many, many years after the event.
Pipeline leaks and spills always negatively impact the health of local residents. The provincial health system is
stretched financially. The additional strain that will come from people suffering from many of the ills
associated with pipeline leaks will further devastate rural communities and their health care options.
A pipeline spill will cause irreversible environmental damage wherever it occurs, yet there will be no
significant benefit to any communities from the pipeline project in terms of jobs or economic development.
This pipeline is for export, and so will primarily feed corporate profits rather than provide benefits to the
people of New Brunswick.
A pipeline through this province is a disaster waiting to happen, and when it does the cascade of effects will
wreck the water, the health of humans, livestock and all animals, destroy tourism, ruin agricultural land and
poison the air with noxious fumes.
A sustainable and abundant human society is what we should be striving towards, and it is possible. But we
need to move away from our archaic dependence on fossil fuels. It is now the time to look to a world of the
future that is powered by clean, green and renewable energy and fuels.

       and operations of the Project
As a tax paying citizen of Canada and New Brunswick and someone who loves Nature, Animals, every type of
Flora and Fauna, and who respects people who regard our lands with reverence – and who treat them thusly
- such as our First Nations friends and local Farmers, I am not only vehemently against the proposal, let alone
the potential reality, of the Energy East oil pipeline, I fear it. And I fear it for multiple reasons – all related to
the potential devastation of everything in Nature that I, and hundreds of thousands of others, hold dear.
The Right whale is one of the most endangered whales on the planet and there are only a recorded 500 Right
Whales living and breeding in Eastern Atlantic waters per a 2014 count. All Right whales are protected
internationally. Building an oil pipeline through the habitat of these majestic mammals is a direct breech of
this protection and any prospect of an oil spill would threaten their limited habitat. As well, the risk of Right
Whales being injured and killed in shipping accidents increases with increased marine shipping. The Right
Whale has been endangered for decades with only about 2000 left in the WORLD! ANY change to their
habitat could mean extinction. The Right Whale IS just as important as Quebec’s Beluga Whale. TransCanada
nixed Cacouna, Quebec, as an oil terminal site because it’s an important Beluga nursery ground. This action
sets precedent.
The pipeline route through New Brunswick would cross our MANY waterways, one of the largest being the
beautiful Kennebecasis River where I have many happy memories. The pipeline ends at New Brunswick’s
highly-prized Bay of Fundy, where one can witness the highest tides in the WORLD! These very same high
tides could logically exacerbate an oil spill and the inherent thick fog of the Bay could exponentially slow
down an emergency response ill-equipped to deal with oil spills. All the waterways affected by the pipeline
route are unique and indispensable to the animals living within and outside of their confines. A personal
favourite is Hammond River, the site of one of New Brunswick’s few covered bridges It boasts a walkway
flanked by wild roses. This beloved swimming hole looks like it may have prehistoric deposits, fossil or
otherwise, so wild and pristine is it. This beautiful green space has a huge rock face one can jump from into
the clear, running water below – if you’re bold enough to brave the huge, prehistoric-looking spiders that live
within.
The construction of some mammoth man-made monster is equal to potential death of all living species
dependent on these waterways, not to mention the ruination that would be caused by an oil spill - anywhere.
A spill would forever harm our fishing holes, swimming spots, canoe routes and wildlife habitat; threaten our
food sources; and risk the health and safety of our community that would be caused by smothering oil spills
and toxic chemicals used by the pipeline.

The Energy East pipeline would put my drinking water supply, and the bodies of water that surround my
home at risk. The Mississippi River is a key tributary of the Ottawa River, the Energy East pipeline would pass
directly next to it and in the event of a spill, oil would flow into the Ottawa River. The main water treatment
plants for Ottawa’s drinking water are located downstream from where the Mississippi River meets the
Ottawa River, at Britannia, and Lemieux Island. A spill into the Rideau River where the Energy East Pipeline
crosses would lead to oil flowing up to 40 kilometers downstream. This means it would flow into the Rideau
Canal, and to the Rideau Falls where the Rideau and Ottawa Rivers meet.
(http://www.canadians.org/sites/default/files/publications/energyeast-waterways-0814.pdf#18) As a lifelong
resident of Ottawa I use all of these bodies of water for paddling, swimming, and skating during the summer
and winter months on a weekly basis. In the event of a spill I and many others would no longer be able to use
these rivers for recreational use. I live within less than a kilometer of the Canal and the Ottawa River, and
within 2 km of the Rideau River meaning I would be unable to escape being affected by an oil spill in the
Ottawa region from Energy East.
In addition to this Energy East would allow for an additional 32 million tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions to
be produced every year. This would make it impossible for Canada to meet it’s 2020 greenhouse gas
emissions target (http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/canada-wont-meet-2020-greenhouse-gas-
emission-targets-report/article21998423/). Energy East would facilitate further expansion of the Alberta tar
sands which would not allow Canada to do it’s part in limiting global warming to 2 degrees celsius
(http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/study-backs-argument-keystone-would-contribute-to-
climate-change/article22335591/). There is no other way for climate change and fossil fuel projects to be
reviewed at a federal level therefore I would urge the NEB to take this into consideration during it’s review.

Manitoba Energy Justice Coalition (MEJC) is a citizen's group made up of Manitobans with expertise in
sustainability, the energy sector, conservation and ecology, Aboriginal politics, and political economy. Our
group are experts in ethical energy development and have a determined stake in the economic, social, and
ecological feasibility of the project.
Our group, since it represents citizens who are property owners all along the pipeline route, especially in the
Whiteshell, St Anne, and Winnipeg Manitoba has numerous pieces of evidence regarding pipeline safety and
spill mitigation as well as insurance liability issues to bring to the board's attention.
In all communities along the pipeline route we have alternative routes and requests for pump station and
safety valve placement. We have expert knowledge in the re-purposing that must take place to make the
pipeline safe.
We wish to speak to how the project pump stations will be powered and the type of product permitted to
flow through the pipe as central questions as to the viability of the asset transfer. Our group has Aboriginal
interest issue concerns to bring to the boards attention for the question of power.
Our organization has a former Manitoba Assistant Deputy Minister of Conservation, a retired biophysicist
specializing in the transportation of hazardous fuels from Pinawa nuclear facility, a Director of Sustainability
for Post Secondary Education, an Account, a trained conservation Program and Policy Analyst, a scholar of
Indigenous Governance, and a trained wildlife biologist for fisheries, and more combining their efforts to
assess the environmental impacts of the project. Who will all be submitting their comments jointly as MEJC.
Our organization is deeply committed to climate justice and therefore believes the review of the pipeline
must be done in the context of all other energy developments in Canada. Our group aims to intervene to
discuss climate change and the economic costs of this project in the context of the tar sands as well as the
global carbon market.
As a group of Manitobans, we will be directly affected by increased water vapour in the hydrological cycle in
Manitoba which will drastically change the climate of Manitoba and have irreversible effects on the provinces
ecological and economic health. We would like to present evidence on this using our expert witnesses.

 The Federation of Northern Ontario Municipalities (FONOM) is a municipal organization that represents 110
member municipalities across northeastern Ontario, many of which will be impacted by the Energy East
Project as the pipeline that will be converted runs through many communities within our region.
The FONOM Board of Directors, consisting of eleven municipal Mayors and Councilors’, represents the local
governments in northeastern Ontario. As leaders within our communities, FONOM has extensive experience
interacting with different levels of government, the private sector and other organizations. Local
governments are held to the highest standards to ensure residents are safe and have a superior quality of
life.
As stewards of vast land across northern Ontario, we have a great interest in ensuring that all potential
environmental effects associated with the Project are appropriately addressed in both the short- and long-
term. Most importantly, we want to ensure that protections are put in place especially in regards to water
crossings and sources of drinking water. Any negative impact to sources of drinking water for a community
could have devastating consequences that municipal governments would have to communicate to their
residents. Municipalities would also have to seek alternative solutions to ensure residents have the services
that municipal governments are mandated to provide. Currently, large volumes of crude oil are being
transported across the province by rail. Continued derailments in northern Ontario have had devastating
effects on municipalities and their surroundings. Therefore, we have a strong interest in the mode of
transportation of such product across our region.
FONOM also acknowledges the socio-economic impacts that the Energy East Project would have on many of
our member municipalities. Many residents of our municipalities would be employed within the construction
and operation phases for TransCanada Pipeline’s Energy East Project if it is to proceed. Therefore, we
acknowledge the opportunity to employ our citizens with highly skilled jobs, as well as training opportunities
for local apprentices. Further, there are economic opportunities for the businesses in our communities who
would benefit from increased local commerce.
Our organization has a specific interest in regards to the safety and security measures that will be
implemented during both the construction and operation of the Project and how they will be communicated
to municipalities. Emergency response planning must be clearly communicated with municipal emergency
services such as fire and police. As an organization that understands municipal planning issues as they relate
to emergency services, we can assist in providing information in best practices and what needs to be
implemented.
In conclusion, FONOM which represents the interests of 110 municipalities across the northeast has a strong
interest in the process and outcome of this project. As local leaders, our organization also has significant
experience and knowledge in regards to working with municipal governments as well as provincial and
federal government officials.

Step 1 -1 am applying as:
                                            An Individual
The following describes the categories under which you may apply. If you want to apply as a
group or authorized representative, please contact the Board and request a form for that category.
An Individual is one person or landowner who may or may not have a lawyer or person
speaking on their behalf and who will represent their own personal interests. Apply as an
Individual if you plan to bring forward issues regarding personal impacts or property-specific
issues, and you are not represented by a Group. Use the IndividuaLATP Form.jf you have a
lawyer or representative but are filling in the ATP Form yoUrselTlf your lawyer or
representative is filling in a form for you, you do not need to complete a separate ATP Form.
An Authorized Representative on Behalf of an Individual is someone who speaks or submits
documents on behalf of an Individual. This may be a lawyer or other person. An Authorized
Representative will present the views and personal interests of the Individual they are
representing.
A Group is:
    •   an organization with its own interests (for example, a company, NGO, special interest
        group, Aboriginal group, government agency), or
    •   a collaboration of two or more people that represents the common interests of those
        people.
The Group will have a Main Contact Person(s) and may also have an Authorized Representative
such as a lawyer. The Main Contact Person will usually fill out the ATP Form on the Group's
behalf and will respond to questions in the hearing on behalf of the Group if participation is
granted. A Group representing an Individual should select the ATP Form for Authorized
Representative on Behalf of an Individual.
Since participating in an NEB hearing can require considerable time and resources, we
encourage people with similar interests or views to appy~K5*parFicipate as aCiroup.

 Step 2 - Hearing Information
The Energy East Project is defined as an approximate 4,500 krn pipeline system designed to
transport crude oil from receipt points in Alberta and Saskatchewan to delivery points in Quebec
and New Brunswick. The proposed Project would include:
    •   The acquisition of natural gas facilities by Energy East Pipeline Ltd. from TransCanada
        PipeLines Limited and the conversion of those facilities to oil service;
    •   New pipeline construction in Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Eastern Ontario, Quebec
        and New Brunswick to line up with the converted pipe;
    •   Constructing the associated facilities, pump stations and tank terminals required to move
        crude oil, including marine facilities that enable access to other markets by ship.
Project Name:           Energy East Project and Asset Transfer
Company Name:           Energy East Pipeline Ltd.
NEB File Number:        OF-Fac-Oil-E266-2014-01 02
Hearing Order:          OH-001-2015
Participant Funding is available for this hearing. For information please see the Participant
Funding Program (PFP) Guide (insert A in your package).
The National Energy Board (NEB or Board) has people who can help you to understand the
Board's process and answer your questions about process. They can also assist you if you have
questions about filling in this ATP form.
For process support on this hearing please contact the Process Advisory Team by emailing
energyeast.processhelp@neb-one.gc.ca or calling toll free 1-800-899-1265.

participate.

Step 4 - Privacy Agreement
The Board is authorized to collect, use and disclose personal information in the context of any
Board proceeding. Except where confidentiality is granted, all information and documents filed
with the Board as an Individual or on behalf of other Individuals will be made public.
Additionally, any contact information provided may be used to contact you or serve documents
on you.
Under the federal Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act, the
Regulations Specifying Publicly Available Information state that personal information in a record
of a quasijudicial body (like the Board) is publicly available without consent, provided that the
collection, use and disclosure of that information relates directly to the purpose for which the
information appears in the record.
By signing here, you are indicating that you have read and understood the above

  Step 7 - Method or Level of Participation
 Tell us how you want to participate:
 A Commenter:
     •   may provide written views on the proposed project in a single Letter of Comment;
     •   may include information supporting the views such as maps or photographs;
     •   may comment on proposed terms or conditions that the Board should recommend be
         added if the project is approved;
     •   may observe and monitor the hearing through the Board's public registry and hearing
         broadcasts; and
     •   is not considered a Party {Intervenor or Company) to the hearing, cannot ask information
         requests or cross-examine other Parties, and cannot provide final argument.
An Intervenor:
     •   may file evidence stating their views on the project or providing information;
     •   may ask written questions to clarify the evidence that others have filed;
     •   must answer written questions from others, if asked, about the evidence that they have
         filed;
     •  may be permitted to speak at an oral portion of the hearing; and
     •   may prepare and submit a final argument at the end of the process.
Intervening requires a time commitment to the hearing process. In addition to the points above,
you will be responsible to read documents, respect procedural steps, and meet all deadlines.
If you wish to express a personal opinion and do not plan to file evidence or ask or answer
questions, select Commenter as your method of participation.
All timely submissions from participants, including letters of comment, are read and considered
by the Board.
The NEB will review your ATP Form and decide whether you are allowed to participate as well
as your method of participation. You may be permitted to participate at a level that differs from
what you requested.
Additional information about the role of commenters and intervenors may be found in the
Hearing Process Handbook (insert C in your package).

 Step 8 - Interest or Expertise
The NEB will only use the information provided in this ATP Form to decide if you will be
allowed to participate in this hearing. No other information will be considered. When completing
the ATP Form, you should consider the Hearing Description in Step 2 above and the List of
Issues in Step 9.

Facilities Hearing (insert B in your package)
You are "directly affected" if you have a specific and detailed interest in the proposed Project
that may be affected by the Board's decision. You have "relevant information or expertise" if
you have knowledge that will assist the Board.
If you are applying as being directly affected you must not only describe how you have a
specific, individual and detailed interest related to the List of Issues but must also show exactly
how that interest is likely to be impacted by the Project. If you demonstrate to the satisfaction of
the Board that you are directly affected by the proposed Project, you will be allowed to
participate.
If you are applying as someone having relevant information you will need to explain where this
information originated, why this information is unique, and how this specific information will
assist the Board.
If you are applying as having relevant expertise you must identify the topics for which you wish
to be recognized as an expert and explain how you obtained your expertise. (If applicable, you
may wish to include a summary of your academic qualifications and work history, as well as any
publications or other explanation of why you are an expert). You must also demonstrate to the
Board how the expertise you will provide is relevant to the List of Issues, how this expertise is
beyond what the Board already possesses and how your expert information will add value to the
Board's decision making process.
If the Board determines that your relevant information or expertise is required and will assist the
Board, it may allow you to participate.

Dear Ms. Young:
I am writing pursuant to the Application to Participate Process (ATP) regarding the above Application to
request participation in the proceeding as a late applicant and Commenter status.
AMPCO is a not-for-profit consumer interest advocacy organization. AMPCO' s members represent Ontario' s
major industries: forestry, chemical, mining and minerals, steel, petroleum products, cement, automotive and
manufacturing and business consumers in general. AMPCO members are major investors, major employers
and a major part of communities in which we operate, across Ontario . A list of current AMPCO members is
attached .
AMPCO's member companies would be known to the Board, due to their ongoing involvement in the Board' s
proceedings. AMPCO participates almost entirely in proceedings, working groups, consultations and initiatives
in Ontario, before the Ontario Energy Board and with the Independent Electricity System Operator in which
matters relevant to Ontario' s large electricity consumers are being addressed . Our interest in the current
proceeding relates to potential material effects the application might impose on power consumers in Ontario
with respect to the price, adequacy, reliability and quality of electricity service.
TransCanada has characterized Energy East as a nation building opportunity. We agree that the project has the
potential to create value in every province and the country as a whole. We are concerned that the risks of the
project be thoroughly considered, and in particular, the potential downstream effects for industrial power
consumers in Ontario. Electricity prices in Ontario are derived from underlying fuel costs, i.e., the delivered
price of gas. As we have learned during the past cold winters, perceptions of scarcity in the natural gas market
trigger material increases in total electricity costs, as well as higher and more volatile prices, and more frequent
and extreme price exceedances. The adequacy of the trans-national energy pipeline infrastructure serving
Ontario is therefore of direct interest to AMPCO and its members.
Please serve all correspondence pertaining to this proceeding to AMPCO as follows:

The following describes the categories under which you may apply. If you want to apply as an
individual or authorized representative, please contact the National Energy Board (NEB or
Board) and request a form for that category.
An Individual is one person or landowner who may or may not have a lawyer or person
speaking on their behalf and who will represent their own personal interests. Apply as an
Individual if you plan to bring forward issues regarding personal impacts or property-specific
issues, and you are not represented by a Group. Use the Individual ATP Form if you have a
lawyer or representative but are filling in the ATP Form yourself. lfyour lawyer or
representative is filling in a form for you, you do not need to complete a separate ATP Form.
An Authorized Representative on Behalf of an Individual is someone who speaks or submits
documents on behalf of an Individual. This may be a lawyer or other person . An Authorized
Representative will present the views and personal interests of the Individual they are
representing.
                                                                                        Page 1 of 10
 A Group is:
    •   an organization with its own interests (for example, a company, NGO, special interest
        group, Aboriginal group, government agency), or
    •   a collaboration of two or more people that represents the common interests of those
        people.
The Group will have a Main Contact Person(s) and may also have an Authorized Representative
such as a lawyer. The Main Contact Person will usually fill out the ATP Form on the Group's
behalf and will respond to questions in the hearing on behalf of the Group if participation is
granted. A Group representing an Individual should select the ATP Form for Authorized
Representative on Behalf of an Individual.
Since participating in an NEB hearing can require considerable time and resources, we
encourage people with similar interests or views to apply to participate as a Group.
Step 2 - Hearing Information
The Energy East Project is defined as an approximate 4,500 km pipeline system designed to
transport crude oil from receipt points in Alberta and Saskatchewan to delivery points in Quebec
and New Brunswick. The proposed Project would include:
    •   The acquisition of natural gas facilities by Energy East Pipeline Ltd. from TransCanada
        PipeLines Limited and the conversion of those facilities to oil service;
    •   New pipeline construction in Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Eastern Ontario, Quebec
        and New Brunswick to line up with the converted pipe;
    •   Constructing the associated facilities, pump stations and tank terminals required to move
        crude oil, including marine facilities that enable access to other markets by ship.
Project Name:           Energy East Project and Asset Transfer
Company Name:           Energy East Pipeline Ltd.
NEB File Number:        OF-Fac-Oii-E266-2014-0I 02
Hearing Order:          OH-001-2015
Participant Funding is available for this hearing. For information please see the Participant
Funding Program (PFP) Guide (insert A in your package).
The National Energy Board (NEB or Board) has people who can help you to understand the
Board's process and answer your questions about process. They can also assist you if you have
questions about filling in this ATP form.
For process support on this hearing please contact the Process Advisory Team by emailing
energyeast.processhelp@neb-one.gc.ca or calling toll free 1-800-899-1265.

  Step 4- Privacy Agreement
 The Board is authorized to collect, use and disclose personal information in the context of any
 Board proceeding. Except where confidentiality is granted, all information and documents filed
 with the Board as an Individual or on behalf of other Individuals will be made public.
 Additionally, any contact information provided may be used to contact you or serve documents
 on you.
 Under the federal Personal information Protection and Electronic Documents Act, the
 Regulations Specifying Publicly Available Information state that personal information in a record
 of a quasijudicial body (like the Board) is publicly available without consent, provided that the
 collection, use and disclosure of that information relates directly to the purpose for which the
 information appears in the record.

    •    may provide written views on the proposed project in a single Letter of Comment;

Step 1 -1 am applying as:
                                               An Individual
The following describes the categories under which you may apply. If you want to apply as a group or
authorized representative, please contact the Board and request a form for that category.
An Individual is one person or landowner who may or may not have a lawyer or person speaking on
their behalf and who will represent their own personal interests. Apply as an Individual if you plan to
bring forward issues regarding personal impacts or property-specific issues, and you are not represented
by a Group. Use the Individual ATP Form if you have a lawyer or representative but are filling in the
ATP Form yourself. If your lawyer or representative is filling in a form for you, you do not need to
complete a separate ATP Form.
An Authorized Representative on Behalf of an Individual is someone who speaks or submits
documents on behalf of an Individual. This may be a lawyer or other person. An Authorized
Representative will present the views and personal interests of the Individual they are representing.
A Group is:
    •   an organization with its own interests (for example, a company, NGO, special interest group,
        Aboriginal group, government agency), or
    •   a collaboration of two or more people that represents the common interests of those people.
The Group will have a Main Contact Person(s) and may also have an Authorized Representative such as
a lawyer. The Main Contact Person will usually fill out the ATP Form on the Group's behalf and will
respond to questions in the hearing on behalf of the Group if participation is granted. A Group
representing an Individual should select the ATP Form for Authorized Representative on Behalf of an
Individual.
Since participating in an NEB hearing can require considerable time and resources, we encourage people
with similar interests or views to apply to participate as a Group.
